HAFIZE GAYE ERKAN, PRESIDENT & DIRECTOR, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: Thanks, Jim. Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here with you today. I would like to talk about what's most important to us at First Republic, our secret sauce and the drivers behind our sustainable organic growth, which I think you'll find to be a unique and compelling story.

Let's first start with our financial performance. Since our IPO in 2010. We have achieved a 20% average annual growth rate in total assets, 19% in total deposits, an impressive 28% in assets under management and mid-teens growth rate in total revenue. When we look at revenue per employee, we are well above the banking average. In fact, we found it valuable to compare ourselves to other service-focused industries, such as luxury and technology. So our most relevant growth peers may not even be in banking.

To better understand these results, let's first take a look at who are we. First Republic is a service organization that just happens to be a bank. Service is our product. Therefore, our most important success measures are client satisfaction and household acquisition. Financial metrics, of course, are very important, but these reflect the true drivers of our financial performance. And how have we done? We have outperformed. Our Net Promoter Score, which indicates client satisfaction and loyalty, has been consistently more than double the banking average. Our clients are extremely happy. And we're acquiring households faster than ever. When you look at our historical run rate, we grew consumer households an average of 9%. Take a look at the last 3 years. The growth rate of households has nearly doubled. In short, we are keeping our existing clients happy, and we're acquiring new households at an increasing pace. In addition to being a bank with a regulatory moat, these results speak to the differentiated service moat that First Republic has created by simply taking great care of our clients one relationship at a time.

Now let's move on to what are the keys to our continued success? Or, simply, how do we continue to make this happen? First and foremost, culture. Our culture is grounded on extraordinary client service delivered by empowered, stable, trusted advisers with great accuracy and speeds and incredibly coordinated teamwork. And service excellence is no small thing at First Republic. It is our purpose of existence.

We achieve it by delivering value to our clients in 3 dimensions. First, trust, peace of mind, keeping our bank safe and sound at all times, giving the best advice to our clients, putting them first always. Second, time, our clients' most precious, most important currency. We enable quick decisions. We empower our trusted advisers to move forward, move fast for their clients. And third, experience. We have turned commoditized banking business into highly personalized relationships customized to each and every relationship based on their single point of contact. That is the key to the value delivery, one quarterback for the relationships, one relationship manager per client. The stability, as Jim mentioned, the stability of the relationship managers translates to the stability and happiness of the client relationship. And over the years, we have expanded the services we provide as well as the delivery channel. But the model has remained constant. Each client has their go-to person. There's Fatema, there's Jeff, there is Samir, who deliver the entire First Republic to them and customize their financial journey. After all, First Republic is a collection of individual-client relationship.

The model works. The question is, how do we scale it? Or how do we continue to scale it? Through empowerment. We empower our trusted advisers through knowledge that enhances their service. Our Eagle Intelligence team, our in-house analytics team, provides timely customized alerts and dashboards to our trusted advisers to help them prioritize their prospect or client outreach.

We also empower their service teams, our support teams by removing bottlenecks, by streamlining processes, everything we do within our continuous process improvements. And you'll have a chance to hear more about these initiatives later today. The key is, at First Republic, technology is here to empower our proven high touch service. It does not replace it.

It is this commitment to service excellence that has enabled us to more than double our assets over the past 5 years. Not through acquisitions, not through chasing new markets, simplify by doing more of what we do best, taking great care of our clients one relationship at a time. And that type of relationship banking, as you all know, allow us a ton of value through service quality. Client knowledge allows us to serve our clients better. It enables us to make safe credit decisions. And we better manage risk for our clients. Because we know our clients' typical banking activities, we can identify unusual trends faster. And we also benefit from advantaged funding. What do I mean with that? Of course, deposits. Our bank is largely deposit funded. Because of these relationships, when a client pays down their loan, what do they do? They increase their liquidity and their deposits with their trusted adviser. And our clients bank with us not for a rate, they choose First Republic because of their human trusted adviser and our superior service, which leads us to organic, lower cost, sticky diversified funding, which enables us to grow and grow safely.

Is this growth sustainable? A definite yes, and it compounds. I'll explain why. The equation is simple. First, happy clients stay with us. We have only 2% attrition compared to banking sector at 8%. Other banks are filling a much bigger hole with new clients. We just keep our clients happy. Second, happy clients deepen their relationships, and they refer others. 75% of our growth comes from within, 75%. We wake up, we take care of our clients, and we take care their referrals, this is how First Republic grows. One happy client relationship can create a large referral network. In fact, over the past 5 years, our best client promoters have referred us more than 80 relationships each.

In case you're wondering how is that possible, let me share an example. It all starts with one satisfied client. We deepen our relationships with the clients, we've followed them to their family, their friends and neighbors, their kids' school, the business, accountants and lawyers and, of course, the nonprofits that are close to their heart. And as soon as we touch another individual, the cycle repeats. It is astounding where one happy client can take us.

That's why the model is simple, and it compounds. The more clients we have, the more referrals we get as we grow as long as we continue on superior service because that superior service is not just a soft metric. With a Net Promoter Score more than double the banking sector, it leads to real performance. Amongst the publicly traded top 25 banks, we are #22 in total assets. And our service has propelled us to #1 in asset growth, #1 in credit quality, #1 in revenue growth, #1 in tangible book value per share and #1 in total shareholder return. And here we are after 34 years of organic growth in mid-teens at $111 billion of total assets and $140 billion assets under management.

What's most exciting is that in our current footprint, we still have less than 5% market share, plenty of room to grow. With amazing culture, exceptional people, happy clients, we have everything we need to be successful as long as we continue to focus on service excellence, delivered one client at a time and as long as we continue to work hard and stay humble.

Thank you very much. And with that -- thank you, I would like to invite our Chief Operating Officer, Jason Bender, to the stage, please. Thanks.

In fact, high net worth households represent less than 50% of our client base. And in fact, that's declined a bit as we build out our next-generation strategy, which you'll hear more about momentarily. However, it's still a great segment and one that we do focus on quite a bit.

The important piece to this slide is really the relation between the 2 columns. The left-hand side shows in our markets, what percentage do our markets comprised of the total U.S. population. So 21% of all U.S. households reside in the markets that we operate in. However, almost 59% or 59% of high net worth households reside in those same markets. We have a disproportionate share of high net worth households in the markets that we operate in, and those households represent prospective clients to us.

Now what's also interesting is to note that over time, that share has increased. So back in 2003 when we first started doing this study, our markets comprised 46% of all high net worth households. So it's grown by almost 30% over the years that we've conducted the study. What's that mean? That means that the markets that First Republic are in are either producing or attracting high net worth households faster than the rest of the U.S. by a substantial margin. We'd much rather operate in healthy, vibrant markets that are attracting talent than vice versa.

This takes a look at the raw numbers of high net worth households in those markets. Again, these are not clients that we bank. These are all high net worth households in these markets. But again, as you can see, the green reflects the high net worth households in our markets, the gray, the rest of the U.S. Since we started doing this study, high net worth households have grown at twice the rate in our markets as compared to the rest of the U.S.

This slide kind of puts together those concepts into one place. What you have across the X axis is the growth rate of high net worth households in both our markets as well as others. The light gray reflects other U.S. cities. The dark gray reflects global markets. The Y axis shows the density of high net worth households in those markets. So the markets that are up and to the right are the ones that are growing quickly and are densely populated, relatively speaking, in high net worth households. We really are angling for those markets that are resilient and represent the best opportunities for banking in the U.S.

Now the other interesting aspect of this slide is the size of the bubble on the chart. That represents the relative size in terms of total high net worth households. Just gives you a sense for how many prospective clients reside in those markets. It gets interesting when you start to compare some of them. So New York alone, in terms of the number of prospective clients for First Republic, is equivalent to the number of high net worth households in all of China or all of Germany. Even Boston, which is a smaller city, obviously, has more high net worth households than Norway or Hong Kong. So the point is not to denigrate other markets, obviously, but the point is to show you just how much opportunity exists in the markets that we're in today. So when we talk about not really needing to go to another big, major new market, that's why. And it's really summed up when you look at the market share.

Now Gaye referenced this in her remarks very well. This looks at just high net worth households. It's true across other dimensions as well. This shows our market share of high net worth households since 2003, when we first started tracking this. We're delighted to see that we've gone from 3% to a little over 4% over that time period. In markets that are rapidly growing, the denominator is growing almost as fast as the numerator. But what we're really excited about is the fact that 96% of the high net worth households in the markets that we're in today don't yet bank with First Republic.

So when people ask us, do you have to go to a new market in order to gain more opportunity to keep this growth rate up? The answer is absolutely not. There's so much opportunity in the markets that we're in right now. We could keep doing this for years and years. And that's really a strength, I think, and an important part of the business model.

Let's jump to Net Promoter Score for a moment. We talk a lot about client service. You've heard that already in the first two sets of remarks today. Net Promoter Score for us is just a measure. It's not the end thing that we're after. What we're really after is highly differentiated client service. Net Promoter Score is a way for us to measure that and to monitor that. It's interesting. We came to Net Promoter Score, and it's -- that's a score and a system and a framework that's used by a lot of companies, not just in banking, as many of you know. But we came to that a little bit backwards from most companies. Many companies stumble on Net Promoter score when they have a client service problem that they want to address, and they want to start measuring it and they want to start solving that problem. We came at NPS in order to try to quantify, first, for ourselves and then for others, how is our client service compared to others. Intuitively, we felt it was pretty good. Our growth rate certainly would suggest that it was good. But NPS for us gave us a way to benchmark against others and to really monitor how that service is going. So if there's one thing that we're delighted about when it comes to NPS, it's the stability of that score and the relative outperformance to the banking sector. Our competition.

For those of you who need a very quick refresher on Net Promoter score, it's pretty simple. It's an answer to one single survey question. How likely are you to recommend First Republic, or whatever company you're measuring, to a friend or colleague? The responses are graded from 0 to 10. If you answer a 9 or 10, meaning most likely to recommend, you're considered a promoter. Now note, that's not 5 and above, that's 9 or 10. So to be a promoter, you have to be particularly passionate about the company that you're promoting. 7 or 8 are considered passives. "My bank does what it needed to do." If you're a 6 or below, you're a detractor. So a lot of people don't realize, it's a very skewed score. And this is the way it's graded across all industries. This is the standard approach to NPS. So net Promoter score is simply the percentage of respondents that are promoters minus the percentage that are detractors, giving you a Net Promoter Score. Anything over 50 is considered excellent. And yes, you can have a negative Net Promoter Score if you have more customers saying bad things about you than good things.

You've seen this slide already. We included it simply as an anchor point. It's important. For us, we have typically been in the low-70s, bank overall. And for clients that consider us their lead bank, we're in the 80s. But most importantly is how we stack relative to our competition. And again, 2x the rest of the banking industry, something we're proud of. But also, it's an important part of our business model. And so when Gaye and Jim talk about how the #1 focus is that client service proposition, that's what it's all about. It's trying to maintain that relative difference.

Now we ask other questions in our own Net Promoter Score survey. In fact, when we do this once a year, we ask a lot of questions, and we get great responses. And it allows us to unpack that Net Promoter Score a bit more. And so what this slide is showing here is actually the respondents to about 4,000-or-so written in narrative comments from our clients. When asked, what is it about First Republic that caused you to give the score that you did, the 9s and the 10s for promoters and the rest for passives, detractors. And what's interesting about this is that when you start to group these in themes, the top 3 are all about service and experience. In fact, many of them just go so far as to say, it's about extraordinary service. 61%, almost 2/3, in fact, are commenting on that. And then another 20% to 30% are elaborating, saying, "You make me feel special. You provide something unique that I can't get other places." It's not until you get all the way down to #4 that people even start talking about rates. Now we're competitive on rates when we need to be, but that's not why our clients are with us. They're with us for the first 3 things. And in fact, if you jump down to the bottom 2, you'll see they pick up the themes of service yet again.

Importantly -- let me back up. One more thing. The other aspect of NPS is that we really use it not just as a static metric. We also use it actively to engage with our clients. And so even when the survey is underway once a year, we're using that information, real-time, to respond. So if we do, for instance, get a detractor, we have a banker on the phone with that client immediately as long as they've said that it's okay. It is an anonymous survey. But we give them the option, especially the detractors, if they're having an issue, to have somebody contact them. And so we learn a great deal even as we're conducting the survey. And we unpack it further and we turn that into action items that we focus on throughout the rest of the year. So this is a very -- it's an active and engaged study for us. It's not just a static metric behind the scenes.

So let me end with another example of the power of this client service model. Now we've talked some about high net worth. We've talked about other examples. This one is a bit of a case study, and it looks at deposits. Looks at deposit clients, and it looks at our ability to build deposits in a market that we've been in for a very long time. Now this is all based on public information from the FDIC. So what we're taking a look at here is a 25-year snapshot of First Republic's performance in the San Francisco deposit market. So back in '94, obviously, we had less than $1 billion of deposits. We've grown that very nicely and up into the right, $40 billion to date. That equates to a 20% compounded annual growth rate in San Francisco deposits.

Now the San Francisco market is a healthy market. It's growing too, deposits overall in that market have grown at 7%. But we've outrun the market by 3x. Now that's interesting, and you'll see a lot of slides that are up and to the right today. But for me, what's really compelling, especially when we're talking about differentiated service and the power of referrals, and the power of keeping your clients happy is, again, how we have performed relative to others over that same time frame.

It's a little bit of an eye chart, but what you see here are the top 30 banks in San Francisco by market share -- deposit market share. On the left, 1994, 25 years ago, we were ranked #26. We had 0.5% market share. And what's happened relative to that over the following 25 years today, 2019, we're now #3 at 10%, just behind Bank of America and Wells Fargo. Now most of you know, San Francisco is a very well banked market. Wells Fargo and BofA, both headquartered there for many of these years, and they have been in the top 1 and 2 spot for market share in every single year of this study, 25 years. And we jumped from 26 to right behind them, #3, today, with very little movement in the rest of the chart. So if there's one thing that really sort of drives home the power of keeping your clients happy, growing with them, the power of doing that within a defined marketplace where people talk to one another and your reputation can build, this to me is a perfect example of that.

So that's what I've got for markets and NPS this morning. I'm sure you'll be hearing more about that as we roll through the day. I think at this point now, we're going to take a very brief pause and show you a couple of videos just to kind of liven things up a little bit. Thank you very much.

MICHAEL D. SELFRIDGE, SENIOR EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT & CHIEF BANKING OFFICER, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: My name is Mike Selfridge. I am the Chief Banking Officer at First Republic Bank. It is my pleasure to present the business banking segment for you today. And joining me on stage, I'd like to make a few introductions: Chris Coleman, Chris is the Head of Business Banking; Jeffrey Bruce, who is our Deputy Regional Managing Director here in New York City on the relationship management side; and Scott Aleali, who is our Managing Director of Private Equity Finance, also here in New York City.

So we'd like to talk a little bit about the business bank, its strategy, where it's come and then the growth opportunities looking forward. And with -- Jeff will give a little perspective on the approach to business banking and how it leads from the personal to the business side, as Gaye had touched on. And then with Scott, we'd like to take a little bit of a deeper dive into the capital call lending opportunities for venture capital and private equity.

Jim alluded to the start of the business bank. The concept started in 1999. And if you were to talk to one of our promoting satisfied clients, they were asking us, "Is it possible you could do what you're doing for me on the personal side for the business that I own or influence?" And that sets the foundation for the strategy of the business bank in 1999. I think we did our first loan in 2000, and not a lot has changed since, except the numbers. So when you look at First Republic -- why First Republic for the business bank? And I think of 3 key competitive advantages amongst many as it relates to other financial institutions. The first is unified, cohesive approach. So we don't silo the business bank over here and the personal banking relationship over here and the wealth manager over here. It's unified. So collectively, Jeff and Scott and maybe somebody on private wealth management, probably cohabitate in the same office, same floor. And the compensation is also structured such that they're better off working together in pursuit of what's most important. That's the client. So the unified holistic approach.

The stability of banker and business banker that Jim talked about. And I think of that as being not segmented. So if Scott is that single point of contact for a business, he is such for life. We don't segment like other business banks that we see with our competitors, into the small business bank and the medium business bank and the large corporate business bank. So that drives stability of relationship. And that's not dissimilar to the model of First Republic. And third, I would call it a relentless focus. So our bankers' specialized. They're knowledgeable in about 8 segments that we serve in our markets with deep opportunities. Focus on credit, focus on client, focus on relationship. And as we go through the credit track record of the business bank, you'll see that, that focus on quality credit, allows our bankers to spend less time with a troubled situation, more time with the client.

So knowledgeable bankers, strong credit, deep expertise, holistic approach and you put that together and you look at what the business bank can drive for the overall franchise, it's quite significant. So for example, Chris will touch on some of the numbers that we've been able to generate over the last 19, 20 years. Today, over half of the deposit franchise comes through the business bank at an average cost of business banking deposits of 41 basis points. That compares to about 65 basis points for the average cost of deposits of the entire First Republic Bank for the quarter ended September 30.

For every dollar that we put out in lending on the business bank, we get about $4.3 back in deposits. A great contributor to the deposit franchise and the diversification of that deposit franchise. And lastly, strong loan growth, which comes in at an average loan yield as of last quarter of about 4.38%.

And so I'd like to hand it over to Chris Coleman, I mentioned he's the Head of Business Banking, to talk about our exceptional results.

CHRIS COLEMAN, HEAD OF BUSINESS BANKING, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: Great. Thank you, Mike. That 4:1 ratio has been around as long as I've been around. That deposit-to-loan ratio. And that -- it runs about 12 years. I joined 12 years ago.

To dive into the numbers just a little bit, first, on the deposit side. Here you see a compounded annual growth rate in high 20s, low 30s. Most of that is checking, and as Mike mentioned, it's a little over half of the bank's overall deposits. And then we have a similar growth rate in the lending side for business loans, hovering right around 30% since 2010. We watch that top part of the graph very carefully. That is loan commitments, we view as a leading indicator, a key indicator for more deposits and more private banking. Once you book the loan, the deposit and operating accounts come over in a 3- or 4-month period, typically. And then we're off to the races in talking to not just senior members of the management team, but also the associates and all employees within the firm about private banking opportunities.

So the question we get a lot of times, what is driving this growth? It is that unified, integrated delivery model to the client. So as Mike mentioned, we co-mingle and joint call with the wealth advisers, the business banker, the preferred bankers, bringing the entire bank to the client. That's a critical success factor. We never know in talking to a prospect whether the mortgage is going to be the hot topic, a student loan refinance actually for their son or daughter, or for the associates within the firm. So we always want to be prepared for that. And we employ a lot of tactics and strategies from the way we pay people to literally having them co-mingle and sit with one another, so as to form one team and stay client-centric. That's critical.

The other critical feature is the industry verticals that we focus on. Half a dozen verticals primarily in the professional service realm, doctors, lawyers, accountants and then private equity and venture capital and nonprofits. Those are some of the leading sectors that we work on. That does a couple of things for us. Importantly, by focusing on an industry, one gets much more marketing efficiency. The more you understand that industry and reflect that to the client, the more they're going to give you referrals as well as their own follow-on business. So that's -- it's very efficient from that standpoint.

In equal measure, when focused as an industry expert, you're more likely to detect headwinds for that sector. And the earlier we detect headwinds, the more time we have to make adjustments and work with the borrower through any speed bumps that they may be encountering. So that's critical for us. It also leads to better cash management solutions and more innovative financing in general.

Speaking of headwinds, here's the credit history in a snapshot. Over $50 billion in originations of business lending. 18 basis points in net charge-offs over those 19 years, so less than 1 basis point per year. A major risk mitigant, in addition to the industry expertise of our business bankers, comes with actually having a broad relationship with the client. So if we are banking, not only the firm but also individuals within the firm, and we may have that mortgage or we may be managing their investments, it's much more likely they reciprocate, consider it a full partnership. And they're going to be that much more transparent about any challenges they are encountering. So that's been a major risk mitigant for us as well.

And then finally, to give you even a little better color on how these relationships evolve over time and become multidimensional, let me introduce Jeff Bruce, Managing Director for -- here in New York. Jeff?

JEFFREY BRUCE, DEPUTY REGIONAL MANAGING DIRECTOR FOR NEW YORK REGION, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: Thanks, Chris. So as Chris said, I'm a Senior Relationship Manager here in New York. SCOTT ALEALI, MANAGING DIRECTOR OF PRIVATE EQUITY FINANCE, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: Thank you, Jeff. Good morning, everyone. I'm Scott Aleali. I lead our Private Equity Financial Assets here in New York. The firms are raising bigger funds, and they're raising them faster than they have in the past. They're also expanding out their platforms. You look at what's happening in private debt markets. Firms are going out, they're raising new platforms, raising new -- and executing on new strategy, and they're doing it well. These larger firms, they have ambitious people. Those people are spinning out, and they're creating new firms. They're raising a first fund and they're raising them successfully.

When you look at the amount of uncalled capital that's in the industry today, it's over $2 trillion. That and the growth of the private markets over the last few years sounds like a really big number, but it really only represents less than 5% of the entire world market cap. It means private equity is still a young asset class and has a ton of room to grow.

So with all of this uncalled capital in the market, what does that mean for us? It means demand for capital call lines of credit secured by those unfunded commitments. If you look back 5 or so years ago, these facilities were not nearly as popular as they are today. They were used as a simple cash management tool, a fund that closes on an investment, calls capital from their investors, then they pay it back, they revolve that through the life cycle of the fund. Now firms are using those facilities much more strategically. Examples of that are ways to mitigate their J curve of their fund, which you also get a nice IRR boost. There's been a lot of press around how those funds are using these facilities both good, both bad.

We're very disciplined in our approach. So the majority of our portfolio is in the shorter-term bucket. We'll look case-by-case on letting our clients use lines to establish some of those trends they want to establish in terms of J curve management and enhancement to IRR.

When you look at the middle market U.S. private equity, that's our sweet spot. There's about $300 billion in credit commitments. First Republic has $16 billion of those credit commitments. And with only 6% of our balance sheet and loans outstanding and capital call lines, it gives us a healthy balance sheet and a lot of run rates to continue to grow.

The capital call line is a lead product in this sector. So when a firm goes out, they raise the fund. This is on the forefront of their mind. But we really view it as an opportunity to showcase all the other things that we can do for a firm. The conversation then goes from just the capital call line product to ways that we can work with the firm's management company, providing them short-term working capital or growth capital secured by management fees. It's our professional loan program where we help partners and their employees finance their commitments to funds. And as the conversation starts drifting in that direction, you start talking more about our private banking capabilities. The way it's presented is presented as a team, with Jeff and myself, going and seeing a client, in that example, delivering the entire bank to the firm. The bank is not -- or the firm is not directed to different departments. It is all done through one cohesive team. This approach leads to strong cross-sell across loans, cash management, foreign exchange, private banking and wealth management.

So it's super competitive out there. In the funds business, there's literally 60 banks that are active or at least trying to be active in the space. So why First Republic? I'll really put it in 3 different buckets. The first, reputation and commitment to the sector. We've been in this business for 20 years. When I'm on the front line, looking to get something done, I'm working with credit members who have 20 years of experience. And so that means we're able to execute quickly, get back to our clients quickly and our clients value that.

The second is our platform. I mentioned the ability to bring the personal and the commercial solutions to our clients within one team that stays with that relationship in perpetuity. That last point is super important in this sector. Private equity professionals are long-term thinkers. So when they make an investment in a portfolio company, they're in that portfolio company for several years. When they're looking at a capital call line provider, they're looking at the broader relationship. They're looking at who the team is, is looking at the stability of the team, and they like that their team is not going to turn over.

And then last and not least, and I'll consider it the most important, is the people. The way we have our teams set up, every person that's inter-facing with our client is an expert in our clients' industry. So our foreign exchange professionals, our cash management professionals, our private bankers, our business bankers, they all speak the same language as our clients. And that makes it easier for our clients to do business with us. And when we make it easy, they want to do more business with us.

So the consistent theme here is just delivering a superior experience to our clients. It'll lead to organic growth within our existing portfolio and lead to opportunities to work with new firms.

Our financial planning team can help our clients work through that process of wealth creation to wealth preservation through financial planning. And my team and I come in to work with clients exclusively when we've been named in our estate planning documents to serve as a trustee, as an executor, as an agent for either of those 2 roles. Marry that with our First Republic, high-touch, high-service experience on the banking and lending side, offer advisory solutions that help mitigate risks such as insurance and foreign exchange, and we've got it all under one umbrella. I think that's what makes us win. So what we're able to do is really provide a customized experience for each of our clients in a very seamless way.

ROBERT LEE THORNTON: Thank you. So how does this model and how does the ways we serve the client translate itself into growth and benefit of the enterprise?

So since 2010, you can see the fee revenue contribution to the bank has grown from 6% to 14% through the third quarter of this year. That's come not only through the growth of investment management and brokerage, but increasingly greater growth from insurance, foreign exchange and trust. So we've continued to diversify the bank's revenue growth as well as doing that while the bank business is still, as you know. So we've had to grow actually at a higher rate than the bank to represent a higher percentage of our growth, and we expect that we'll have a good opportunity to do that as we move forward.

One thing I want to chat a little bit about is our asset growth. You can see that we've increased our assets under management about 8.5x since 2010, and this has largely occurred through organic growth rather than RIA acquisitions. There are 2 things that really drive our asset growth. The first is market appreciation and the second is what we call net client flow. Net client flow is simply the amount of new assets that come in less assets that leave.

So on the next page, I'm going to talk a little bit about how each has contributed to our growth. So since the beginning of 2013, we've grown about $100 billion. Almost 70% of that growth has come from what I'd describe as net client flow and about 30% from market appreciation. We can't -- we haven't found a way to control the market yet, but we do focus very much on net client flow. And we have found that's typically quite strong regardless of market conditions.

One of the things that allows us to have such strong net client flow is that I believe we have more sources of growth than many of our competitors. First, we have very capable advisers who are very engaged around growing their client base, either from getting assets -- more assets from existing clients or developing new clients.

Number two, we have a very strong referral model, where our relationship managers and our other bankers are very focused on referring their clients to wealth management. And last but not least is new teams. We've generally hired 7 to 9 new wealth management teams around the country, generally 1 or 2 per market, consistently over the last several years.

I want to focus in a little bit on the bank referral model because I do think that's one of our unique strengths. I remember an adviser and his partner joining us about 3 or 4 years ago, and I had lunch with them a year later, and they've been quite a recipient of bank referrals. And they said, you know, Bob, when we joined, you told us about these bank referrals, but we didn't really believe you. We've heard there are things called platypuses, we've seen pictures of them, but we didn't know they really existed. And we've been the benefit of a lot of bank referrals.

And the question is why. How did a little over $6 billion of referrals come from about 150 bankers to our wealth management professionals? And that's almost pretty much doubled just since 2014. Well, one, as Mike and others have talked about, we really work on having people collaborate together. They sit together. They sit across the hall from one another. They know each other. That's no small matter. They respect the professionalism of their colleagues. Our compensation structure rewards that not only for closing the business, but our bankers receive a trailer in perpetuity to ensure that the wealth management part of the relationship remains strong alongside the wealth professionals supporting the clients. We do train and training in the sense of not only how do you get comfortable talking about wealth management but our products and services. And last but not least, we have a professional called a wealth adviser, about 20 in the country, whose principal focus is really working with our bankers to refer bank clients to wealth management based on the nature of their clients' holdings, what firm they may have their assets at today, their investment style, who's the best matchup.

But I'm going to turn to my 2 colleagues to briefly share 1 or 2 examples of referral activity you've been involved in and why this has worked. Maybe, Kris, I'll start with you.

KRISTIN ASHMAN: Not only do our bankers bring us in to be the subject matter expert and the experienced fiduciary on my side, but they also bring us in to help close the business and to help expand that business. And in my case, in particular, a banker called me because his long-time client needed an executor of his estate. We won the mandate and through that estate settlement process, we increased assets under management extensively as well as created a very long-term relationship on the trust company side by serving as trustee. So I think what works well is that the bankers trust us. They bring us in early, and they know we're there to help close and to help grow that business.

ROBERT LEE THORNTON: Next, George?

GEORGE FUCHS: Thanks, Bob. I'd like to mention a recent win that we've had akin to the collaboration that you mentioned. So our team, our direct team was asked to partner with the relationship manager by a wealth adviser. And the relationship manager had a client relationship, providing banking and lending services to the client. And the goal -- the first goal of the meeting was to generate more banking services and also more lending opportunity from this client, who we understood to be of pretty good means -- pretty well means, had a large net worth and also was the business owner of a midsized company here in New York City. So we entered the meeting with that knowledge, and the initial second target was a private wealth management acquisition, including both asset management and financial planning for this client. What we uncovered during the exploratory stage of the meeting, and it's the 4 of us at that meeting, was that there was also a need for wealth management, significant opportunity wealth management services for the clients' organization. The client did mention to us in viewing our team as being cohesive and decided to refer us to his investment committee for this potential corporate mandate. And so at the close of the meeting, we were able to get the private wealth opportunity, which was smaller but being referred to the investment committee then allowed us to meet with the committee and close the business shortly after. The total business under assets under management and acquisition was about $90 million, and our whole team continues to service the client. We will not disband.

ROBERT LEE THORNTON: Let me turn to deposits. While assets under management and wealth management fee revenue is very important to our efforts, deposit growth is equally important. We're about 10% of the bank's deposit base, and that has increased -- our overall deposits have increased year-to-year. You can see that in the last year, we've grown about 21% in terms of deposits from sweeps and referred deposits.

Again, question, why is that working? Well, number one, we have fantastic banking services. A lot of the colleagues who join us from other firms are not used to being quite as comfortable with referring their wealth management clients to banking. And here, it's a layup, and they're very excited to do that.

In addition, we've really made it just an important focus in terms of recognition. A lot of the good things I talked about with respect to bank referrals to wealth management apply when we're referring wealth management clients to banking, teamwork, compensation, long-term investment by the team in terms of maintaining the banking relationship. So again, I see this as being a continually important part of our wealth management focus.

We talk about household growth, the new household growth of the bank, and that's very important. One of the things we see as a great opportunity continuing for wealth management is our existing clients. Even though we've had a very high growth rate in terms of assets under management, just over 90% of our bank clients do not have a wealth management relationship. And you say, well, "Bob, better get off the stick. You kind of can't get that number." Well, the reality is, again, we've doubled in the last 2 years, we did $6 billion. Overall, obviously, our bank base is growing significantly, but we see this as still a great opportunity for our overall growth before adding new additional clients or households.

Somewhat similarly on the wealth management side, 61% of our wealth management clients are not yet banking clients. But again, that effort is very strong, 95% of our wealth professionals preferred banking last year. So it's just continuing to introduce clients to the bank, and those numbers will continue to grow.

I want to finish talking about some specific opportunities that we have identified as we move through the next year or 2. I talked about bank referrals, which I think will remain strong. We continue to be a very attractive home for new teams, new wealth managers. If you've been watching our press releases, we've announced 3 very prominent wealth management team hires just in the last 6 or 7 weeks, including one on Friday from UBS in Los Angeles, and I think we'll continue to be attractive because of our model, because of our culture and our ability to serve the client's full relationship.

We also have increasingly turned our attention to engaging later generations. As clients age, they generally have their wealth set, not that we're not happy to continue to manage that, but the complexity in their lives continues to grow. There's more trust planning issues that can arise. They may want legacy planning. They want to set up more foundations. They want to educate their kids. So that's a big opportunity for us. And I think one of the secrets to that is one of the things that Gaye has shared, which is our retention. We have very high retention of clients. So that makes our job easier to try and maintain the family.

I also want to just draw attention, as I mentioned at the outset, to foreign exchange trust and insurance. Those are increasingly significant for us and, again, a reflection of continuing to serve the entire client relationship. About 2 years ago, we introduced Eagle Invest, which was our online investment management service. That is something that we expected that we're still quite pleased is growing. It was always meant to be both a way to serve clients who maybe didn't have the wealth to really support a day-to-day wealth manager, but it's also a way to engage our younger clients, our student loan refinancing PLP clients, and that's had, I think, a meaningful impact in those areas as well.

So I want to thank you -- we want to thank you for your attention. We hope you walk away with a better sense of why we're different and unique and why we think that'll continue to support, which we think is a terrific growth opportunity in wealth management. Thank you.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: Thank you, Bob, Kristin and George. Thanks, everyone. We're going to take a 15-minute break now. So if you could please just be back in your seats at 5 till noon. We would appreciate it. Thank you.

The single lesson that the Chinese have taken over the past year of trade negotiations and non-negotiations on the security and tech side has been that they can never be this vulnerable again to the Americans being able to cut them off. And that means building their own semiconductors. Now does this mean the end of globalization? And the answer is, no. It really depends on what part of the global economy you're talking about. It's really problematic for high tech. It's really not for commodities. So let me take you through that for a second.

If you think about oil and gas and rare earths, even food, I would argue despite everything I just said, despite all of the questions of illegitimacy and polarization in the west, despite all of what the Chinese are doing, actually the commodities markets are becoming more global, more efficient. And they don't want to be made into a political football, so as a consequence, let everybody take advantage of it, and we'll just be the neutral -- no arbiter, not our problem. That's a problem.

So I do think that I'd worry less about the cyber, are they going to break the financial institutions. I think the people that are vulnerable there, spending an awful lot of money trying to get ahead of the curve, I am more worried about what happens with fake news and algorithms where people are believing things that just aren't so. A very small amount of money can weaponize information in ways that cause serious problems for government and society. We have not figured it out. We're not close to figuring that out.

I've got time for, I think, 1 or 2 more. Who wants to go? One over here.

STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: It's Steve Alexopoulos, JPMorgan. So on China, first, what do you think the odds are of a phase 2 deal ultimately getting done? And second, how do you think Hong Kong resolves with China?

IAN BREMMER: I think the chances of a phase 2 deal are functionally 0. The Chinese are actually offering less in this phase 1 deal than they were offering to Trump and to Lighthizer, et al, a few months ago when we had the back and forth. The Chinese, number one, believe that they've already expended political capital with Trump, and it hasn't gotten them very far, so Xi Jinping doesn't want to do that again. Secondarily, they understand the impact of the trade war is growing on the U.S. economy, 2020 compared to 2019, and Trump really wants to avoid that in the run-up to the elections. So for both of those reasons, the Chinese are really unwilling to go farther than where they are right now. They think it's in their advantage to wait Trump out. They're probably right.

Now I'm talking about a phase 2 deal in the remainder of the Trump administration. I'm not talking about what would happen in the next administration. I don't know. It depends on who's elected. It depends on where the Chinese economy is at that point. But I feel very confident about that pre-election call. The kinds of things that the Trump administration have demanded for the Chinese for a phase 2 deal, which means basically changing their legal system in terms of state subsidies and the ability to have sovereignty and autonomy over tariffs in an asymmetric way, the Chinese simply will not accept. Those are red lines. Those have been from day 1. So I don't think we're moving anywhere on that.

But let's keep in mind that the Huawei issue and the tech issue isn't part of this anyway. It's separate. And you now have just 2 weeks ago, 8 new Chinese AI companies, including national champions in the space that have been placed by the blacklist by the United States. And Congress saying that they will not allow Trump to put those companies back in play, even if he wants to. So really tying the hands of the President what happens to matter strategically most to the Chinese.

Your other question was about Hong Kong. I think the fact that President Xi in the last week has indicated that he is willing to let Carrie Lam go as Executive of Hong Kong implies that they now feel fairly confident that in the near term, they've broken the back of these demonstrations, close to where Macron eventually got by giving a little -- but generally also waiting them out with the gilets jaunes, the yellow vests. I think that's right.

School is back in session. The numbers we're seeing in Hong Kong on the streets are so much lower than they were. About 1,000 demonstrators have been arrested. Some have been released. Most are still in jail. It's a leaderless movement, but still, they got the people that had the most influence on the ground, those that played a bigger role in social media. And the Chinese said that they would fully withdraw the extradition law, which they have now done. So I think when you put those things together and the fact that tourism to Hong Kong is down over 50%, it's been a big hit on the economy, they feel pretty confident.

Now last week, you had the Fourth Plenum in China, which is a very important Chinese communist meeting. And coming out of that meeting, there was a press conference that I watched, and it was quite something to see the statements that were made about Hong Kong, which were not in any way talking about how we're going to find a modus vivendi with these people. It was, we are going to integrate them into our new Silicon Valley of China.

The role that Hong Kong used to play is not the role they're going to play in the future. Now this will lead to more demonstrations of young people long term. They don't care. Hong Kong in 1997 during the handover was 13.5% of the entire Chinese economy. Today, it's 2%. And that really changes the way you think about Hong Kong if you're in China. It really changes the way.

And it also means that for those international companies that have thought that they can do their China business out of Hong Kong, the answer is no. You should either be doing it in China, of which Hong Kong might be a China play, but you need to have reasons for that, or you're in Singapore. But the idea that Hong Kong is going to continue to play this conduit role over the next 5 to 10 years, no one -- they should be disabused of that.

Last question, who has the last one? Don't make me make something up, because I'll do it. We haven't talked about Russia, Brazil, Latin America is off. Who else? Nothing?

I'll tell you a final point then, give you something upbeat on. So populism, as you know, goes both left wing and right wing. Anti-establishment works in both directions. I want to be clear that in Brazil, you have an extraordinary populous movement that was really deeply angry at how the establishment in government, in congress, presidents were caught up with this strategic nasty corruption around infrastructure and Odebrecht and the rest. And as a consequence, they actually elected this complete outlier, Bolsonaro, who offends people on social media and he's close to the military and isn't really a lover of democracy. And yet, you now have, by far, the broadest economic structural reforms of any emerging market in the world being put into place by Bolsonaro, not just on pensions, but microeconomic reform, administrative reform, privatizations, sanitation measures, you name it. Brazil's economic outlook is going to be dramatically better as a consequence of that populism than what you had under Dilma Rousseff or Lula.

So let's not pretend. Just in the United States, a number of Trump's own policies, which he -- which came in on anti-establishment but would have been seen as very positive for the corporates, very positive for investment, that actually has the ability to happen in other countries, too. Anti-establishment sentiment just means you're going to throw the bums out. But what you end up with can be radically different from country to country.

In Argentina, it's pushing in one way. In Brazil, it's pushing in exactly the opposite. Really important to dig into those countries and be aware of that as opposed to just take this as a broad anti-market phenomenon. I think it's politics are playing a much greater role, but they're playing a greater role in opportunities in addition to risk.

That's my 40 minutes. Hope you have a great rest of your day. See all you, guys.

And one way to measure that is through a loan-to-value ratio. So look at our 5 real estate secured loan types: single family, home equity line, multifamily, commercial real estate and construction. And you can see in all cases, in the last 4 years, the loan-to-value ratios have dropped, and that was a conscious decision we made 4 years ago when real estate was getting very expensive, and we didn't think that trees could grow to the sky, and we got a little bit more conservative. Now in hindsight, we're a little bit early and a little bit maybe too conservative, but we still grew a lot, and we cut our loan-to-value ratios back in all loan types. This is just one measure of how we keep our standards high.

Another reason for our success has been the markets that we're in. We're in a small handful of markets. Look at our 4 key markets we've talked about: New York and Boston on the East Coast, and then San Francisco and L.A. on the West Coast. We've been in those markets for a very long time. OLGA TSOKOVA, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT & CHIEF ACCOUNTING OFFICER, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: So David just talked about our pristine credit quality, which we have demonstrated throughout our history. When you think about how CECL impacts First Republic, 2 things are important: one, history and our low historical losses matter; and second, the life of the loan, which is the expected life of the loan adjusted for prepayments.

And just to remind you the way how CECL works, you start with a reasonable and supportable forecasting period, which now, in our case, is 2 years and when -- you revert back to historical losses for the remainder of the life of the loan, and the again, our historical losses were very low.

So how does CECL impact us? And actually, the CECL is not expected to have significant impact on our financial statements. And again, why? Because of our low historical losses and relatively low life -- relatively short life of the loan portfolio. Directionally, if we look at the single family and multifamily, commercial real estate and student loan refinance portfolios, we expect CECL's going to increase the reserves because those portfolios have longer life compared to our current methodology. And CECL will decrease quantitative reserves for some of our shorter-lived portfolios. And again, we're talking here about the quantitative reserves, which doesn't include the qualitative component of that.

So during 2019, we have completed 3 parallel runs. And based on the results of the last parallel run we had for September, we expect that CECL will change our reserves by approximately 5% to 10%, and the impact on the regulatory capital will be less than 10 basis points.

Importantly, the actual impact of CECL will impact -- will be impacted by economic conditions, forecasts, macroeconomic forecasts as well as portfolio composition at the time we adopt the CECL. And as I mentioned, we have completed 3 parallel runs this year, but we continue to refine our models and methodology. We continue to refine some of our qualitative framework and address some other implementation steps, which include finalizing and refining the controls over CECL process as well as data, but we are well positioned to complete those steps by January 1, 2020.

And just to recap, CECL is just an accounting change. It does not impact the way how we do business.

Investments, 12% high-quality liquid assets. I think we said that a lot, but also opportunistically add to the portfolio when time -- when there's a good time to do that, and we've built a very good municipal bond portfolio over the years.

Largely deposit-funded. You've heard almost 59% checking. Again, the last sort of 2 years, we've used a bit of a barbell instead of repricing money markets focused on CDs, coupled with a checking relationship because, again, it brings a household to the bank or it deepens the relationship with the bank. And that's been a good way for us to manage sort of the cost of funds over the past couple of years.

And lastly, we do use the Federal Home Loan Bank as a source of fixed-rate term funding. I will tell you today, rates today are better than they were a year ago. And so that also -- as things start to mature, rates for our new borrowings should be a bit better.

All right. Just a couple more. So a couple of pages ago, we talked about what happened with the sharp drop in interest rates during sort of the summertime. And so we look at our expense base from a few different lenses to see where can we optimize or manage a little bit differently, if, in fact, this is the new paradigm we're going to be under. And we sort of have 3 buckets that we think about. First is really, I'm going to say, they're off limits. If it's tied to exceptional service, risk management or long-term growth initiatives, we're not going to sacrifice that. So even in the last 90 days, 3 or 4 wealth teams we've hired because that has great long-term potential for the bank.

Now then there's sort of opportunities that exist. And the biggest one is around -- this is always about the pace of growth. It's never about announcing the cost reduction program, right? You hear lots of people talk about that. This is about the pace at which we grow. And obviously, personnel is 2/3 of our costs. So can you grow a little bit slower? Can you wait a little bit without sacrificing service, risk, et cetera? And so we look at that, and we manage it, and we talk about it. And so I think that's a place where we go very thoughtfully. And are there places we could do that to deal with a more challenging rate environment. And I have some listed here, sublease some real estate that we're going to -- again, we took, we'll grow into over time, but we can sort of spread the cost out over time.

So these last few slides are sort of some metrics and comparisons against the bank index. Now we can give him time to look for it, but nobody can spend on this card because we've locked it.

So we spend a lot of time talking to our clients on a daily basis. And we're trying to understand what their needs are so that we can figure out what matters most that we can enhance of our digital offerings. And we know our millennial clients really appreciate tools that help them track all their finances. But increasingly, we've seen that our net worth -- our higher net worth clients' value similar types of tools. Because if you have multiple accounts, multiple credit cards, checking accounts, savings accounts, investment accounts, we hear from clients that they're afraid that things can happen in their account. It could be fraud, it could be a mistake. Across all these different financial institutions, would you even catch it? So we're piloting a new capability, although I'll first point out our existing capability, which is, right now, you can add an external account from any financial institution into our app. So you can see your balances, your transactions, if you click in for your American Express credit card from a checking account or investment account somewhere else. But we're taking it a step further. So if you click here on More, and then the Budgets and Spending. The first tool in here is a consolidated transaction feed. So in one place, across all your financial accounts at different financial institutions, you can see your transactions. So that's not one checking count, that's checking accounts, credit cards, everything. You can also choose which accounts you actually want to see. So if some accounts you're focused on that you really want to look at, you only want to look at credit cards today or something else, you can filter and really focus on what matters most to you.

Additionally, you can choose the time frame. So I use this myself. I tend to only look back past the last couple of days. That's the easiest way to keep track of what's happening with my own transactions. But you can customize the time frame to weeks, months or however you want to do it. Across the top, it's showing you projected transactions that we expect to see hit your account. This is a real one that happened to me last weekend, where I said, "Why am I paying Audible twice?" And that was when I learned that my wife and I had subscribed to Audible on 2 different cards in the same short period of time, and that was why we were paying $30. Sometimes the examples can be bigger, but that was kind of a wake-up call that we don't really -- we need to talk more. Or I need to track my wife better.

The other thing beyond transactions then is what's happening with my money at a category level. Where am I spending my money? So in this case, I'd say, "How is it I'm spending $3,400 a month on auto and transport? That doesn't really make sense to me." So I click on that category and say, okay, auto insurance, auto payment, gas, ah, there it is, car rental. That's right. I rented a car for work, cost me $1,100, and that's really skewing the tracking because it's a work expense not a personal expense. So I click on it, and I see the category just says car rental. But let me dig into that further. So I click on the category. And now I have choices on how do I want to categorize this. So I look under travel, because this is really work travel, not personal travel, but there's no work travel category. So I create a work travel category, and now it's set. So the category is right there. And then it asks me, do you want to categorize all your Hertz charges backward and in the future as work travel or only categorize this one? So I say, well, this is pretty much what I use for work. So I say yes, always do this. And then when I go back in, now the auto transport category, now the spending is categorized in the way that I think about my money. So this is something that if you're a First Republic client, you'll be seeing in the near future.

Lastly, I want to talk about corporate. We continue to spend in the consumer digital space, but equally, we're investing in the corporate space. So we are right now rolling out to our corporate clients, a new user interface for our corporate online platform. And a key component of that is delightful design. It's a key part of our broader digital strategy as well. But delightful design doesn't just mean a nice user interface or generally easy to use. It means it's really tailored to the workflow of our clients. So we don't just survey clients or talk to them occasionally. We kind of move in with them. We'll go to their offices, and we'll spend up to 2 to 3 days sitting with some of their employees and really understanding the workflow of how they use our capabilities. And where it really comes together is when we figure out what matters most. And in this case, we found ways to make them complete -- to enable clients to complete transactions up to 5x faster. So when you can take a task from 30 minutes to 5 or 6 minutes because we understand exactly how you do your job, it's really impactful for the client, and it shows the client that we're listening, and that's really what matters.

JASON C. BENDER: Thank you, Scott. So I think we'll wrap the update on technology and operations there, but maybe just leave you with one thought here. In fact, I think one of our client panellists said it best. Technology is -- and technology investing is one of those things that it's never over. I mean, you just -- you have to keep doing it. You have to keep staying fresh. And for us, the important thing is to stay really close to the client, make sure that we understand what it is that they need or employees need and let that drive the prioritization. But one fundamental thing will remain true always and true to our First Republic business model, and that's that technology for us is really designed to enhance, not to replace those human relationships. Those are here for good.

So with that, thank you. We appreciate your time. We're going to take a very brief break, although I think we ask that you stay in the room, we're just going to reset the stage here for the Q&A panel. So thank you.

ERIKA NAJARIAN: Erika Najarian from BofA. This question is for Mike Selfridge. I'll give Mike Roffler a break. And I think most of the folks in this room are very confident in the credit quality metrics for First Republic, just from a cultural standpoint and the structure of a capital call line. But in your experience, what could we expect from the alternative asset managers that you service in a downturn? Is it just going to be an issue with volume? Or are you picking really the best managers that they would actually outperform in terms of performance? I guess we wanted to think about it from a cyclical perspective.

MICHAEL D. SELFRIDGE: Yes. No, it's a thoughtful question. A couple of things to note. Yes, there's a bit of a secular change in companies staying private longer. In the sort of the dot-com meltdown, the average time to IPO was between 3 and 5 years, today, it's more like 8 to 12 years. In some ways, that's healthy. I think we're all reading the headlines of some of the unicorns and valuation adjustments and what does that mean. The market is still robust. Our credit standards have not changed. And correct, in a downturn, I think you would expect to see strong credit quality. And the pace of investment would change, in my -- from my perspective, for both venture and private equity. Having said that, I think that our ability to grow by gaining market share could allow us to increase in a downturn.

STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: Steve Alexopoulos, JPMorgan. So first question on market share. It's been a couple of years since you guys published the market share in the individual markets, Boston, L.A., San Fran, New York. Can you give us a sense of how market share is trending in each of those, first?

JAMES H. HERBERT: We -- well, we do a Capgemini study every 2 years. And '19 is -- the study -- there'll be a '19 study basically done in the middle of '20. So the '17 study is still the most current one. Its life is about to end, and we'll have a new one.

Intuitively, the market share probably hasn't changed very much. I'm going to guess, if you look at that 4.2 on the chart, maybe 4.5. And the reason is the markets are so strong. I mean, the truth is we've had trouble keeping up. The question we get, quite frankly, all the time for a couple of decades is how do you keep growing this way? The answer is the markets we're in. At least part of the answer is the markets we're in are so incredibly strong. We actually have trouble keeping up in some of them. We actually went backwards in the San Francisco Bay Area, 1 year, 1 time. That was '13 or...?

JAMES H. HERBERT: A couple years ago.

JAMES H. HERBERT: A couple years ago, went backwards. It was all share, and we grew like crazy. So these markets are so powerful. And so I don't expect much change actually.

JASON C. BENDER: Just to add that. I mean, we are posting positive client acquisition in all those markets. But if the denominator is growing a bit faster than the numerator, it may slip back. But in general, it's very strong.

STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: I know in terms of new markets, I know you don't need any new markets because your market shares are still low. But when you think about Jackson Hole or Palm Beach, they work pretty well. JAMES H. HERBERT: We don't need them. We get drawn to them every once in a while by either an opportunity or just a client call. Jackson Hole is in that category. We've been able to -- actually Jackson Hole, interestingly enough, first 9 months it was the fastest-growing office we ever opened.

But the -- but Seattle has called for a long time because of the proximity and the flow between Seattle and San Francisco and L.A. But it's complicated. It's very well banked. And if we can gain market share where we are, why go into another big market? Jackson Hole is a small service point market for our other markets. It's going to be pretty good size actually. But per se, it's not that large. It's the flow from other places. Palm Beach is not quite that way. It has much more of an intrinsic market as well as the flow.

STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: And then finally for Jason. Just following up on the increased use of digital. As your clients use digital more, are you seeing them rely on the RMs less? What is the trend in human interaction?

JASON C. BENDER: Yes. So let me answer that one and then come back to Jim's comment for a second just to add some color there, too. With regards to digital, we're seeing that digital usage does not eat into the relationship with the RMs. What it does do is it changes what they take the time to talk about. And so the interactions tend to be slightly higher value as opposed to, can you just transfer money here it's let's talk about new business. Let's talk about a referral. And so we're finding that the interactions are just as strong as they've ever been. And in fact, in cases like what Scott showed, that digital usage sometimes even facilitates additional conversations, and that's really the goal.

If we go back to a second to Jim's comments, too, about market share. I'd say also, when we're looking at markets, whether that's the big ones or even the smaller more ancillary markets, we're not only looking for the relative attractiveness of the markets, but looking for interconnectivity with our other markets. And so one thing that we really maybe didn't talk as much about today is that the markets that we're in now are very tightly connected. People that work in L.A. are frequently ones who move to San Francisco or move to New York. People who are in Boston move frequently to New York. And so that kind of interconnectivity plays well to our referral-based and relationship-based kind of networking model. And so we really take that into account when we're looking at any new markets.

JAMES H. HERBERT: You know Steve, if I can add on that question, what you ask about is applicable and has been applicable in the company from the beginning. Continually, we try to find the standard that can be done automatically or simplistically to save the IQ for the more complicated thing. Generally, think credit. We now we have single-family home loan credit, about half of our business goes through a single signature channel, okay? And we -- to the best of my knowledge never had a loss in that channel for 18 years or so. And so that leaves the gray matter IQ -- time for the more complicated deals. The same thing is happening here, exactly. And that's usually what the client is more interested in your time on. They'd rather have their time, automatic, down here on the transactional and the time face-to-face, saved for the important things. And so it applies to technology, but it also applies to credit. It applies to how we spend our time. It applies to what happens when someone comes into an office. The more we know about them before they walk in with the artificial, the AI now or the Eagle intelligence, rather, sorry, the faster that you get to the point, and it's the point they want to talk about. And so everything we do is continually -- that's really what the empowerment activity is all about, to get them to the key segments, either on their mind or needs to be on their mind.

JOHN G. PANCARI: Okay. And then if I could just ask one more, Mike Selfridge. Just on the capital call line side of the business. And how do you think about the risks for the business further out if that migration continues?

MICHAEL D. SELFRIDGE: Yes. So to reiterate what Scott Aleali mentioned, he mentioned more in the competitive world there is this he called it J-curve management. People are borrowing -- firms are borrowing longer, up to 1 year, sometimes even 2 and 3 years to boost the IRR, and that's the reference of the IRR enhancement. We are seeing more competition, and competitors provide more of these IRR enhancement lines. It's not the core of what we do. Occasionally, for the very best managers, we will extend terms maybe up to a year at most, but it's not going to be a core practice of ours. And if we have to pass some business, we'll pass some business. There's enough out there for us to have. We appreciate the relationship for the core of what it is. It's a little bit of a debate in the industry right now, and we'll see how that shakes out.

From a credit perspective, it's still the backstop of the limited partners, the strong institutions, longer duration alone, more risk, theoretically, but the same credit backstop. So it's a little bit more on the edge, riskier on the credit side, but not too much.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: We have Aaron in front here, maybe.

AARON JAMES DEER, MD, EQUITY RESEARCH AND EQUITY RESEARCH ANALYST, SANDLER O'NEILL + PARTNERS, L.P., RESEARCH DIVISION: Aaron Deer, Sandler O'Neill. I have a question for you, Bob. In terms of the broader fee spectrum, we have not -- it's interesting. We've looked very closely at our fees over the last 5, 7 years, and we've seen no change in fees. And I think that's one of the major reasons is we -- while we very much care and take care of our clients and their investments, we really believe what our clients are paying us to do is to help manage their lives. And that's why I think we continue to see strong fees and no erosion of fees. I can't predict the future, but I think that's an essential part of what we offer to clients.

HAFIZE GAYE ERKAN: It does speak to the opportunity, though. MICHAEL D. SELFRIDGE: And maybe just a plug to Gaye's team. This goes back to data and being able to now mine, say, a mortgage loan client. We have their whole balance sheet. MICHAEL IOANILLI: Erika has another question over here.

ERIKA NAJARIAN: Now that the Fed is potentially in a more prolonged pause, what does that mean for deposit competition?

HAFIZE GAYE ERKAN: So the competition is still quite fair, quite fierce when it comes to deposits. And relationship banking is the one that's unlocking value for us. That's why we're very pleased that our checking deposits remain where they are, even though we have modeled around 55% in our NII simulation, as you know. So the competition continues. What we do is we do a more of a holistic funding optimization, then we'll look at the growth of deposits and the wholesale borrowing sources. And over the last year, especially, or 1.5 years, we have actually expanded the toolkit quite a bit in terms of funding sources in addition to deposits, just to be able to tap into the markets. So we give mid-teens guidance, and we're pleased that our deposits have grown around mid-teens so far. And as the short-term rates have been coming down, that actually makes them -- some of the other funding sources more attractive. So as part of the dynamic optimization we run on the liability side in line with the organic growth that comes from our lending and wealth management clients, so we are very pleased how it's turned out so far despite the competition.

And to your point, because the competition, even though where the Fed rates were and where other money market rates in the markets were, so we didn't necessarily want to play that money market game because we are a relationship bank we are not a transactional bank. So in that regard, as you will have observed this since end of 2015, Q4 of 2015, when the Fed started the hikes, we have seen more of a barbell approach of CDs and checking in terms of adding in terms of the deposit growth. And our preferred banking officers have been in this type of environment for many, many years across different rate cycles. And given their service half of the time, those CD deposit clients are cross service into checking relationship once they like the service. So that worked out perfectly.

KENNETH ALLEN ZERBE: I have a broader question. On Slide 114 in the deck, you mentioned that you have about 13% of your borrowers are low to moderate income, I guess, 29% in low to moderate MSAs. There's no arguing with your underwriting, right? You do amazing underwriting, no credit losses period, back. Can you help us just understand, like I wouldn't have thought this particular cohort would have the same, literally, 1 basis point of losses over time as the rest of the doctors and lawyers of the world with very low LTVs. Can you just talk about how you underwrite to this particular cohort? And how is it the losses have been so exceptionally low there?

JAMES H. HERBERT: It's actually the same way we underwrite everything else. The loan-to-value ratios may be slightly higher because it may be for probably a slightly higher percentage of first-time purchases. But philosophically, there's good credit everywhere. You just have to take the time to understand the situation and the circumstances. And as you properly point out, Ken, the losses, the loss history of the bank in single-family lending includes all those loans, whether we sold them or not, it includes all of them. And so we've had a very good experience. It takes a little more time sometimes, have to pay a little more attention, have a little more flexibility, but you can do good underwriting in every situation.

HAFIZE GAYE ERKAN: If I could add, the very first credit call that I had attended at First Republic, we spent about 45 minutes of an hour call to understand the character of the borrower. It's really the -- it's not about your wallet, it's about the character, the prudent risk management of the person. And it's more of a chicken and egg situation. If you have a good trusted adviser who is incentivized to make the safe credit decisions for you and the bank, so that goes hand-in-hand, and it's really the character that's driving the payment behavior.

DAVID JOSEPH LONG, SENIOR ANALYST, RAYMOND JAMES & ASSOCIATES, INC., RESEARCH DIVISION: It's Dave Long from Raymond James. Jason, I think it was one of your slides that showed the 2% attrition rate. JASON C. BENDER: Sure. I think it was on a couple of slides. But the 2% attrition rate, I mean, that -- sometimes people move out of market. They may move overseas. STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: First for Mike Roffler. So the 210 spread right now is 20 basis points. At about what level of steepness do you need for the NIM to stabilize?

MICHAEL J. ROFFLER: So the steepness, a little bit steeper would be better. And so how is Wells Fargo, JPMorgan, Citibank, BofA going to react? Or are they going to follow that or not?
