STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: So if the Fed does stay on hold here, how do you think about the NIM, just say, the rate environment holds where it is, are we under modest pressure?

MICHAEL J. ROFFLER: Yes. I think in the fourth quarter, we provided some numbers that thought we'd be approximately [2 75%]. And that's a good place to sort of start off as you go to January. STEVEN A. ALEXOPOULOS: Okay. And then separately, if we look at the student loan refinance business. At what age do you think that cohort will primarily start buying their first home? And if you look at the 2015, which was the first year of real vintage, if you will. Have many of those already converted to first home loan customers?

JAMES H. HERBERT: Some are beginning to. The 2,000 number you saw, that's obviously coming from that primarily. But the first-time home buying in the urban settings we're operating in, remember that by definition, the cohort has a student loan, okay? So that's going to happen in the late 30s, late 30s, early 40s. And so the average age of the cohort, call it, 32, 33 has got 4, 5 years to go.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: Erika up front here.

JAMES H. HERBERT: James, do you want to add to that?

JAMES HERBERT: Sure. I think we're seeing really strong progress, thus far, from the 2015 vintage, is what we talked about up there. And so that's something that's really been rolled out in the last 7 quarters. And so I think that's really helping accelerate it. And as we develop those deeper relationships, I think we'll see that penetration pick up.

JAMES H. HERBERT: Most important thing that they said about this cohort is, it's exactly the same client base we've always had, just younger. And actually, they're better educated. Generally speaking, our single-family home loan portfolio, if you consider them somewhat parallel, on the average, kind of has about 50% have graduate degrees, 45%, the student loan refinance, about 90% have graduate degrees.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: Erika?

ERIKA NAJARIAN: Jim, this question is for you. As we look out longer term, as we think about knowing the bank a long time, it's clear that the culture hasn't changed. But also, what I think you get not as much credit for is you have changed in response to what's different, right, whether it's technology or growing business banking or growing Eagle lending. So 5 years from now, if you're -- you've gathered us again in a room, what would be a little bit more -- what would be different about the bank in 5 years, in response to the changes that you do see?

JAMES H. HERBERT: Actually, we have changed a lot. But I think of it more as adjusting to circumstances on the one hand and then taking opportunities that become more than self-evident in some cases on the other.

I think that the technology that Gaye and everybody, all the teams, Jason, everybody's leading to take us to, is going -- I think you're in the second inning of that at the most. I was delighted to hear our clients talk about how they saw our technology. That was -- thank you, Steve. That was a good leading question. That was very helpful. But also, I was very pleased by the results. Now 2 years ago, you wouldn't have had that same answer. So we're just around the corner on that, I think.

Internally, we have a ways to go, yes, but it's happening very rapidly. So I think the power -- I would predict that the current relationship managers, business bankers, wealth managers, 5 years from now, will be approximately 50% more productive as a result of what's going on.

And then I think the other thing is that the student loan refinance and the professional loan program, think of the seeds that are being sown right now. They will be 50% to 70% of the consumer base of the bank. And 5 years now, from now, to Steve's question, I would guess, 40% to 50% of them have bought their home. And then they're really in the bank. So those are the things that are obvious.

What isn't obvious, I think, is there an existential challenge to banking. I think at the individual consumer service level and at the individual private company level in 5 years, I don't see it. In 10 years, possibly. And it comes in my mind primarily from the payment system side first, Stripe, Square, et cetera. And then secondarily, it comes from the question of, is there an alternative currency and now I'm out about 10 years probably, but maybe not.

One of the nice things about the enterprise, though, is that we operate -- we have a barbell. We're going to -- if you look forward 5 years and you say 50% or 60% of the clients are millennial then, of course, 5 years older, but still that generation moving through, it's still somewhat axiomatic, and it will always be the case that the older generation has most of the money. And the reason is that if you take the group as a whole, they have more time to compound. It's not inventing anything. And so about 60% to 65% of the money in the bank is 55 plus. I don't think that changes, except in our case, because we started at a certain point, it gets a little older, okay? And probably, thereby, is more stable rather than less in terms of if we've done a good job. So I think the other thing that, that last point leads me to is I believe that the 3 -- 5 years ago, wealth management was equal to about 70% of the assets of the bank. It was not 1 to 1. Now it's about 1.25, 1.4 to 1. I would guess that wealth management because it comes and stays and grows, okay, and the cross-sell increases will be 2.5 to 3 to 1, 2.5 to 1 -- 2 to 2.5 to 1 in 5 years. 10 years? Maybe 3 to 1.

Northern Trust, the old JPMorgan Private Bank, states for any of these trust banks, they're 100 years old. We're only 34 years old. What they did in their early generation was to help families gain wealth and do well, save and begin to move their assets residually as the generations passed to the bank. We're in the very first round of that. And so what I see coming is much more of a trust bank. Almost inevitably. But with the feed at the young end because what happens is those banks get smaller relative to the trust, the trust takes over the situation, and the bank is just a little facilitator. I don't want that to happen. I want the bank to grow continually. And the #1 thing we've done is this PLP, the Eagle banking, PLP and SLR, to keep feeding it. And the single-family home, they keep feeding that way, too. If we turn away -- we won't turn away from those. And those are really powerful. So you can put those 2 together, you have a balance tipping towards trust, but a very powerful bank still.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: I think we have one over here on this side. Urmas, maybe, do you want to go first, and then we can go to this gentleman over here.

URMAS WOMPA: Oh, okay. Could you please give us an update on Gradifi? I'm missing those beautiful commercials. I haven't seen one for a while.

HAFIZE GAYE ERKAN: So we have over 800 employers now on the platform, quite a few landmark marquee names now, in addition to where we started. We started to disrupt some of the smaller enterprises. Now it's much larger organizations that are on the platform. So the team has done a really, really great job in terms of bringing those on to the platform. And we also had a product switch in terms of get trial, it is much easier to get trial from an employer when you talk about hey do we have a solution. It doesn't cost you anything, and it makes the financial health of your employees much better. Do you care about them? And that is the theme on refinancing. If it's in our footprint, within our credit guidelines, it would automatically come to us, but if it's not, they are partnering lenders that is the Gradifi Refi platform. So it's a small marketplace or -- for 4 different lenders that includes First Republic and other lenders as well. They are at a threshold of the service quality. We want to make sure that everybody is providing the great quality of service. So that has been a switch in the last less than 1 year that we have done building that platform, which didn't exist, then we built Gradifi at the end of 2016. So that is the reason for only seeing a lot more and bigger sized employers coming on to the platform to get trial. And then cross servicing into other products like student loan paydown or a benefit that helps the 529. All you need to do really as an employer, and all of us here are employed somewhere. All you need today as an employer to do well by doing good is some of the monthly benefits we all provide. Give your employees the option. Do you want to spend it for gym membership or you want to spend it to pay down your student debt through the principal pay downs and you also get to refinance? Or if you have kids, and you don't have student loan refinancing, you may use the monthly benefit to do 529 saveups or tuition reimbursement, if you want to learn Python and grow as a person. So it's really adding to the menu of the HR benefits platform. One of our clients that Gradifi student loan pay down and refi is Mollie.

MOLLIE M. RICHARDSON: Yes, absolutely. Pretty demanding too on the team with my levels of service expectations, but it was 1 of the reasons why we decided to go with Gradifi in the first place. And about 25% of our workforce is either taking advantage of the student loan paydown benefit that we offer or the 529 college saveup plan as well.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: I think we have a question over here, if you're still...?

JOHANNES MOLLER: Yes, Johan Moller, Fitch Ratings. A question for Jim. I'm just curious, so you obviously don't offer a credit card currently. I'm just curious as to sort of, from a strategic standpoint, why you've chosen to stay out of that product?

JAMES H. HERBERT: We're really not -- credit cards are a massive scale product. And we have clients who use their credit cards quite actively, but we don't have very many clients. We've tried credit cards twice actually. We did it with 2 different purveyors. And quite frankly, we also had the issue of their service became us and we weren't completely happy with that.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: Maybe do we have time for one last question or maybe 1 or 2 more if anybody has one. Okay, Brock. I see Brock over on this side.

BROCK CLINTON VANDERVLIET: Brock Vandervliet, UBS. So I think from an investment perspective, one of the best and strongest parts of the story is that the guides you've so frequently given on loan growth end up being conservative, sometimes materially so, due to the continued success in mortgage or the build-out of business banking or a combination. With higher rates now beginning to strike housing, do you worry that, that becomes more difficult? Or that -- are there offsets that you'd point to?

I tried to word this in a way that you wouldn't just remind me about no guidance and still answer.

JAMES H. HERBERT: Well, no guidance. They -- you have to take it apart a little bit. The business banking loan growth is quite separate from the single-family home loan business. Single-family home loan business does have a rather meaningful rate level driver component to it. The business banking doesn't. It's just who we are able to establish new relationships with primarily. The -- and even the usage in business banking doesn't -- isn't rate driven. The home loan business has only got about a, from our perspective, only has about a 90-day forward view that we can be pretty accurate on and because of the rate component. And it's still -- as we said on our call, this last call, it's still quite strong. I think our backlog going into the fourth quarter as we covered on the call was strong.

HAFIZE GAYE ERKAN: And maybe if I could just combine Erika's question with your question about growth, and then there was a digital -- Steve's question on digital. So the growth pillars are still the same as it was 5 years ago. So markets that are vibrant, a Net Promoter Score that is differentiated, which leads to growth from within. And that is why we don't set artificial loan targets. We don't have artificial loan targets. We just wake up, take care of the clients of their needs and great quality of clients and whatever great safe business there is, we do that. So mid-teens, that's why we're comfortable guidance that we're still providing. And if we see good business to do, we end up doing that. But what's happening in addition to those. So Erika mentioned and Jim mentioned about in the question about business banking growing faster than the bank, about Eagle lending growing faster than the bank, and the wealth management growing faster than the bank. Those growth pillars are now on solid foundation. The seeds are planted, and they're growing. On top of it with digital, there is yet another when you look forward ahead, there's a digital scalable platform that is forming at First Republic. You take robo-advisor. You take Gradifi. You take the deposit client onboarding, that's the team I talked about. You can -- if you're an existing client, you can open your accounts online digitally through your phone app. Financial planning soon to come, financial planning [light] soon to come. So that's the digital and lending cost that Jason mentioned, digital scalable platform. But we're in a customization business. So how do you bring those 2 together?

If you choose to customize, and we are just doing this with one employer right now, we are -- they are in our footprint, one of their financial wellness partners. And if you choose to customize further, you have a person, you have a quarterback of that relationship that you can pull and further do investment management or other complicated credit decisions can be made to your trusted adviser. So that's really exciting to bring everything together but staying true to the First Republic customization model.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: Maybe one final question over here with Garrett.

GARRETT ANTHONY HOLLAND: Garrett Holland with Baird. Just a couple of follow-up questions. On the Net Promoter Score, how does that score trend as digital engagement increases? And then separately, over your next 35 years and $100 billion of assets, how do you sustain the entrepreneurial spirit that's instilled for so many of the larger banks?

JASON C. BENDER: I'll take the NPS piece first. So NPS, we've done since 2013, and through that period, we've seen a great increase in digital usage. We've also seen a doubling in size for ourselves. And so, for us, the thing that's most important, I think, is the relative stability of that Net Promoter Score and the underlying service model, even through growth, even through changes in digital and other influences, frankly.

And so, for us, when we think about our client service model, what we're really trying to do is make sure that that's very stable, that's very sustainable regardless of the trends that are coming at us.

MOLLIE M. RICHARDSON: I'll maybe tackle the culture question, and it's culture, culture, culture, culture. And frankly, it starts with all of us here, how we act, how we interact, how we lead, doing so by example. It starts with a vigilance on we are who we hire and being focused and committed to that. It's about -- it's not just about communicating with our workforce. It's about interacting with our people and making the time commitment to do that so that they can continue to deliver that extraordinary service to our clients.

JAMES H. HERBERT: Let me add to that for a second in terms of they used the word entrepreneurial. The -- it is an entrepreneurial organization. I would note that all organizations started sometime. So they were all entrepreneurial one day. But the maintenance of it is actually built into the model. And it's not something that we talk about very much, but you heard it here today several times. Several of the people that were up here talked about they're entrepreneurial. They're dealing with their clients, Ruth Aronowitz, Todd (inaudible). And we have a whole row of entrepreneurs sitting in the back here. And our model empowers them. Jeff mentioned it a couple of times. Garrett mentioned it. Garrett is sitting back here. This kind of -- the model is built around the people. And the entire job that we have is to say, here's where we're going. Here are the tools to get there. Here are the rules inside our organization, rules, culture, okay? Go get them. We'll support you. And we don't move them around. I've said that a couple of times, I'll keep saying it. We don't move them around, unless they want to be moved, which just happens sometimes. And we're glad to accommodate. But empowering each one of them to be an entrepreneur in their own business.

And then I got the question a couple of times today, which we always get, which is how large can it be? I've been getting that actually for 30 years. But the answer is if you think about the business and the way I just described it. And then you put another entrepreneur and another entrepreneur and another entrepreneur, that isn't bigger. It's the same empowered. And so our job is to create an environment where we can allow for somewhat different styles but operating very much in our culture and doing the clients who, in many cases, select them. A lot of clients would select Gaye, most would probably, versus me. But the point is that they choose their relationship manager, and the manager finds them. They run into each other. They try it on, it fits. So don't get in the way of that. Leave it there.

And then, by the way, we haven't mentioned this, but if Ruth has a wealth management client and she thinks that's the best person to serve that client, she's in New York, the best person to serve that client in San Francisco, fly them in. You're adults, figure it out. Because if you get the connection right, it's about 85% successful right out of the bat. And she knows her client. She judges them and pulls the right person in.

That entrepreneurial spirit is embedded in the structure and the culture. It's not -- we're entrepreneurial. I'm entrepreneurial, Gaye is, but it's in the structure. It's in the culture. We have hundreds of entrepreneurs in this company.

MICHAEL IOANILLI: So we do have a reception, which Shannon is going to come and tell you about. But before I turn it over to Shannon, Jim, do you have any final remarks for the day?

JAMES H. HERBERT: I think I just made them. Thanks all very much for your support and for being here and for sitting through the day. We hope it was useful. We may have had a few less numbers in this presentation than you're used to in banking. But what we're trying to get at is why we're different.

And actually, I can just go to the -- we're going to be out back, right, Shannon?

SHANNON HOUSTON, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, CHIEF MARKETING & COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER, FIRST REPUBLIC BANK: We are, yes.

JAMES H. HERBERT: So we're going to -- are we going right to that?

SHANNON HOUSTON: We are. I have some brief instructions for folks. Is that it...

JAMES H. HERBERT: Go ahead.

SHANNON HOUSTON: All right. Thank you, Jim. Hi. My name is Shannon Houston. I'm the bank's Chief Marketing and Communications Officer. We are about to conclude our day by ending with our banker reception.

Before we do so, though, I'd like to extend a quick thank you. Many folks throughout the organization helped to support bringing this event together. But in particular, it's the leadership of our fantastic Investor Relations team: Allie Hoffman, Jake Crooks and our leader, Mike Ioanilli, who pulled off just a wonderful event. So thank you very much.

The US has seen more than 4.3 million infections, with an early surge in New York and the north-east followed...

Good morning. Six months since the very first cases of Covid-19 were diagnosed in China, more than 150,000 Americans are now dead – by far the biggest toll of any nation afflicted by the raging global pandemic. The US has seen more than 4.3 million infections, with an early surge in New York and the north-east followed...

Good morning. Six months since the very first cases of Covid-19 were diagnosed in China, more than 150,000 Americans are now
dead – by far the biggest toll of any nation afflicted by the raging global pandemic. The US has seen more than 4.3 million infections, with an early surge in New York and the north-east followed by outbreaks across the sun belt, which now threaten to prog...

Good morning. Six months since the very first cases of Covid-19 were diagnosed in China, more than 150,000 Americans are now dead – by far the biggest toll of any nation afflicted by the raging global pandemic. The US has seen more than 4.3 million infections, with an early surge in New York and the north-east followed by outbreaks across the sun belt, which now threaten to progress to central states, thanks in part to the fumbling response of the federal government. Alexandra Villarreal identifies the key milestones on America’s grim coronavirus timeline , while we break down the shocking victim statistics to show how the disease has disproportionately hit older people, people of colour and those with lower incomes. After six months of denials about the seriousness of the crisis, pundits claimed Donald Trump had adopted a more somber tone last week, writes David Smith. Not for long, he didn’t . It was soon enough the same old Trump, culminating in his retweet on Monday of a video in which a group of lab coat-wearing doctors pushed false and misleading claims about Covid-19. Federal paramilitaries are being pulled out of Portland In a major climbdown for the Trump administration, federal troops are to be pulled out of Portland after weeks of escalating clashes with protesters. Oregon governor Kate Brown announced she had agreed the pull-out in talks with Mike Pence, the US vice-president, saying the federal agents had “acted as an occupying force, refused accountability, and brought violence and strife to our community.” Congress told big tech CEOs they have ‘too much power’ House lawmakers have threatened an unprecedented antitrust crackdown on America’s biggest technology companies, after Mark Zuckerberg, Jeff Bezos, Apple’s Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai, the boss of Google’s parent Alphabet, were told they have “too much power” at a combative congressional hearing on Wednesday . Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google censor political speech, spread fake news and abuse their power to crush potential competitors, claimed the members of the House judiciary’s antitrust subcommittee, which has investigated the firms for over a year. Democrat David Cicilline, the subcommittee chairman, described their CEOs as “the emperors of the online economy”: These companies, as they exist today, have monopoly power. Some need to be broken up, all need to be properly regulated and held accountable. The ‘Suburban Lifestyle Dream’ is Trump’s new dog-whistle Trump has resorted to a familiar tactic to try to shore up his cratering support among suburban voters: barely veiled race-baiting . The president tweeted on Wednesday that Americans “living their Suburban Lifestyle Dream” will no longer be “bothered” by low-income housing in their communities, after he rescinded an Obama-era program designed to reduce racial segregation in US suburbs. Speaking in Texas, Trump said the Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing rule had been “hell for suburbia”. In other news … Climate countdown: 97 days to save the planet The hottest April day in Miami’s history occurred this year, when the mercury in the city’s thermometers hit 97F. There are now 97 days until the US is due to exit the Paris climate agreement; today in our climate countdown series, Fiona Harvey reports on how Trump’s stance has emboldened the world’s other populist, Paris-sceptic leaders . Great reads California’s coming ‘tsunami of evictions’ California lawmakers may continue $600 weekly unemployment benefits for the state’s residents if Congress fails to extend them. But meanwhile, California’s key renter protections are about to expire, which could lead to a catastrophic homeless crisis in the midst of the pandemic. Sam Levin reports from Los Angeles. Twitter announced last week that it would stop promoting content linked to the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory, which has made the leap from the internet swamp to the real-world, with dangerous consequences. But will suppressing it work, or just fuel its adherents’ paranoia ? Poppy Noor asks the experts. Opinion: Lebanon’s economic crisis is a social catastrophe Decades of mismanagement and corruption have plunged Lebanon into the worst economic crisis in its history . Naji Bakhti’s father recently lost his job of more than four decades – and yet, Bakhti writes, he saves his pity for the younger generation. Nearly half the population now find themselves officially below the poverty line, their salaries, savings and retirement funds reduced to a pittance, with the lira having lost more than 70% of its value against the dollar. Lebanon has the distinct honour of being the first country in the Middle East and North Africa region to experience hyperinflation. Last Thing: the joys of travel – with MS flight simulator Microsoft has updated its decades-old Flight Simulator series, with a “near-photorealistic depiction of the entire planet” at a time when most of us can’t travel far beyond our front doors. The recreation of flight mechanics is as faithful as ever, says Keith Stuart, but now its creators have captured the emotional element of flight , too. urn:contentItem:60G9-2N21-F021-60B2-00000-00First Thing: six months into the Covid-19 pandemic, 150,000 Americans are dead;The US death toll is by far the highest in the world, with hospitals in several states still under increasing strain. Plus, an economic catastrophe in LebanonDon't already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:12ZLexisNexisUS NEWSVersion:2First Thing: six months into the Covid-19 pandemic, 150,000 Americans are deadThe US death toll is by far the highest in the world, with hospitals in several states still under increasing strain. Plus, an economic catastrophe in LebanonDon't already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up hereTim Walker

The US death toll is by far the highest in the world, with hospitals in several states still under increasing strain. Plus, an economic catastrophe in LebanonDon't already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning. Six months since the first cases of Covid-19 were diagnosed in the US, more than 150,000 Americans are now dead - by far the biggest toll of any nation afflicted by the raging global pandemic. The US has seen more than 4.3 million infections, with an early surge in New York and the north-east followed by outbreaks across the sun belt, which now threaten to progress to central states, thanks in part to the fumbling response of the federal government.

Alexandra Villarreal identifies the key milestones on America's grim coronavirus timeline, while we break down the shocking victim statistics to show how the disease has disproportionately hit older people, people of colour and those with lower incomes.

After six months of denials about the seriousness of the crisis, pundits claimed Donald Trump had adopted a more somber tone last week, writes David Smith. Not for long, he didn't.

It was soon enough the same old Trump, culminating in his retweet on Monday of a video in which a group of lab coat-wearing doctors pushed false and misleading claims about Covid-19.

Federal paramilitaries are being pulled out of Portland

In a major climbdown for the Trump administration, federal troops are to be pulled out of Portland after weeks of escalating clashes with protesters. Oregon governor Kate Brown announced she had agreed the pull-out in talks with Mike Pence, the US vice-president, saying the federal agents had "acted as an occupying force, refused accountability, and brought violence and strife to our community."

State and city police officers will replace the federal paramilitaries guarding the city's courthouse, the focus of the Black Lives Matter protests that had been re-energised and exacerbated by the presence of the Department of Homeland Security agents.

Congress told big tech CEOs they have 'too much power'

House lawmakers have threatened an unprecedented antitrust crackdown on America's biggest technology companies, after Mark Zuckerberg, Jeff Bezos, Apple's Tim Cook and Sundar Pichai, the boss of Google's parent Alphabet, were told they have "too much power" at a combative congressional hearing on Wednesday.

Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google censor political speech, spread fake news and abuse their power to crush potential competitors, claimed the members of the House judiciary's antitrust subcommittee, which has investigated the firms for over a year. Democrat David Cicilline, the subcommittee chairman, described their CEOs as "the emperors of the online economy":

These companies, as they exist today, have monopoly power. Some need to be broken up, all need to be properly regulated and held accountable.

The 'Suburban Lifestyle Dream' is Trump's new dog-whistle

Trump has resorted to a familiar tactic to try to shore up his cratering support among suburban voters: barely veiled race-baiting. The president tweeted on Wednesday that Americans "living their Suburban Lifestyle Dream" will no longer be "bothered" by low-income housing in their communities, after he rescinded an Obama-era program designed to reduce racial segregation in US suburbs. Speaking in Texas, Trump said the Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing rule had been "hell for suburbia".

Four black women are on Joe Biden's list of potential running mates, but despite a wealth of well-qualified candidates, no single vice-presidential pick will satisfy everyone in the Democratic party. Daniel Strauss reports.

In other news ...

Nasa's latest mission to Mars will launch from Cape Canaveral early on Thursday morning, with the express purpose of determining whether there was ever life on the red planet - including "life not as we know it", under a broader definition of life that Nasa astrobiologists have dubbed "lyfe".

Ruth Bader Ginsburg is 'resting comfortably' in hospital following a non-surgical procedure to revise a bile duct stent. It is the 87-year-old liberal supreme court justice's second hospital stay in less than a month.

Maine's first ever fatal shark attack, in which a 63-year-old woman was killed while swimming earlier this week, may be linked to the successful efforts to restore seal and shark populations along the New England coast, experts have said.

 Climate countdown: 97 days to save the planet

The hottest April day in Miami's history occurred this year, when the mercury in the city's thermometers hit 97F. There are now 97 days until the US is due to exit the Paris climate agreement; today in our climate countdown series, Fiona Harvey reports on how Trump's stance has emboldened the world's other populist, Paris-sceptic leaders.

Great reads

California's coming 'tsunami of evictions'

California lawmakers may continue $600 weekly unemployment benefits for the state's residents if Congress fails to extend them. But meanwhile, California's key renter protections are about to expire, which could lead to a catastrophic homeless crisis in the midst of the pandemic. Sam Levin reports from Los Angeles.

Will blocking QAnon work, or just fuel the conspiracy theory?

Twitter announced last week that it would stop promoting content linked to the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory, which has made the leap from the internet swamp to the real-world, with dangerous consequences. But will suppressing it work, or just fuel its adherents' paranoia ? Poppy Noor asks the experts.

Opinion: Lebanon's economic crisis is a social catastrophe

Decades of mismanagement and corruption have plunged Lebanon into the worst economic crisis in its history. Naji Bakhti's father recently lost his job of more than four decades - and yet, Bakhti writes, he saves his pity for the younger generation.

Nearly half the population now find themselves officially below the poverty line, their salaries, savings and retirement funds reduced to a pittance, with the lira having lost more than 70% of its value against the dollar. Lebanon has the distinct honour of being the first country in the Middle East and North Africa region to experience hyperinflation.

Last Thing: the joys of travel - with MS flight simulator

Microsoft has updated its decades-old Flight Simulator series, with a "near-photorealistic depiction of the entire planet" at a time when most of us can't travel far beyond our front doors. The recreation of flight mechanics is as faithful as ever, says Keith Stuart, but now its creators have captured the emotional element of flight, too.

urn:contentItem:600V-WW51-F021-606B-00000-00First Thing: the US has passed a grim milestone - 100,000 Covid-19 deaths;But as country mourns, president ignored death toll to focus on attacking tech companies. Plus, Gary Busey's new pet-based reality showDon't already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:13ZLexisNexisUS NEWSVersion:3First Thing: the US has passed a grim milestone - 100,000 Covid-19 deathsBut as country mourns, president ignored death toll to focus on attacking tech companies. Plus, Gary Busey's new pet-based reality showDon't already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up hereTim Walker

Good morning.

More than 100,000 US citizens have died from the coronavirus, a toll almost   three times   that of any other country and more than the US lost in the Korean and Vietnam wars combined. The pandemic has   laid bare   the US's brutal social faultlines - race, gender and poverty - writes Ed Pilkington, while the government's abject failure to prepare for it exposed a broken politics.   Here, loved ones pay tribute to a few of those who have lost their lives.

Donald Trump did not acknowledge the grim milestone on Wednesday, instead choosing to renew his attacks on the tech companies he claims are trying to censor him. Joe Biden released a video   extending his condolences to all those who were grieving loved ones. Trump's son Eric   tweeted about the stock market, calling it a "GREAT DAY for the DOW!!"

20% of US citizens would choose not to get a Covid-19 vaccine if or when one is available, according to a poll. Even if such a vaccine were developed in the next 18 months, only 49% of respondents said they would agree to be immunised.  About one-third said they weren't sure.

 Trump is threatening to 'close down' social media companies

Days after Twitter slapped Trump's tweets with a fact-check label for the first time, the president is set to sign an executive order that could expose Twitter and other large tech firms such as Facebook and Google to lawsuits over material posted by their users, according to Reuters.

On Wednesday morning Trump threatened to "strongly regulate" or "close down" social media platforms that he and his allies perceive as "silencing conservative voices". In the evening, he tweeted again:

Big Tech is doing everything in their very considerable power to CENSOR in advance of the 2020 Election. If that happens, we no longer have our freedom. I will never let it happen!

South Korea is locking down again after a new spike in cases

South Korea, one of the first countries to successfully contain the coronavirus, has reintroduced some lockdown measures in the capital, Seoul, after its biggest rise in infections for almost two months. The two-week closure of museums, galleries and parks in the city - which is home to half of the country's 52 million people - comes after   the Korean CDC reported 79 new infections on Thursday, 67 of them in the Seoul metropolitan area.

France, Italy and Belgium have all taken steps to block the use of hydroxychloroquine, the anti-malarial drug that Trump has backed and says he is taking, as a Covid-19 treatment over concerns about the drug's safety.

Argentina 's security forces have cordoned off one of the country's poorest slums after a surge of coronavirus cases, a move criticised by one of the leftwing government's own ministers as " creating ghettoes for poor people ".

 George Floyd's sister says police should face murder charges

As protests over the police killing of George Floyd continued in Minneapolis on Wednesday, his sister, Bridget called for the officers involved in the incident to be charged with murder. Sports stars including LeBron James, Colin Kaepernick and Lewis Hamilton   have expressed anger over the killing of another unarmed African American man by a white police officer.

Everyday racism. A video of a man in Minneapolis questioning whether a group of black men were entitled to work out at his gym has gone viral. The men were entrepreneurs whose office is in the same block as the gym.

Police abolition. The futile cycle of police killings, protest and promises of justice unfulfilled suggest police reform is not enough to address the problem, argues Derecka Purnell:

If we can understand that the calls to abolish Ice [the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency] actually mean that this country needs a new, transformational immigration system, then why dismiss police abolition as a viable option for a transformative society?

In other news ...

The US no longer considers Hong Kong autonomous and will cease to treat it as such for trade and economic purposes, Mike Pompeo has announced, as the Chinese parliament approved a new law stripping the territory of its freedoms.

Brazil lost 4,633 sq miles of forest last year, according to a study that raises fresh alarm over the rate of deforestation under Jair Bolsonaro's government. Another study noted a 27% increase in the destruction of tropical forests in eastern Brazil.

The SpaceX-Nasa rocket launch was scrubbed owing to poor weather in Florida on Wednesday. The first crewed spaceflight from US soil since 2011 could now take off on Saturday.

The US funded pro-democracy rock groups in Venezuela and encouraged them to write songs that would undermine the rule of the country's late president Hugo Chávez, according to documents released after a Freedom of Information Act request.

 Great reads

Gary Busey has a new reality show about pets

The star of Big Wednesday, who survived a serious Harley Davidson accident - and the Hollywood party scene - tells Simon Hattenstone about his new show, Pet Judge, in which he presides over a court in which litigants resolve quarrels about their pets. "None of the other judge shows hold a candle fire, bonfire or rocket to this."

The free press is under threat worldwide

Journalists and publishers around the world increasingly face attacks on their work and on themselves, ranging from strategic lawsuits to targeted assassinations. Now the pandemic is being used as cover to crack down further on independent voices, as Gill Phillips reports.

Opinion: Lockdown turned my neighbourhood into Sesame Street

The lockdown has had an unexpected - and positive - effect on Krista Burton's Minnesota neighbourhood, she says: she's finally getting to know her neighbours.

I've shared apartment walls for years with people I've never met. Suddenly speaking to my neighbours feels a little thrilling, like we're all crossing a once-forbidden boundary together.

Last Thing: RIP Larry Kramer, angry prophet of the Aids crisis

Larry Kramer, the gay rights titan and groundbreaking writer of the novel Faggots and the play The Normal Heart, has died aged 84, almost two decades after doctors gave him a year to live. Matthew Lopez   pays tribute to the "angry prophet" of the Aids crisis.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XD4-0C01-JBHT-D513-00000-00First Uber, then Airbnb: How socialism tries to crush the gig economy2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:13ZLexisNexisOPINIONFirst Uber, then Airbnb: How socialism tries to crush the gig economyTom RoganWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

Until we start highlighting the personal costs of left-wing policies, those policies will continue to find traction with voters. That's why the Right should stand up and make the case that liberals want to stop you from taking cheap vacations.

That's how conservatives should describe left-wing efforts to destroy the segment of the gig economy represented by Airbnb, Vrbo, and their various competitors that allow homeowners to let rooms, apartments, or houses to vacationing guests. The populist drive to kill off or hinder these services is not at all unrelated to the result of a new YouGov poll suggesting that just shy of 50% of millennials have favorable opinions of socialism.

A great way for conservatives to rebut that sympathy is to focus on the gig economy. Millennials love ride-sharing services such as Uber and Lyft, and residence-sharing services such as Airbnb. These opportunities allow us to travel with greater ease, affordability, and choice. Empowering individuals to provide their human and physical capital on the free market, they show capitalism at its best.

Most left-wing politicians are too clever to openly admit a desire to destroy the gig economy or co-opt it on behalf of the union special interests that control their political fate. Instead, liberal officeholders like Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City, and Sen. Elizabeth Warren aim to kill the gig economy with a thousand cuts. Incidentally, it's the same strategy Warren applies in destroying our innovative technology sector.

Fortunately, there are those on the Left who aren't as clever as the politicians themselves. Conservatives would do well to shine a light on their strategy.

Take the press release issued on Wednesday by "Airbnb Watch," a self-styled "coalition of concerned neighbors." Airbnb Watch actually appears to be funded by hotel and union lobbyists. Although veiled by quotes from seemingly genuine city leaders, the press release makes clear what it wants: Put pressure on Congress to pass the Plan Act, which would better enable hoteliers and government to sue Airbnb and its accommodation providers.

The mechanism here is especially important because it strikes at a free-speech issue central to debates over online censorship by Big Tech companies. The secret plan to cripple AirbnB revolves around creating new exceptions to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. That provision, as the Electronic Frontier Foundation notes,

says that "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider" (47 U.S.C. § 230). In other words, online intermediaries that host or republish speech are protected against a range of laws that might otherwise be used to hold them legally responsible for what others say and do.

This is usually discussed in the context of social media, where the traffic is all in ideas and memes. But you can just imagine how changes to this section could affect a service whose sole purpose is to connect users who request or supply rides or places to stay.

Airbnb Watch claims that the bill is about protecting communities. Fortunately, however, the sponsor of this measure in Congress doesn't appear to have gotten the memo. Rep. Ed Case's announcement of the bill offers supporting quotes from numerous hotel associations. The whole point is to protect an industry — and sadly, there are some conservative lobbyists running around town right now carrying their water as well — and its dying union.

This campaign has reached across the whole world. Right now, in Jersey City, the hotel lobby is trying to trick voters into banning themselves from using their properties as they see fit. This ties nicely to Newsom's new law, regulating Uber and Lyft out of California. These bills attacking the gig economy are all about protecting hotel and taxi special interests over the right of individuals to use their property and money in their own best interests. It is an example of socialism's immoral pursuit of command economy regulation at the expense of the rights of others.

Yes, there are those on the Republican side who also favor a planned economy. Senator Josh Hawley and Congressman Matt Gaetz have a great deal in common with Warren and company here. But at the core, the anti-gig economy movement is one being driven from the political Left. Free-market conservatives should stand up and make our own arguments clear so that millennials understand socialism is not just some pie-in-the-sky utopian idea — socialism will put people out of work and inconvenience them almost immediately.

Photo Caption:FILE - In this Aug. 28, 2019 file photoAssemblywoman Lorena Gonzalez, D-San Diego, speaks at rally calling for passage of her measure to limit when companies can label workers as independent contractors at the Capitol in Sacramento, Calif.California took a stand against companies in the so-called gig economy like Uber and Lyft by passing legislation aimed at making them treat their workers like employees. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

urn:contentItem:5YDK-8S91-F15W-H02H-00000-00FiscalNote-CQ Roll Call Holds Discussion on Healthcare2020-03-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:13ZLexisNexisFiscalNote-CQ Roll Call Holds Discussion on Healthcare

Fiscalnote-Cq Roll Call Holds Discussion On Healthcare

March 10, 2020 08:30 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

REP. DONNA E. SHALALA (D-FLA.)

BETTER MEDICARE ALLIANCE CEO FORMER REP. ALLYSON SCHWARTZ (D-PA.)

CATO INSTITUTE HEALTH POLICY STUDIES DIRECTOR MICHAEL F. CANNON

BIPARTISAN POLICY CENTER SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT G. WILLIAM HOAGLAND

PUBLIC AFFAIRS CONSULTANT JIM MANLEY

CQ ROLL CALL HEALTH CARE REPORTER MARY ELLEN MCINTIRE

CQ ROLL CALL SENIOR STAFF WRITER GOPAL RATNAM

CQ ROLL CALL HEALTH EDITOR REBECCA ADAMS

CQ ROLL CALL PUBLISHER JOSH RESNIK

PROJECT HOPE SENIOR FELLOW GAIL WILENSKY

HEALTH INNOVATION ALLIANCE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR JOEL WHITE

AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBER DR. BOBBY MUKKAMALA

REP. DR. LARRY BUCSHON (R-IN.)

[*]RESNIK: Good morning. Can everyone hear me okay? All right, great. Welcome to CQ Roll call's fourth annual health care decoded event. My name is Josh Resnik and I am CQ Roll Call publisher as well--as well as chief content officer for our parent company, FiscalNote. I'd like to thank you all for joining us this morning, as well as those watching live on rollcall.com. Before we begin, I'd like to take a moment to thank or presenting Sponsor Better Medicare Alliance, as well as our supporting sponsors DentaQuest and the Alzheimer's Association for making today's event possible.

The most recent election results in states like Kentucky, Virginia, and Louisiana proved that healthcare continues to be the number one issue for voters. Similar to 2018, winning candidates made health care a centerpiece of their campaigns and 2020 should yield similar results. Will congressional and presidential candidates learn from the recent elections and make healthcare a central campaign issue? Concurrent(ph) congressional Democrats and Republicans unite on a health care bill that increases access to care.

Is there an opportunity to strengthen protections for preexisting conditions? How will the administration and Congress work together to address health care costs? Perhaps, most important of all, how can Congress and the private sector work together to support continued innovation in health care? Today's program will feature several newsworthy discussions previewing health care policy in 2020. Our newsroom experts will be joined onstage with health care's most influential players for a deep dive on the most pressing issues facing Congress and presidential candidates in the run-up to the 2020 elections.

So let's dive in. We're delighted to have Congresswoman Donna Shalala, representing Florida's 27th District join us this morning. In 1993, Congresswoman Shalala was nominated by President Bill Clinton to serve as secretary of Health and human services. There, she created, implemented and oversaw the Children's Health Insurance Program or CHIP. Today, it covers more than 7.6 million children and has earned remarkable bipartisan support. She also succeeded in doubling the budget of the National Institutes for Health and secured the highest immunization rates in American history.

At the end of her eight-year tenure at HHS, a Washington Post article described her as, "One of the most successful government managers of modern times." In 2007, President George W Bush hand-picked her to co-chair with Senator Bob Dole, the Commission on Care for Returning Wounded Warriors, tasked with evaluating how wounded service members transition from active duty to civilian life.

In 2008, President Bush selected her as the recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award. Congresswoman Shalala has also received the Nelson Mandela Award for Health and Human Rights and was inducted into the National Women's Hall of Fame and has more than five dozen honorary degrees. Interviewing Congresswoman Shalala, CQ Roll Call's health reporter, Mary Ellen McIntire. Mary Ellen, over to you.

MCINTIRE: Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for being here. Thanks for joining us, Congresswoman.

SHALALA: You bet.

MCINTIRE: You know, no--no shortage of things to talk about this morning so we'll get right into it. But thought we would start with the Coronavirus which is really, you know, kind of what our Capitol Hill is talking about these days. You know, I know this week there's a lot of talk about a second sort of bill covering a wide range of policy issues coming together. What sort of are you expecting this to look like at this point and might you have something--might the house have something to start talking about this week?

SHALALA: Well, I think we read because we're concerned about the economy, obviously, but its impact on individuals. A third of our population has no paid sick leave and people who may have to stay home that are hourly employees won't get their salaries. So enhancing unemployment insurance, looking at the sick leave issue, there are--there are all sorts of restraints that the administration has put on SNAP benefits that we went to look at. But there are a set of things that affect real people and the effect of this economy on their jobs and we want to make sure that people are protected, but more importantly, that they don't hesitate to use the health care system. And there are gaps in our health care system, obviously.

We want to make sure that federally qualified health centers can send their tests to probably the commercial insurers, not just the state labs, but certainly to the commercial labs around the country. So we have to have backup systems both in terms of income as well as in health care for people. I know the White House has talked a little bit about this and about bailing out industries but before we start bailing out industries, we better worry about the workers in this country and their families.

MCINTIRE: One thing that a lot of health care experts have been concerned about is that costs associated with getting tested could be a deterrent. Are you guys looking at doing anything and targeting sort of out-of-pocket cost of leave and who would that be going towards?

SHALALA: Absolutely. Certainly, you want to eliminate any co-pays for getting treatment or getting the test; initially, getting the tests down the road. If there is a vaccine or a treatment protocol, you certainly want to cover all of that without any co-pays. We know from our experience in the flu vaccine that people actually will not do this unless you eliminate co-pays. So you want to eliminate it for everyone and then make sure those that don't have insurance or have lousy insurance.

There was a case of someone in Florida that went in to get the testing, got a $3000 bill. Now, everybody thought that was a surprise bill. It was certainly a surprise to the person, but it was really because he had a junk plan. He actually had a junk plan and that's one of the things we have to think about because these high deductible plans that people are taking, some of--they get mixed up with the surprise billing issue, but it really is high deductible plans. And that's why we have to make sure that we eliminate any kind of co-pays or deductibles for--for the tests initially, for treatment and certainly down the road for the possibility of a vaccine.

Now, we've done this before. Remember, we filled in the gaps with the Ryan White Act for AIDS because we wanted to make sure that everybody got the treatment. So this is not a new phenomena in which Congress and the administration steps up to make sure that everybody has the right kind of coverage.

MCINTIRE: And is this something--last week, Congress, of course, passed $8.3 billion supplemental, very bipartisan. As you get into more policy and not just the appropriations, how do you keep this as a bipartisan?

SHALALA: We would do everything we can And I've done everything I can to make sure that people know that this virus doesn't know the difference between Republicans and Democrats or independents. Not that--this virus is not choosing a candidate in the presidential election. So it has to be bipartisan, it must be.

MCINTIRE: What might, you know, trying to keep down costs of a future vaccine or treatment, I know that's been a sticking point in the last couple of weeks on the vaccine issue. Those typically aren't, you know, where drug companies are making their money, as my understanding. But what might U.S. be looking at in the future to try to keep those future costs down?

SHALALA: Well, we just have to have permanent funding. The problem is that we treat all of this is an ad hoc exercise that unlike--I think in my op-ed in The Times earlier in the week, I argued that we needed the Stafford Act for public health. That is, we need something that kicked in the additional money, but we needed permanent funding for the public health infrastructure in this country.

That's Not just the NIH, the FDA, and the CDC and the public health service. It is in fact, the state, local governments who have their places on the ground. It was very difficult when I was secretary to convince people, Congress in particular, that we needed to permanently fund the public health infrastructure, that block grant in the CDC They just kept cutting because they saw it as kind of loose money that they could move around, but without a permanent infrastructure.

Look, I don't know the name of the next virus, but I can assure you it's going to come in the next two years. So unless we do permanent funding, unless we have a readiness that's very different from what we have now, we are simply not going to be able to protect the American people.

MCINTIRE: You think this virus could be a turning point in getting Congress to think about that in any way?

SHALALA: I think so. And certainly, I have colleagues on the Democratic side that where we're starting to think about how do we make this more permanent. And that means we need a public health workforce that we can slide in that are going to spend their careers worrying about on the ground issues.

MCINTIRE: So as you noted, a lot of the commercial labs have now started testing for this. It's been a lot of talk about trying to track how many people have been tested. How important do you think that is like having those numbers? Are you concerned that those numbers aren't currently available?

SHALALA: It's very important. And frankly, the labs are used to turning over the information to the CDC. We do have an infrast--information infrastructure in this country in which docs call their--their health departments when they see something. And that's--that's the way we've always caught things, whether it's a food outbreak, it's always been that pattern of reporting first to the local health officials and then to the state health officials and then to the CDC. And that's the way we've caught things early on in this country. And yes, the commercial labs, which have basically taken over the testing business in this country.

I mean, everybody was worried about the number of public labs that we had around the country. The truth is it's these commercial labs that need to add this to their protocols and they have stepped up big time to--to do this. And I think--I think pharma's going to step up. We've been beating on them so much that this is their opportunity to shine. Assuming that we get a vaccine--sorry I'm getting hoarse--I've talked so much. I'm getting hoarse. So they're going to bake--you know, everybody's working on the vaccine issue, a lot of people are working on the vaccine issue. It's the treatment that we need to get first which is the same way we took on the AIDS crisis.

We--we--when I arrived at HHS, people were just dying. My--most of my early career, people died from AIDS and we finally got a treatment somewhere in the middle of our administration, and then making it widespread was extremely important.

MCINTIRE: So do you expect several of your colleagues have announced in the last couple of days that they are self-quarantined after coming in contact, possibly with people who have tested positively for the virus. How do you expect this to affect Congress and Capitol Hill and your day to day work up there? It sounds like you guys aren't expecting at this point for a prolonged recess, but how do you kind of see that taking shape?

SHALALA: You know, it's hard to tell. As of now, you know, we're going to work every day. And--but everybody's avoiding large groups. I noticed that some of the fly-ins, people that fly in from around the country to lobbyists are being canceled, we do a lot more telephonically. My town, I'd finished a whole series of town meetings, but in my community, I'm going to have to do more about the Coronavirus But I'll do them electronically, I mean, with people calling in. For one thing, I'll get more people to sign up. When I do that, I'll get a thousand people. When I do a town meeting, I maybe get as many as 300. So I'm happy to do whatever we need to do in terms of communications.

MCINTIRE: How do you feel, you know, this shift to focusing on the coronavirus might affect the rest of Congress's health care agenda in the coming months, particularly an ability to possibly get a surprise billing or drug pricing bill to come together, given that you also have this focus now?

SHALALA: Well, I think it's brought everybody health--the entire health care system in focus because what Coronavirus tells you is what are the gaps in the health care system. And it's not just an emergency response because you have to use the health care infrastructure to respond to it. So I don't think it will slow down our agenda. We will have a big health care bill, what we describe as a big health care bill, not what I would describe as a big health care bill; that basically beefs up and fixes some of the challenges in the Affordable Care Act, for example.

We never got a chance to make the technical corrections that we wanted to do. We knew we weren't going to get the subsidies right the first time around. So we will do some of that. We passed a very large bill on negotiating drug prices already and so I--And we just passed a huge bill, which I was honored to co-sponsored and I co-sponsored the drug bill as well but Frank Pallone and I had a big bill on vaping which is a big public health crisis.

Shu--we brought kids smoking down to 3 percent. The tobacco companies pivoted and we now have 27 percent of all high school students that are vaping, I mean, that are using nicotine. And so we have another public health crisis that involves young people in this country.

MCINTIRE: So couple of things in there that I wanted to touch on. First, forthcoming ACA bills. Is that tied to the 10th anniversary?

SHALALA: Yes. It's tied to the--

MCINTIRE: What do you expect to be beefing up subsidies?

SHALALA: It'll focus on affordability. Here's what we hear when we go out into our communities. We ran on coverage. That is a preexisting condition. That's a coverage issue. The issue for our constituents is clearly affordability. And so, we will--I expect the bill to focus on affordability and making the ACA more affordable. That means, deeper subsidies, probably going a little deeper into the middle class and when we have bipartisan support (INAUDIBLE), the Republicans are fighting us, I mean, they're in court to get rid of--this is--We're still in repeal But no one has any kind of replacement. But we're still in the repeal mode with-- because they're suing us and they're not going to be very helpful about this particular bill. Some of them will.

Look, I have the largest enrollment in the Affordable Care Act of any congressional district in the country. There are more than 100,000 people in my district that are in the Affordable Care Act. Florida has a huge enrollment, even though we haven't expanded Medicaid. So it's very important to the people that I represent.

MCINTIRE: What are you--on--on this price billing issue, where would you say things stand right now you've been very involved in this issue in the last few months particularly?

SHALALA: Yeah. And I've made no secret of the fact that I favor the bill that came out of ways of being right which is from my point of view much more balanced. The one thing you want to do in good health care policy or good public policy, in general, is not tilt one way or another. The whole--the issue in politics is whose ox are you going to gore? Political scientists use that term and that is who is going to get hurt? Who's going pay?

In this case, I want to make sure that the doctors, the nurses, the people that work in hospitals, the patient first is protected in all the bills, but we don't tilt toward the insurance companies or towards the doctor or towards the hospitals in a--in an improper way. There has to be balance in terms of who pays. And--and I think some of the bills tilt one way or the other And I think the Ways and Means Bill is more balanced.

They're going to have to negotiate because we have three committees. Two of them came out one way and one of them, the Ways and Means Committee came out, which I think is a much more balanced. But the key is what can we negotiate on the Senate side? But the real key is what will the president accept? It looks like he'll accept anything that will solve the problem. All of the bills solve the problem for the patient. Some of them, from my point of view, are a disaster for the health care system, have unintended consequences for the people who provide health care and the institutions like hospitals, academic health centers, children's hospitals, rural health care.

And I just think sometimes you have to have a lighter hand of government and it has to be fairer. It can't be so heavy-handed. So I'm hoping will be able to negotiate something nearer to the Ways and Means Bill.

MCINTIRE: And at this point, if our final bill does look more similar to the Education and Labor Energy and Commerce Committee, would you consider voting against it at this point?

SHALALA: I'm not sure it'll pass. I'm just--I think that we've got to be able to make the case to our colleagues that it's a fair bill.

MCINTIRE: Great. I'm going to up for questions in just one moment if anyone else has anything. But given that it isn't an election year, I think I'd be remiss not to bring up sort of how health care is playing on the campaign trail. In your district, you talked a lot about people being opposed to Medicare for all, the focus on affordability. How do you think that is shaping things at this point?

SHALALA: Well, I think it's really about affordability. It's really--But when people say affordability, they're talking about their out-of-pocket costs. And I think it's important to remember that not only have we shifted the health care system one way or another, but we have a lot more people who have good health insurance, but high deductibles And that is--that has, by the way, mixed-up this surprise billing situation. But because we have high deductibles, people are seeing their out-of-pocket costs in many times for the first time. They're seeing out-of-pocket costs because of the high deductibles.

If they're in a plan like the one we designed at the University of Miami where we pay the upfront costs and all the primary care costs, they don't see it as much. They do have a donut hole and a high deductible, but we cover the front end. But if they just have a high deductible plans, whoa, they're seeing out-of-pocket costs and that's what they're feeling. And--and that makes the health care system very different for them but everybody is talking to us about out-of-pocket costs. That's what we have to focus on.

They focus--The public is focused on drug costs, but drug costs are only a part of it but drug costs have become the proxy for what has unfolded from, in my judgment, the high deductible plans.

MCINTIRE: Do you think that people having more out-of-pocket costs, often in those high deductible plans does help kind of drive support for Medicare for all in a way?

SHALALA: I think there are a variety of things, including the simplicity of it.

MCINTIRE: All right, my moment here. Anyone in the audience have questions?

SHALALA: No, wait. No one who I've met is for Medicare for all understands the Medicare program. If they did, they'd probably call for Medicaid for all which is more comprehensive. A very good point.

MCINTIRE: I think we have mikes that are coming around, if you could just wait for that and then just state your name and who you're with and ask your question.

QUESTION: Thank you for being here Representative Shalala, and thank you for this event. My name is Richelle Friedman. I'm with the Coalition on Human Needs. And at the very end, Representative Shalala, you talked about drug pricing becoming a proxy for high deductible--deductible. I'm thinking that that might sort of say something about it's not really about drug pricing, but I think it really is about drug pricing. So could you speak a little bit more to that? Thank you.

SHALALA: I think, you know, I've been--I've known about the politics of drug pricing and how Americans compare our prices to other countries. The fact is that the rest of the world has cost shifted on to us the cost--the lower cost of their drugs have been subsidized by Americans, that we essentially pay for the research component and for and therefore, we pay more for drugs than any other people in the world.

And that has led to discussions about why can't we just import drugs from Canada or from Mexico? My sister lives in North Dakota and she can run across the border to the pharmacy on the other side and get drugs at a much lower cost and by the way, they'll take her American prescriptions there but every American can't do that. But drug prices are certainly higher in this country for a wide variety of drugs and insulin has been the poster child for this fee.

The head of J and J--no, the head of Eli Lilly came in to see me when he was cutting the cost of insulin. They were about to have a press conference. And he actually said to me he could have cut it even lower. I thought, why are you saying this to me? I think he came in for a photo opportunity and he ended up saying that to me. But I think Americans are seeing drug costs. I think their drug coverage has gaps in it and so they're seeing the out-of-pocket costs, particularly if they're forced into taking a certain kind of drug if their doctor wants them to take another drug.

But the reason I said it's a proxy is because it's a clear example of us always overpaying and--and having strong out-of-pocket cost and it's the most concrete example that we have. And so, people are reacting to it. But there's no question that we're paying more than any European country or--or--or Canada or Mexico or Australia. But--but let me say this.

The arguments the drug companies have given us has been that we'll destroy their pipeline, we'll destroy innovation. And every proposal I've seen, including the one the Democrats passed, actually allow for that in the pricing mechanism. And so, I don't buy that. I also don't buy that they have big pipelines anymore that they produce. They're basically buying licenses from the major research universities that are producing the ideas that have come out of the NIH investments that we've made.

But these are real costs by real people. I sit often because I--I'm kind of hands-on and learning health policy. I'll sit in a CVS or a Walgreens on the chairs and watch as people come in and find out, particularly the elderly or people that have chronic diseases and have conversations with their pharmacists about costs and about what discounts are available to them. And while Part D was an enormous improvement, it doesn't cover everybody and particularly people that don't have very good health care.

So these are real things. And I'm simply saying it's the most concrete example for people of--of out-of-pocket costs and I--I couldn't be more sympathetic with that. And that's why I often--when I--I know everybody that provides a service for me exactly what their healthcare situation is, what their costs are, what their out-of-pocket costs are and what they're concerned about, because I learned more about health policy from talking to real people about their situations than I do, frankly, from reading the articles. Sorry about that.

MCINTIRE: No worries. Well, we are out of time for this morning's. Sorry if anyone else had questions but thank you so much for joining us, congresswoman.

SHALALA: Welcome.

RESNIK: Thank you again, Congresswoman Shalala, for your time this morning, and thank you, Mary Ellen, for leading that conversation. I'd like to welcome our presenting sponsor, the Better Medicare Alliance, to the stage. Former Congresswoman, Allyson Schwartz is the president and CEO of the Better Medicare Alliance. Joining the congresswoman is Gail Wilensky, senior fellow at Project Hope. Sorry, just a moment. All right, Gail, Congresswoman, the floor is yours.

WILENSKY: Get myself together. Pleasure to be here this morning, especially to share a few minutes with Congresswoman Schwartz. Always a pleasure to spend a few minutes with her. This is an interesting time because we are going now full blast into the election and one of the things that we know, not surprisingly true for almost every election, is health care is a big issue. People sometimes will ask me, do I think health care is going to be an issue in whatever election is coming up? And the answer, even without paying any attention to the polls, is almost invariably yes, for at least two reasons.

First is that health care, health care costs particularly out-of-pocket cost, what it costs the individual is always an issue. But politically, you can be sure that health care is going to be an issue because it's in the interest of Democrats to make sure that health care comes up as an issue in a national election, because years and years, decades and decades' worth of polling has shown that on average, people feel more comfortable with the positions of Democrats on issues like health care and Social Security. And so you can rest assured that it will come up as an election issue.

But there are particular reasons why we are seeing health care as an even more important issue than usual. I know that the Better Medicare Alliance is releasing a new study today and one of the things I hopefully discuss is a little bit about what that study has found. But what I also want to talk about is some of the support that you are finding for Medicare Advantage as an option for people to choose and how the members of Congress are reacting to the program. So maybe talk a little bit about that.

SCHWARTZ: Well, good morning, everyone, and pleased to see you again this year. Always good--good to do this. And yes, health care is certainly always been on my agenda, it seems for a very long time, but it is on people's minds. And I can connect the two kinds of questions you asked about, which is why does it matter so much how much does it matter politically and how--and how we actually have achieved really bipartisan support for Medicare Advantage of a place where both Democrats and Republicans or people of no political stripe actually, you know, really come together and--and why.

So first, I would say yes, health care is always an issue for people. It's helped me--Interesting thing about health care policy is it's not a big policy It's one that really individuals can relate to. It's--it's really a part of our daily conversations, you know, whether we're healthy or not. And certainly, you just heard Congresswoman Shalala talk about what's on all of our minds right now with the coronavirus.

And, you know, how do we act responsibly for ourselves? How do we act responsibly for our communities and at--what we do together as a nation? That's kind of a big picture question that we're facing right now around public health and personal health issues. But we--we--what we know also is that right now, increasingly individuals, consumers are very concerned about health care costs and they're not concerned about federal costs, they are concerned their costs, their out-of-pocket costs.

You see this with prescription drug coverage. It's you know, you're at the pharmacy, can I afford that co-pay? Can I afford all my medication? What if I do if I have high-cost specialty drugs? You heard about, again, Congresswoman Shalala talking about high deductible plans and out-of-pocket costs, which is really deductibles, co-pays. This is like insurance language, but it sort of matters to each of us every day as to what do you actually have to pay.

And as we know, more and more consumers, whether they're employees or within individual market are finding themselves--are faced with having more costs directly related to them. That's a huge issue. I think--And so it is a political issue.

Around Medicare Advantage, what I think is particularly interesting is, you know, the goals around Medicare Advantage are to provide a more integrated system of care that can do care coordination, offer your provider of--network of providers can help you sort through what--instead of a very fragmented fee for service system, which can be confusing, can be expensive and can be hard to access. It actually helps you navigate all those health care services.

And seniors, it's a voluntary decision. How you get Medicare when you sign up, you get to decide if you notice it. If you don't decide, you're going to traditional fee for service Medicare, but you can choose is more integrated care coordinate system and consumers are choosing it. You've been following this, of course, with a 10 percent increase in Medicare Advantage. This past year, we've been seeing 8 to 10 percent increases since the last one to five years.

But what's interesting about it is the--in related to consumer costs and you have this report that we're putting out today, so that you are the first ones to see it. It's on your on your seat. There's report we did last year and did again this year which actually asked consumers' Medicare beneficiaries to national survey data, We didn't do the survey, that's the national Medicare data. But asking consumers if they actually are more cost-burdened or less cost-burdened if they're in Medicare Advantage compared to traditional Medicare.

And last year, we found it was about $1,200 a year less in savings. This year it was almost $1,600 per year savings if you signed up for Medicare Advantage and it's really important data for people to take into account. And that's because we've seen premiums go down in Medicare Advantage. Half of people who are enrolled in Medicare Advantage actually pay nothing extra after they pay part B that they don't need to and cannot buy Medigap, so that is a savings.

These tend to be MAPD plans so your part D coverage is included in that. And plus you get extra benefits. Half of the plans provide some dental vision hearing and wellness programs. All four of those are provided by 50 percent of the plans.

WILENSKY: This is especially important because as I assume most of you know, people tend to have lower incomes once they retire, once they're eligible for Medicare. And so while it's always important to us how much we have to spend for Medicare or health insurance, it becomes extremely important as you get older. My old agency, CMS, has proposed payment rules and maybe you could talk a little bit about the kinds of payments they're proposing going forward and any thoughts you have about adequacy for the purpose at hand.

SCHWARTZ: We--we do watch CMS very carefully, so we'll watch all of them, every regulation that put out. But there is requite--required annual rate notice they call it is when they actually decide the rate they will pay for Medicare events next year and related policies. The rates are actually somewhat by formula but so it's really about the--the--the other policies that they-- two things I'll point out. Lots of details, but two that I'll point out that we're looking at and many of our allies, BMA is an alliance of almost 150 organizations and almost 500,000 beneficiary advocates of Medicare. But working together, we're concerned about--one thing we've liked a lot which is they're proposing expanded use of telehealth.

You've heard about this happening because of the coronavirus, the idea that you could actually maybe not leave your home and go to the doctor's offices and sit in the waiting room with other sick people or healthy people or a combination thereof but more telehealth. This has been a space where Medicare Advantage has really led in using telehealth more because it (AUDIO GAP) aid by service, they're paid in a lump sum. So that's a useful tool for them. And really funding is a really important innovations in that.

Group sessions, you can have or mental health visit or (AUDIO GAP) interesting kinds of models, I'm not to mention just being able to communicate with your doctor if you need to or the doctors communicating to each other, which is actually very helpful as well. (AUDIO GAP) but also greater use of telehealth, so we're very positive about that. We want them to keep those rules and to move forward on that. It's a chance away from Medicare Advantage to continue to innovate in this new space and new technology and all.

But the other area is interesting is that 500,000 people in this country have end-stage renal disease and they've always been for very long time carved out and they've been offered--

WILENSKY: 72, thank you.

SCHWARTZ: I didn't even know that. Is that the federal government recognized that even people under 65 who end up with end-stage renal disease and go on dialysis are very complex patients, They tend to have comorbidities, they are very expensive, They now costs about $100,000 a year to be on dialysis three times a week, typically. And so, they said, gross, if who you are, you can get a Medicare if you've end-stage renal disease, it's really recognition of the high cost of special needs of this population. So thank you CMS, going back a while. But they always were carved out of Medicare Advantage.

And if you are in Medicare Advantage and you had chronic kidney disease and you had kidney failure, you could stay in Medicare Advantage, but you couldn't enroll in Medicare Advantage once you were diagnosed. That changes in 2021. We think that's a good idea.
