We think many of these patients could benefit from the care coordination and the supplemental benefits even if it's transportation to your dialysis center could be an issue. But there are issues and a big issue is often happens is payment.

Now, plans are not paid adequately to be able to pay the dialysis provider's and facilities. And there is a sense that there needs to be adjustments in the way the payment is done. We've done some--we've asked for some analysis disparities across the country. In (INAUDIBLE) particularly metropolitan areas where many of the beneficiaries are. There are higher incidence of those with end-stage renal disease, minorities, African-Americans and Hispanics. So we're asking CMS to find other ways to make sure that there's adequate payment, that there's a smooth transition, and that is enough resources to innovate in this space, more home dialysis potential mobile dialysis, use of outpatient hospital facilities to really create opportunities to bring down the cost overall.

WILENSKY: There's one other issue and I'd like to touch on, and that has to do with the kinds of benefits that are now being allowed as maybe in the audience I--I've (AUDIO GAP) been hearing about it again in the run-up for the election that so much of health reflects what we call the social determinants of health. The places where you live and where you're born and the circumstances that you face as opposed to only a direct medical care.

And one of the things that happened in a very important way was the Chronic Care Act which is now just being implemented, that allowed the Medicare program, the Medicare Advantage programs to include, as you were already alluding to, some of the social services, maybe tell a little bit more than you had already discussed what you think that will mean for some of the services that they can now receive.

SCHWARTZ: And I'll just say the Chronic Care Act was a bipartisan effort in the Senate House, which was great and made a lot of changes in recognizing that the high costs in Medicare these days is really part of those single episodes of care when you do go to the hospital. But--but also it's the treatment and care of people with chronic conditions and multiple chronic conditions. A lot of people--I went on a home visit recently was with one of our provider allies. Both the husband and wife each had six to--six or eight chronic conditions, kind of sounds crazy. But not unusual in this day and age to have people have four or five or six chronic conditions.

So they recognized that they made some changes both in fee for service but in Medicare Advantage and they work practically to the plans to be able to pry with no extra dollars. These are just dollars that they in the monthly payments and dollars they can save from avoidable hospitalizations and avoidable ER visits. Some of those dollars and actually to be able to find extra benefits that are not covered in traditional Medicare. Because you're right, there's been increasing recognition that, yes, we need clinical medical care. But in fact, what happens to the rest of our lives with her family history we can't do much about or whether it is, you know, our environment that we live in or access to health services or income or our limitations, functional limitations, that the social determinants of health account a great deal in being able to care for people and to be able to improve outcomes.

So if your goal is to improve healthcare outcomes, which it isn't Medicare Advantage and to keep people healthier than you--then they start to realize that it really was important to do things like care in the home or even now they can do respite care for a caregiver, which is going to be really important to offer transportation to medical appointments. Huge issue for health care providers, getting people to a doctor or clinician, including not just calling 911 in the hospital, getting an ambulance to the hospital, but actually go into that primary care doctor or the nurse practitioner or the clinician you see and do that regularly to get your prescriptions if they need to be delivered, to get you even meal delivery.

This has been going on for several years where meal delivery after an acute illness even for two weeks actually avoids readmissions because people actually-- post-surgery, I don't know If you have that experience, you hopefully you have family support. But if you don't, if you're elderly, if you can't get out of the house to buy groceries, you can't cook food for yourself, you are not getting nourished and you don't heal as well. Huge issues or you're not even hydrated. I mean, it's just a huge issue. So that's made a big difference. So now plans are allowed. Not all plans are doing this, but we are seeing plans really want to innovate in this space, particularly around healthy foods, a meal delivery, transportation, care in the home, they were even able to do some home modifications.

So if you need one of those chair sliders because you've just had surgery for a month or so, if you need grippers in your--in your bathroom to prevent falls, these are things that now get--not every plan is offering all this, but in fact, it is happening across this country. There's a way for us to test out what works and what doesn't, what's most important and to ask you what personalized health care for people to be able--It also allows is you can target some of these benefits to the people who need it. It's not really allowed in traditional Medicare. Although, some people have more needs than others and getting them those cares will help them get healthier and save costs for the government.

So I don't think I answered your question about the bipartisan nature. I should say that this year, we had 403 members of Congress split evenly between R and Ds and sign a letter supporting Medicare Advantage that went to CMS. That's 75 percent of Congress; it's an astounding number. In this moment, it only seems that all we're doing is arguing about health care and how we actually achieve the goal.

It turns out for Medicare Advantage, Republicans like it, maybe because they like it--because it's using the private sector, it's a little more nimble in getting things done, they like the competition around quality and cost. Democrats like the security and the guaranteed benefits and yes, these social determinants of health and both Republicans and Democrats really like lower costs for consumers and better costs for the government.

WILENSKY: How to objective that combination What we'll have to look for going forward is whether traditional Medicare, because it will probably always be an important choice for some seniors, can figure out how to do a better job integrating care. It is a program that's been set up that makes it challenging, irrespective of the desires of the physicians and nurses and other clinicians providing care to be able to integrate that care because part A inpatient hospital and part B physician and clinical labs and Part D outpatient prescription drugs are very separate even so much that if you have the physicians closing a savings to occur in prescription drugs or in inpatient services, the physicians can't get credit and the saving and spending is locked into whichever part makes it.

It's just a reminder of how stove-piped traditional Medicare is. Medicare Advantage isn't always as integrated as we would like to see, but it at least allows a structure that if the plan is focused on integrating care for seniors, it can do so and I think it's a--it's an advantage that will be even more important as our population continues to age. I know I'm more interested in seeing that than I was eight, 10 or 15 years ago. So thank you for having this.

SCHWARTZ: It's a good lesson for the whole health care system. It really is. So thank you for your comments and also it's my question to you about what do you think about Medicare Advantage and where Medicare is going in the future. But I think you're right. Those are gonna be around but it is a way to inform and improve health care for not only seniors but maybe for all of us.

WILENSKY: I suspect as the people who age into Medicare are even more used to having networks as the way that they receive care, that wasn't the case, say, 20 or 25 years ago, when most of the people who were over 65 had not experienced that before. They got to be on Medicare that you will see Medicare Advantage grow even more in popularity because it will be what people were used to having when they were working.

But importantly, for some people, having traditional Medicare will always be important, if only philosophically and because it's what they're used to or because they're in an area where having integrated care is hard to come by. Some of the more rural areas, small towns of the country that traditional Medicare will be important and it'll be important as an option to push Medicare Advantage to be even better than it is right now.

SCHWARTZ: Well, let's thank Wilensky also. She's using the speaker, not the interviewer. So let's thank her very much for doing this.

(APPLAUSE)

RESNIK: Thank you, Gail. Thank you, Congresswoman, and thank you again to the Better Medicare Alliance for making today's event possible. Keeping things moving, our first panel this morning will examine the state of play of the politics of healthcare. Healthcare seems to always be an issue in Washington. Being the pressing issue at the moment, coronavirus, the White House and Congress's negotiations on drug prices, The Supreme Court's decision to hear the Affordable Care Act challenges where the presidential campaign trails aim to define where our health care future lies.

This panel will focus on what's next. Moving forward into 2020, what particular health care issues will take the spotlight? Mary Ellen McIntire will return to moderate this discussion which features a number of political experts. Bill Hoagland, SVP at Bipartisan Policy Center. Bill directs and manages the center's fiscal, health, and economic policy analysis. Before joining Bipartisan Policy Center in 2012, Bill served as the VP of public policy at Cigna.

He worked with business leaders, trade associations and interest groups to develop the company's policy on health care reform issues at both the state and federal level. Before joining Cigna, Bill completed 33 years of federal government service, including 25 years as a Senate staffer.

Jim Manley is a public affairs consultant and Democratic strategist With more than two decades of experience working in Congress. He formerly served as the senior communications adviser and spokesman for then Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid and the Senate Democratic Caucus. Jim played a major role in crafting the messaging strategy and tactics surrounding the passage of the Affordable Care and Patient Protection Act, as well as the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.

Michael Cannon is the director of health policy studies at the Cato Institute. Michael has been described as an influential health care walk by The Washington Post and Obamacare's fiercest critic. Before joining the Cato Institute, Michael served as a domestic policy analyst for the U.S. Senate Republican Policy Committee, where he advised the Senate leadership on health, education, labor, and welfare. Mary Ellen and our panel The floor is yours.

MCINTIRE: All right We've got a pretty pro-Senate panel up here today I guess so we can take away from those introductions. Thank you all for joining us. We're going to be talking, like Josh said, about what comes next on health care. And you know, we have a lot. With the congresswoman about the Coronavirus which sort of seems to be taking a lot of the attention of Congress right now but Congress is also supposed to working on some sort of health care package ahead of this May 22nd deadline for our community health centers and other public health programs. To get started on that, what do you guys think is the likelihood of Congress being able to come together and get some sort of health care package in the next couple of months and weeks?

HOAGLAND: I'll start with my sense is that the May deadline before the coronavirus broke and big news, everybody I think thought that that was going to be the triggering point for either surprise billing or some prescription drug amendments that would carry those through. I now think that that triggering date will serve more to address some of the issues that was raised by the secretary and that is the second supplemental on dealing with providing assistance to those who are impacted, individuals who are impacted.

And so that will pull it--pull it through and only then maybe would--maybe surprise billing be attached to it. So I do see the May deadline is critical, but it's going to be more focused on the coronavirus Second supplemental.

MANLEY: I think I'd probably agree with that. I must admit, I haven't spent a lot of time focusing on the impact of the Coronavirus, on how to move the legislative process. As you're about to find out depending what the question is, I'm going to be very pessimistic about getting much of anything done in Congress this year.

Having said that, you know, for me, one of the fascinating things to watch Congress is the fact that this, you know, surprise billing issue hasn't been addressed and for me, it underlines the fundamental problems with Congress in this day and age, you know, in that it's broken. And the other thing I just simply raise is that I don't know if others have discussed this, but, you know, some of these bills being discussed, including surprise billing for this--for this May 20 package, you know, could serve as pay for us as well to pay for some of the other bills that are out there and or the extension of the previous package that has gone towards May 20th. So there is an inducement to deal with this but whether it's going to be enough to get it over the goal line remains to be seen.

CANNON: So I think I agree with Bill. Congress really doesn't do business as usual anymore. We start in the sense of meeting deadlines and passing bills and that sort of thing. They respond to crises and sometimes those crises can pull other things along with them and get people to overcome. What I do think, it has been an increase in partisanship in Congress. I'm usually skeptical of those claims, but I am--I think it is getting worse.

MCINTIRE: What do you guys think Sort of the shift in the past couple of months--a couple of years to start talking about healthcare costs in Congress as opposed to sort of the bitter fights over the Affordable Care Act in Obamacare, particularly kind of highlighted in 2017. Michael, what do you think of that shift in the past couple of years and how does that--the election may be shifted back to that?

CANNON: Well, that is what supporters of the ACA promised and Donna Shalala said this. On occasion is that first, you have to get everyone covered and then, we can worry about cost control. So if you think about it, it's really sort of a dessert for spinach later approach to health policy. Well--we'll hand out lots of subsidies to health care providers and--and--and--and--and insurance companies and we'll--we'll--we'll cut back on the--on the payments to them, will--the excessive--excessive prices, the waste, the fraud, we'll take care of all of that later.

It doesn't really work that way. I mean, once you--once you expand coverage, it's very hard then for Congress to try to eliminate any of the waste to excessive pricing in the system. Look at surprise medical bills. Here is an issue that has--that is affecting just about everyone. Raise your hand, by the way, if you or someone in your household has ever gotten a surprise medical bill. Okay, so this affects a lot of people, usually in the majority of the room. And this affects a lot of people.

There is popular support for doing something about surprise medical bills, bipartisan support, bi-cameral support for it and it--and the fixes have been proposed would really only affect a small percentage of physicians, a small percentage of healthcare providers. Congress still--still can't get it done because it might reduce someone's income or might reduce someone's access to care and Congress is just no good at this. Every dollar of wasteful health care spending is a dollar of income to somebody and that somebody has a lobbyist and that lobbyist is gonna fight to defend it.

So--so they can try to pivot--There's all this talk about pivoting to costs and trying to do something about costs. I'm very skeptical that they're going to be able to do anything simply because no one is very careful with their spending other people's money and certainly not as careful as they are when they're spending their own and that's why we have so much excessive pricing, so much waste in healthcare.

HOAGLAND: By the way, Mary Ellen, with Congress fiddles around about surprise billing, the states are doing something on their own. As I recall, state of Virginia just finished their session which they came up with a baseball arbitration approach to it. The longer we delay and dally about it, the states are going to go ahead and start doing it on their own.

MCINTIRE: Right, that make sense. Jim, House Democrats are getting ready to and Senate Democrats, I'm sure as well that we've kind of heard a little bit from the congresswoman about House Democrats getting ready to celebrate the 10-year anniversary of the ACA, a health care affordability package, looking at maybe beefing up subsidies coming forward. How is that helpful for Democrats to be talking about the ACA and as we're on the campaign trail right now?

MANLEY: Yeah, I got to tell you, when I read The New York Times online last night, the leek of the upcoming speech by the speaker and to former President Obama, I was very excited that it actually would give me something to talk about especially in the context, the current political debate, because I think building on the successes of the Obamacare is exactly the right way to go. And I am--I, for one, am deeply skeptical about the support out there for so-called Medicare for all.

So, again, I--I was through--I've been through the health care wars, not only to survive Obamacare, is going back to patients' bill of rights, as Michael pointed out when I worked for Senator Kennedy, working with his old pal John McCain. Reform is hard and I learned from Kennedy that sometimes, half a loaf is better than nothing at all. And so given the hyperpolarized environment that we're in, I think hanging our hat on modest reforms, the current health care system are--are not--are the right way to go.

And again, not to--Well, actually, I will be critical, you know, that for--the reforms being demanded by the Medicare for all folks are just too extreme and I am delighted to see that they are beginning to realize that, you know, it's only a asper--you know, it--it's aspirational at best. I think it's deeply unfair for senators to demand Medicare for all for their constituents at a time when there's not a snowball's chance in hell. It's going to get done anytime soon. So, again, I think it's right way to go on the policy. I think it's the right way to go into politics. It's good--it gives the speaker and the Senate Democrats something to rally round in the weeks and months to come because while the real election may focus one, two and three on Donald Trump, for Democrats, health care reform is going to serve as a powerful wedge issue.

MCINTIRE: So far Bill, do you think--Jim, sorry. Do you think that Democrats are doing a good job of following up on the 2018 playbook that, you know, put house Democrats in power as you know, I think you would hope they would be?

MANLEY: You know, it's tricky, Mary Ellen. You know, I--I--I for one sure, I would like to start the two year--this two-year cycle by focusing on bread and butter issues, including health care and, yes, the speaker and her team had passed a long list of agenda items, all of which are going to die and or have died a quick, painful death in the Senate. But I also acknowledge that you know, for better, for worse, we had to deal with the impeachment issue. That's been done. I know the speaker very well. She's got an amazing ability to walk and chew gum. I hate that phrase, but she's got an amazing ability to walk and chew--chew gum at the same time and she is going to Hammer on her caucus to the extent she needs to--to focus on these issues in the weeks and months to come.

Again, for better, for worse, I can talk about that as well as some of the things, the oversight we're going to lose but I'm confident she can do it.

MCINTIRE: Michael, as Republicans are talking about health care, you know, they've tactics--the president talks a lot about trying to lower drug prices but some have criticized Republicans for not really having a clear replacement plan for the ACA. How do you think Republicans should be talking about this as Democrats are talking about, you know, building out on this Medicare for all public option or even just beating up subsidies?

CANNON: How should Republicans be talking about health care? Gosh, talk about aspiration. If you understand the politics of health care of the United States, I have a little joke that helps people understand the politics of health care in the United States. It goes like this. What do Republicans and Christian scientists have in common? They just don't do health care and--and it--and it really shows and when I saw Amy Klobuchar's health care, her two-paragraph health care plan, you remember that Elizabeth Warren hammered against, I thought is she running for the right party's nomination? I thought she was running as a Republican, her health plan was so thin.

It's really hard to get Republicans to focus on this. I worked in the Senate for--Senate leadership for four years. I was not a Republican at the time. They knew that before they hired me, I couldn't get them interested in health care because it's just, I mean, there are really important reasons for this. But it's, you know, I have all sorts of ideas about what they should be talking about.

One of the problems is when they do talk about health care, often they are not talking about what they're--they're not following their principles supposedly about freedom and free markets and limited government. Oftentimes, they're just sticking up for the industry that wants bigger subsidies from the--from the federal government. I think a perfect example and sort of a man bites dog, an example of--of Republicans doing something on health care is the Medicare Part B International Pricing Index proposal that the Trump administration has put forward.

I think just about everybody who has looked at pricing for Medicare Part B drugs agrees that -outside of the industry maybe - agrees that these prices are excessive, that the way the Congress came up with paying for these drugs is inherently inflationary, not only inflates the prices, but it also encourages doctors to pick the most expensive drugs. And what the Trump administration did was a very sensible step that would address the problem that Congresswoman Shalala mentioned or help mitigate it of U.S. consumers having to pay the--the R&D costs for drugs and effectively subsidizing folks or patients in governments in other countries.

He said, look, we'll just make the prices--the--we'll just peg them to the average price for a basket of countries rather than just the average price in the United States. That would have the effect of bringing those prices down. So I thought this was wonderful. You know, this is--this is finally a Republican administration that proposes something that would reduce health care spending. And you would think that all sorts of conservative groups would rally around this government limiting proposal. But what has happened? You see front page ads - not front page, full-page ads in The Wall Street Journal, in The Washington Post with all sorts of conservatives and even some couple libertarian groups, not the Cato Institute are calling this importing foreign price controls.

I didn't see the one in Roll Call. I saw those two and I have them and I can put them in PowerPoint presentations and all that. And so, you know, it's--it's really hard to get Republicans to say anything sensible about it--about health care. And when they do, they're often very divided and confuse what the industry wants with what is good for consumers and what is pro-market and pro-competition.

MCINTIRE: So Bill, as we are--I don't know if we can say we're getting to the end of the Democratic primary and perhaps tonight, we'll be a little bit instructive on that. But heading into the general election, how do you expect the health care debate to change sort of from Medicare for all versus public option camp into more of whoever the nominee is versus President Trump's health plans?

HOAGLAND: Well, as you say, it depends a lot about the Democratic nominee, whether it's going to be Senator Sanders or senator or vice president--former Vice President Biden. Particularly as we go into the campaign to--then to the presidential debates this fall, I think that we're going to see this dichotomy about whether we build upon the Affordable Care Act. I think Medicare for all, by the way, I agree with Jim completely, I think Medicare for all should be off the table first It will never pass in the United States Senate. There will never be 60 votes for anything like that unless there's a major--major change in the makeup of the Senate. I don't think it's going to happen.

So I think basically it's going to shift to along the lines, Michael won't agree with this, but I do think we're talking about improving upon the Affordable Care Act, building upon it. This is a selfish plug on my part. We spent the last three years at the Bipartisan Policy Center with a group that we call the Big Ten which was led by Senator Daschle and Senator Frist. And we came up with a proposal that we released about two weeks ago which basically says, come on, from a bipartisan perspective, you got to take what we've got and build--improve upon it.

There are things in there, Michael, that you would like as it relates to a cost and controlling cost and consolidations and pricing, but it was a bipartisan approach. I would hope--maybe I'm--maybe I'm a dreamer on this, I still think that there's a possibility that depending upon the outcome this fall, that we could still see a need to--Congress could still see a need to build upon and improve upon that particular law.

I think pricing, we talked--you talked about cost, I think the issue is price. I agree with Michael, I don't understand why Republicans didn't, quite frankly, in the Senate too take on the position that the president put forth with his proposal on this. But it does seem to me that--that--that the HR3 to some extent, it really goes down that same route, that there should have been some movement. But the whole issue to me is price and not in controlling those price and I think we're--we're going to have to come back to that in the next Congress.

MCINTIRE: Are any of you optimistic that there could be some sort of bipartisan, meaningful drug pricing agreement?

HOAGLAND: I don't believe in this session.

CANNON: Not--not optimistic, but I think it's possible because the Grassley-Wyden Bill is pretty sensitive. Again, if Republicans were following their limited government principles, they would say, hey, this is an attempt to try to reduce government spending. But get them in a room with a former lobbyist and innovation, oh, we can't stop that, oh, it sounds like government price controls, never mind that it is no more government price controls than what we're doing right now or no more government interfering with pricing than what the government is doing right now.

HOAGLAND: I would agree with--with Michael that--but I would expect this is where Jim will weigh in except the majority leader of the United States Senate does not plan on taking up the--

CANNON: Well, right because--

MANLEY: He stole my line actually. Yes, Senator McConnell's not in the habit of bringing up bills that picked up seven Republican no votes, How many--in the Finance Committee. I don't know if this is the right time or whatever, but I just say one word, reconciliation. Honestly, not going to happen year. Yeah, obviously not going to happen this year, but, you know, depending on how things play out, you know, the use of reconciliation will be interesting to watch.

HOAGLAND: Can I--can I weigh in there just a second having spent it (INAUDIBLE) Well, I have to keep reminding people, you know this. I kept reminding people, you don't get to reconciliation unless you pass a budget. We hadn't passed the budget for the last four years, we're not going to pass one this year and yet getting a budget passed is--

MANLEY: I know. that--I came up into it wrong. I mean, obviously, I was going to lay down that predicate, you got to pass a budget and it depends--you know, a lot--a lot of different variables, can't get into which one. But my only point raising is that, again, as I suggested earlier, I'm not sure how much of anything is going to be next is going to get done this year But depending on how things happen, hopefully--hopefully we'll flip the Senate. There is--There will be ability deals some of this stuff in the next--next Congress.

MCINTIRE: Do you think that if Democrats still control the Senate, you would get Republican votes on bipartisan bill?

MANLEY: No.

MCINTIRE: Gonna open it up for questions in just a moment, but wanted to bring up before we wrapped up the Texas vs. Azar case. Last week, the Supreme Court said it will hear the case sometime next--in its next term. What do you guys think ends up happening with this and how does this affect sort of the summer campaign?

CANNON: Why I like--we're talking about this because it's an issue in which Jim and I can agree because this case, even though--

MANLEY: I just found this out, by the way, I thought we were going to come to blowers (INAUDIBLE)

CANNON: No, so even though I had something to do--

HOAGLAND: And I had special sit between them.

CANNON: with another Obamacare case, it made it to the Supreme Court. I think it is unconstitutional-- the whole war was unconstitutional, should be overturned by the courts. Now, I don't think they should do it like this. I think this case is terrible. I mean, the plaintiffs don't have standing, there is no more mandate to challenge and if there--if there were, it would be severable from the rest of the law. I think it's a terrible case. But then again, the courts have handed down lousy opinions before Obamacare cases and it might be that he who lives by terrible judging also dies by terrible judging.

I don't want that to happen but I think that if that does happen, ACA supporters will only have themselves to blame. Now, I also think that it's the second most important to Obamacare case making its way through the courts or case related to Obamacare. There's another one that will be called a CAPI treasury, which is a challenge to the Trump administration Short term plans rule.

Congresswoman Shalala derided these earlier, but the young man in Florida she mentioned who got the $3,000 bill for--for a coronavirus test because he had a short term plan. He would have paid even more under Obamacare. If he had stayed with his Obamacare plan, he would have ended up paying even more. So who's selling junk plans now?

That--there is a challenge to the Trump administration's rules that--rule that--that added consumer protections to short term plans. It's being brought by insurance companies that want to make those plans unattractive as a way to force consumers like that young man into more expensive Obamacare plans that they sell.

MANLEY: Succinctly, as a so-called Democratic strategists, it's the gift that keeps on giving. As long as this issue is hanging out there, we're going to run like hell against it.

HOAGLAND: I'm not a lawyer, I'm not a constitutional lawyer at all So I can't really on can say that if it were to be struck down, the disruptive effects it would have on the currency, because I think it's--I think the way that the case has been brought, the whole law falls. There's a lot of other stuff in there besides the insurance stuff that we'd survive. I think it would be--I think it would be a very uncomfortable situation. I kind of wish--I kind of wish the Supreme Court had taken it up before the election so we can resolve this and put it before it.

CANNON: Again, I don't think they should strike it down or at least not like this, but I do agree that it is a gift to Democrats in the election because Republicans once again have not learned how to talk about health care. If Republicans point it out that the ACA's preexisting conditions provisions are actually making the quality of coverage worse for people with a lot of expensive medical conditions and there's economic research showing this--economic research by supporters of the ACA showing this is happening, then they would get the public on their side against those provisions.

Every poll that's ever been done shows that if you talk about the costs of those provisions and not just the benefits, then not only do Republicans and independents swing against those provisions, Democrats swing against those provisions. But Republicans would have to learn how to talk about health care And Republicans don't do health care.

MCINTIRE: All right. Perhaps, that's as close to a kum ba yah moment.

MANLEY: Pretty damn close.

MCINTIRE: Does anyone have any questions for the panelists? Just wait for the microphone to come around.

QUESTION: Hi, Paul Heldman with Heldman Simpson Partners. I want to tap Bill's expertise on the budget and maybe Jim's expertise on the Senate and ask you. If the Democrats control Washington in 21, if despite your skepticism, Bill, they get a budget resolution, what can be done on healthcare via reconciliation, specifically on the public option and negotiation of drug prices as envisioned by HR 3? Are those things that can be done by reconciliation? How do you think the parliamentarian might rule on that?

HOAGLAND: First of all, right, we have to get a budget passed. If--I'll take--I'll take your position, first of all as to Democrats controlling the Senate. It depends who those Democrats are first of all, because it takes, of course, 51 votes to pass that budget resolution with the reconciliation. Reconciliation has been completely from my perspective, the years that I was involved in--in putting together reconciliation, it has been completely blown out of the water in terms of what its original purposes were.

But ostensibly the parliamentarian would still only look at those things that have a budgetary consequence. So I think that a public option would have a budgetary consequence and therefore, I think it would pass reconciliation muster. I think anything dealing with drug prices would have a budgetary consequence, therefore, it would pass reconciliation. It's all the ancillary stuff that goes along with that that could possibly be struck under what we call the Byrd Group. But that's--that's the that's the difficulty. You could end up with the budgetary impact, but you would end up with a Swiss cheese type of bill that you can't implement a lot of it.

CANNON: But wouldn't the budgetary impact of a public option be incidental to it's--

HOAGLAND: I--I--I would--It all depends on--who knows.

CANNON: But HR3 has provisions that would affect the directly regulated private prices for drugs. It's not just government spending for drugs. And so that would create reconciliation problems to. Now, I think Grassley-Wyden might--

MANLEY: A thing of the pass.

CANNON: has filed reconciliation, it wouldn't be stopped by budget rules.

MANLEY: And then, Paul, regarding the Senate, There's obviously have to be a real come to Jesus meeting between the House and Senate leaders about what exactly to focus on, you have limited bites on the apple with no inside knowledge. I assume that health care would be one track for a reconciliation bill depending on how you work it. You can get another bite of the apple--apple on another reconciliation bill and I think probably so-called infrastructure reform would be a likely topic for the second reconciliation bill.

But you know, the Green New Deal, folks are going to be coming after you with a two by four to deal with that as well. So it's going to--it's good--It would--The debates would get ugly before it'd be over.

MCINTIRE: Good question. Do you think whoever the next president is, healthcare is where they spend the bulk of their political capital in the beginning of next term?

MANLEY: Well, this are shades of 2008 when Obama--

CANNON: If it's a Republican, no.

MANLEY: What do they focus on?

HOAGLAND: Infrastructure.

CANNON: Oh, God, what do Republicans focus on? I don't know.

HOAGLAND: Taxes.

MCINTIRE: Taxes.

CANNON: Is it God or immigration?

MANLEY: Yeah Well, again, that's an interesting point because the pressure on the Democratic administration deal with immigration reform would be tremendous. You know, there's--this is really bring bad flashbacks of 2008 trying to deal with all these competing concerns. We'll have to wait. It just depends but, you know, there's only limited bites in the apple. All of these, you know, executive orders on day one are worth a piece of paper. They're written on for variety of different reasons, but I assume for a Democratic president to be at the top of the list.

MCINTIRE: All right Well, we are out of time for this morning. Thank you all for joining us.

(APPLAUSE)

RESNIK: Thank you again, Mary Ellen, and thanks again to Bill Hoagland, Jim Manley, and Michael Cannon for joining us this morning. In keeping with the theme of today's event, our second panel will discuss a wide range of topics from changes to existing laws and regulations that are needed in order to enable machine learning technologies to identify patterns and improve health care outcomes to the role of physicians in developing new apps and how the FDA is encouraging the emergence of virtual reality drugs.

The conversation will be moderated by my colleague, Gopal Ratnam, tech reporter at CQ Roll Call. This panel will feature a number of experts. Andy Fish is chief strategy officer for AdvaMed, otherwise known as the Advanced Medical Technology Association. As chief strategy officer, Andy overseas AdvaMed's global, regulatory and payment departments. He also coordinates the development, operations and policy work of AdvaMed's membership sectors, as well as AdvaMed's Center for Digital Health.

Dr. Bobby Mukkamala is board-certified otolary--otolaryngologist - I'm relatively proud of myself right there - and an elected member of the American Mental Association's board of trustees. A graduate of the University of Michigan Medical School, he is in solo private practice in Flint, Michigan.

Dr. Mukkamala, who's been active in the AMA since residency, is a past Michigan representative to the AMA young physician section, a past recipient of the AMA Foundations Excellence in Medicine Leadership Award And for the last 13 years, a member of the Michigan delegation to the AMA House of Delegates.

Joel White is executive director at the Health Innovation Alliance. The alliance is a broad-based coalition of patient groups, provider organizations, employers and payers. It supports incentives to deploy health information technology, to improve quality outcomes and patient safety at lower costs. Joel spent 12 years on Capitol Hill as professional staff, during which he helped enact nine laws, including the Medicare Modernization Act, the Deficit Reduction Act, the Tax Reform and Health Care Act, the Trade Act and the Children's Health Act. Joel was instrumental in developing the Part D e-prescribing law and the Medicare Modernization Act and in developing legislation that passed the house to promote the adoption for use of health information technology. Gopal, take it away.

RATNAM: Thank you. Thank you, Josh. Thanks--Thanks, everyone, for showing up at this conference despite the fears of the pandemic spreading all over. I have to reassure everyone that we've been very careful and not shaking hands with each other. We've all done this in a very dignified way to greet each other.

I'd like us to--we have 20 minutes, which is barely enough to scratch the surface of the things we want to talk about. But I want to talk--begin by asking the panelists to talk about what if we were in a perfect tech-enabled healthcare world, how would that look in terms of how we track and prevent the spread of this pandemic that we're in the midst of? I--and I want to ask Bobby to begin that. I mean, he's a physician. He's at the pointy end of the spear, so to speak dealing with patients so why don't you talk about that?

MUKKAMALA: Sure. Yeah, Thank you, Gopal. So it's an interesting question and an interesting time to ask that question. But as I think back of what would be different if everything was ideal and tech was perfect and did everything we needed to do, what would my office day be different and which way would it be different tomorrow?

And so I would say as it relates to this virus, if I saw a patient that came in tomorrow morning that had the sniffles and had a little bit of an ear ache and came in to see me as a routine patient because they come every six months to get the wax cleaned out of their ear, right now, I wouldn't think much of it. I'd say probably caught a cold, no reason to sort of dig into travel history and all that sort of thing.

But if, however, in this tech-enabled environment, that patient before recently visiting Italy had gone in for a routine physical exam with their primary care physicians office and that was captured in that physician's medical record, the patient about to go on a trip to Italy, then in a perfectly tech-enabled world, AI would be able to put together, here somebody that went to Italy, Italy is now under lockdown and comes back with a little bit of sniffles and happened to get noted when they came in for a routine visit to get their earwax checked. Their primary care physician has no idea that they have these symptoms. I have no idea that the patient went to Italy, but AI knows both, Right.

And so how great would it be that something pops up on my computer screen that says, based on what we've assessed, this patient is at high risk for acquisition of this virus and should be monitored or tested. Right--right now that it's impossible that that would happen unless they become symptomatic and by then, the horse has left the bar.

RATNAM: Andy so, I mean, you represent a lot of companies that are in the business of developing those technologies that connect the dots.. What would that look like if your companies could have the perfect tech-enabled world?

FISH: Well, I think setting aside that initial ramp-up here and ideally, what you have is, you know, relaxed criteria for screening so that you could actually identify all the folks that are low symptomatic rate. It would--and--and that would be the biggest possible window on this situation, because--without that wide field of--of data, you're just never going to get ahead of this, right.

I think that's what we're confronting right now, is we're playing catch up and testing has not yet caught up with reality. So in an ideal tech-enabled world, you have that test capacity and you have, you know, criteria that allow you to test anyone who is conceivably symptomatic and then through that kind of AI-enabled database, you've got a much more complete picture, right.

So I think, you know, that's--some of that is a matter of policy. It's not technology(ph) necessarily but we're, you know, we have most of those pieces right now. We have yet to have a system that really can put them together.

RATNAM: We're gonna get to the policy aspect. But Joel, I mean, you also deal with the, you know, the--the point where patients actually collect the medication, you represent pharmacies and so on. How would that look like if all of this were well connected?

WHITE: Is I think about this I mean, you've got to think about what's the ideal way to stop the spread and to treat the patient. And, you know, ideally, it's under a quarantine type situation. You want to treat people in their home. So we need the tools and the data that enable people to be treated in their home rather than having them come into a hospital facility or physician office to be tested or, you know, a lab situation to be tested or to come to a pharmacy to pick up their medication where they may be infecting additional people, right.

Like we want to be able to, first of all, have a rapid diagnostic test that can be delivered to the patient in their home with the assistance of a telemedicine or a physician or nurse to be able to walk that patient through that. We need to collect that safely, get it to a lab, have it tested, results need to be delivered real-time, probably by an app to both the provider and the patients so they know don't leave your house, right. And then once that's done, then we can figure out a better course of treatment to keep that person, you know, kind of out from the general population.

Again, the last thing we want them to do is to be kind of wandering around the metro or the subway or the pharmacy infecting other people. So those tools and I think part of what we are also seeing is that kind of the failure of government policy to enable those tools in the homebase setting and we need to change that and that's something the government can absolutely, absolutely do.

And just to underscore John's point right, we have tabletop technology to run those kinds of genetic tests looking for, you know, viruses that have a sample So, again, cost aside, if you could deploy those--those test machines actually to individual patients, consumers at home, they could, in fact, run the tests themselves.

I mean, the other point of care test technologies that an individual could run with extremely minimal instruction and training and you can get those results right. So, again, this kind of these pieces exist but again, cost aside, just the infrastructure, right, to get those tests to the people who should have them as you know, it would be a challenge.

FISH: To just add on to that, I think this is not Tomorrowland, right, this is not Technology to be developed, this is--as so many technology issues are in healthcare, this is a leadership issue. Right. We need to define how we're going to address this going forward and then actually move out and we need for that, we need the leadership at this local, state and national level.

RATNAM: I mean, one of the things that I think all three of you care a lot about is, I mean, in terms of policy and in terms of leadership is the way that information on patients that are embedded in electronic health records, they don't talk to each other. And so, therefore, physicians aren't able to find out in a large group of patients in a--in a city or in a county what's going on. And Joel, I think you pointed out that, you know, that kind of lack of interoperability and lack of information sharing also affects the entire chain of actors. So can you talk about--maybe, Joel, you can talk about this. you can start with this and talk about how, you know, what we need to do to get all the health records working and talking to each other.

We're--we're $38 billion in on for promoting interoperability program where we basically subsidize the purchase of these electronic health record systems and what we did through those systems is we digitized, we didn't transform health care. So we made the information electronic but that information is still kind of locked in These systems is not shared for treatment purposes. And, you know, just yesterday, the administration came out with a rule that basically said you can no longer block information as part of these electronic health record systems.

It took us 10 years to get that law enacted and to get those regulations out. It was a really tough fight to say you can't lock this information down anymore if--if--if you need it to treat a patient with head neck cancer. Like I can't stop you from getting that information out of the primary care EHR system.

I mean, the politics around this are brutal. It's absolutely brutal because people make a lot of money through data silos. And so by freeing up the data and hopefully, you know, we're still digging into these rules that were just released yesterday, the rules will effectuate kind of a tidal wave of data liquidity. And that data liquidity will foster the future of health care because I believe firmly that data is the future of health care, will help us cure cancer, will help us spot and prevent infectious disease and it will help us, you know, intervene at a--at a population and individual level to help lower health care costs.

RATNAM: And what about Andy, what do you think the possibility looks like?

FISH: Well, I mean, it looks like Joel kind of described it right which is freely flowing information available kind of to whomever needs it when they need it, right, and ideally powered by a number of, you know, algorithms that can make, you know, find those insights and that data to reduce the amount of time someone has to spend poring over that information.

I guess I would just underscore, I think what Joel kind of alluded to, which is I think pretty much everyone aspires to and understands the benefits of having that kind of massive data liquidity and having interoperability actually work properly. But there's a lot of factors why people hold on to data, right and some of it is--some of it is commercial value. But there's a lot of, you know, pressures to individuals to extract something from that data and publish on it and I mean, there's you know, there's a lot of sort of reasons why people hold on to what they've gathered.

So I think we need to keep having conversations around, you know, some of those underlying issues that have resisted, you know, a more interoperable environment.

MUKKAMALA: And if I could just add an observation. So I practice in Flint, Michigan. I share an office with my wife. every week, we still have to go and get refills on our fax toner because that is the primary method of communication with the offices in our area. So a patient comes to see me, they've got records at another physician's office. We have probably about 10 EHRs that are in our community that somebody--that some percentage of the physicians are using and they're not interoperable.

And so we end up faxing records and scanning them and--and then I look at them and I click off on them and I sign them. So at the same time that we find ourselves with the ability in this country to do remote robotic surgery on the battlefield, right. So that--that--that extreme evolution of healthcare and the utility of that and yet have the majority of us faxing records back and forth, I mean, I feel like I'm Fred Flintstone and George Jetson at the same time. And it's that-it's that striking on a daily basis.

FISH: Right. Quick question. When you fat--when you scan those records in, you've got an image now in your EHR that you just read the image but it's not extracting data at a field by field basis and it's still nothing you can do.

MUKKAMALA: Exactly. It's great for me, but it's not great for the next person that backs that same record to.

RATNAM: What about I mean, all three of you talked about data liquidity and now obviously what that means is that data is now available to third parties as well. So who can then develop applications of the AI and machine learning on top of that data to find patterns, to find things. What are some of the benefits and downsides of that that third party is having and how do you--quickly can you talk about how do you put some parameters and boundaries on how the data will be used and should not be used? Joel, do you want to go?

WHITE: So I, you know, I said data is part of the future of health care. I think we should make it a goal in this country that within five years we will kill the fax machine. Now, I don't want to get brutally assaulted by the fax machine industry and whatever is out there. But, you know, the platforms and the ability to manipulate data and use it so that a physician or clinician can spot a problem or challenge and then address it is huge.

And so I'll give you one example from Kaiser. They're now using the big data to figure out optimal scheduling times for patients, right. They know from social determinants of health and other data, you know when Jim is--is going to be available on a Friday because he fills up his--his boat, right, with--with--with fuel. And they know that like Jim's going to take off Friday, Saturday, Sunday to go be at the lake. So let's not schedule that Friday for an appointment with Jim as he goes through his next round of chemotherapy.

It's those kinds of interventions that will be able to figure out through big data that--that will help assist an optimal engagement with the patient. But at the other end, like we are using increasingly encounter data, clinical data and claims data as well as real-world evidence data to kind of extract and be able to pull through--through the scientific community, spotting problems and challenges for new cures.

A company out of Salt Lake City right now that is one 100 percent machine data fed and they're literally going through tissue samples and other things and running algorithms on it to figure out what is the best chance possible for curing this very specific type of rare childhood cancer. It's--it's--none of it is touching a patient, right? So data literally, we'll be curing cancer through this effort in Salt Lake City.

So the opportunities are massive. They are exciting, they are the future I think that you know, we've had a few anecdotes about, you know, Google Health is involved in this or Amazon's involved in that and look at this hospital system is using this big tech company to figure out a new system and isn't that horrible? I think what we need to recognize is those companies are the experts and they're operating within the four walls of HIPPA to assist a hospital, to either better engage with their patients or to figure out a cure for cancer.

And so that side of the story, I think, first of all, it needs to be told. Second of all, we need to recognize that when people take that data and use it inappropriately, that there ought to be an enforcement mechanism or a tool to kind of slam those guys. And I'm not sure it's a fine or a criminal penalty, I think my sense is, is that we--we ought to be looking at preventing people from operating in markets that they want to operate in if they're going to act like bad actors. But we need to have that discussion, you know, the enforcement discussion is a very important dialog. But right now, what we need to focus on is really freeing up that data and establishing the rules of the road around how it's used and how it shouldn't be used.

RATNAM: And, could you have anything too quick--to add to that?

MUKKAMALA: Yeah, I guess I would also say that I can imagine patients coming in with voluminous terabytes of data about their blood pressure readings over the course of the past six months prior to their next visit, and the quality of that data is what I want to know, right. So was that data--You know, there's a right way to monitor blood pressure and there's a wrong way to monitor blood pressure. If you download an app, get a device, put it on your arm, put your fingers on it and get data, It is not necessarily useful to the people that are managing that condition, like the primary care physician that now has to look at literally thousands of blood pressure readings to figure out, does this require an adjustment in the blood pressure medication or not?

And so, you know, we have to be careful that the acquisition of that data, the source of it, the verification of its validity, is also very robust.

RATNAM: We're going to talk about the role of physicians in developing some of these apps. But quickly, there is obviously a big national debate going on, as well as the debate at the state level on data privacy. And to your point, Joel, so third party developers getting access to patient data, there's obviously doubts and fears about de-identified data. Can you identify an individual based on that data or is all of that metadata stripped out of it?

To what extent are states and Congress dealing with healthcare-related data in the larger context of consumer privacy? I know both Andy and you have some thoughts on that.

WHITE: So what are the first laws I worked on when I went to work in Congress Was HIPPA and that law was created 10 years before the first iPhone came out. It was a very different time, but it is the main law that is governing privacy as it relates to health care data. It is woefully out of date, it needs to be modernized because we never envisioned when we created that law, these different platforms and the different types of data and the different uses for the data, the applications.

Second thing we never envisioned was the general societal and cultural changes that have evolved over time with respect to how data is out there, right. Kind of everyone in this room would say, I'm on Facebook, I'm putting my data out there, that's okay. But I also feel powerless to not walk around life without my cell phone, right. And how much data is being sucked through this, right and what am I trading off in terms of privacy.

So a lot of these privacy laws that are--that are coming up right now literally is an effort to modernize and fill in the gaps where HIPPA no longer is adequate. But it's also a response to people feeling kind of powerless and that--and that, you know, there needs to be a new framework.

And so states are stepping up, but really, what we need to recognize that data is kind of a global commodity or asset right now. It's not like a state by state. If we don't have a nationwide uniform structure to govern data and how it's used in health care, we will lose the applications that will get us to cures us for cancer or to spot pandemics or to treat patients in the most appropriate cost-effective way.

RATNAM: So Andy, so the--some of--some of the companies that are part of your group, I mean, they depend on this data and so obviously to develop apps and technologies based off of that. To what extent are, you know, the absence of these national (INAUDIBLE) data privacy laws hindering that process?

FISH: Well, I would say right now status quo is not necessarily a challenge--the challenge. The concern is that with multiple state laws that have differing requirements and are inconsistent with HIPPA and other federal privacy frameworks around research subjects and so forth, you'll end up with a--with a really tough mess.

Our concern primarily is that you'll have general privacy restrictions put in place that affect health care, but aren't designed for health care and health care is a much more complex situation I think sort of this irony of we need to do much more with data, the promise that we can deliver better health care more efficiently and do a better job is--is there but at the same time, we need to make sure we're doing more for privacy, partly just to make sure that consumers and patients feel comfortable with the data sharing that they may be consenting to, right.

So we've been seeing that California Consumer Privacy Act as a general law affecting health care but the California legislature saw it fit to exempt certain major areas of health care data from it, recognizing that HIPPA's covering those areas, right. So we're hoping we're hopeful that the states and Washington State is sort of following this model as well, will not touch certain major areas of health care data when they enact broad privacy laws.

At the same time, of course, we are working with Congress and we do actually endorse having a national privacy framework. It has to take health care into specific special account or we're going to have--we're gonna--we're gonna screw up the promise of health care data.

RATNAM: And we have a four and a half minutes or we're going to talk about some of the most exciting tech in this four and a half minutes. So FDA, Bobby, we talked about this. So there's just a whole variety of apps that deal with health, health care and collecting data directly to consumers. And you had some concerns about how as physicians you don't have a role in the development of these apps and you would like, you know, a greater involvement in how tech companies develop these apps. Talk about that.

MUKKAMALA: Yeah, absolutely. I mean, there's--we don't want to fall into the trap of just collecting again, volumes of data. Not all data is going to be useful data. And so, I would much rather be on the front end, sort of looking at what the technology is doing as far as creation of that data, make sure that it's valid and clinically useful. Then on the back end, going through terabytes of data, trying to figure out which ones are useful clinically or not, right. And so we don't want to--like the EHR is that train left the station and now we're working on interoperability.

I don't want this app based data production. I don't want that train to leave the station and then figure out which of the apps are actually useful data or not. So why not on the front end, during the creation phase, during the vetting of that, make sure that it's actually going to produce something that's useful to help us take care of those patients.

RATNAM: So you are I mean, your association is working with tech developers to kind of help them understand how as a physician, you would view the data and so on.

MUKKAMALA: Yeah So I mean, the American Medical Association is very much out there wanting to be a resource in the development of these products so that we don't get caught in the same way that we were with EHRs, you know, be there on the creation side instead of being consulted to help fix it and make it what we want after it's already out there.

RATNAM: Anything you want to add?

FISH: Yeah, I would--I would just say, first of all, let's just says pause for a moment and think about what we mean when we say digital health, right. So we take this broad view that digital health is as horizontal, increasingly embedded across technology, Healthcare, med--medical technology. It's not--it's not a vertical, certainly not a vertical anymore, right.

So you have this universe of data-generating technologies which can be distributed outside of intensive health care settings, right all the way to someone in their home, near-patient data collection, wearables, ingestibles, implantable, etc, right. So this expanding ability to create--to generate new data, either more of traditional data or novel data, right, continuous monitoring data gives you data points you've never seen before, right.

Instead of going in every year for your cholesterol check, now you can see how your cholesterol varies over the course of a day and we all have a much deeper insight into what cholesterol means in terms of a health care measurement, right. So that's that proliferation of data through these data-generating technologies and then you have all the passing of data you can do to find actionable insights. And then you have data-driven technologies as well, right.

So now, we'd like to talk about continuous glucose meters and the closed-loop systems that we now have. So you can drive insulin injections automatically based on, you know, where your glucose is at any given time. That's a tremendous advance for patients, right. We're gonna see more and more of these remote and automated interventions that can be driven by these data loops, right. And that frees up health care providers to spend more time doing what people should be doing and less time trying to figure out, you know, all the other stuff in diagnosis.

So the range of applications that are data-driven is just, you know, is just incredible. I would say one of the most interesting advances among this because you ask about sort of where is cutting edge tech is digital therapeutics. Digital therapeutics are in some ways kind of the most data, pure application, if you will, because the only device involved, the only technology involved is the platform on which the app runs. But these are apps--these are essentially apps that are collecting patient information and engaging with the patient and basically behavior modification.

So we've seen therapy--digital therapeutics go through and get FDA approval for indications that previously are only biopharmaceutical indications, depression really, for example, pain--pain relief, opioid alternatives that are getting clinical indications, claims, FDA approved, driven solely as apps that engage with patients, collect information and give feedback to patients in coaching and so forth. And that's a really interesting advance and we're going to see that just continue to take off.

RATNAM: In fact, I saw Mickey Hart, the drummer, kind of talk about that. I think he's involved in one of these trials where there is a virtual reality headset for people with certain mental illnesses and Parkinson's kind of thing, then that kind of sets them through this process of movement. That is one of the therapeutic apps that apparently is being developed.

So are we going to see the future of medicine where you talked about a series of things, ingestible? I mean, a lot of the--even the therapy being driven by apps. Is that the future? I mean, quickly, just maybe 10 seconds each.

MUKKAMALA: And I think that it will add value, It will give me one more tool to help take care of my patient. I don't think that it's going to transform the way we take care of patients but in the same way that, you know, we used to get X-rays of the sinuses and now we get CAT scans of the sinuses, we get more detail. In the same way, what we used to acquire by having a patient come into the office, now that data gets acquired and we have that to use to interpret and take care of that patient.

WHITE: Yeah, I think we've constructed a world in the physician office. I wouldn't call it artificial intelligence, I call it artificial communication where the physician is spending 40 percent of their time doing data entry and not working and looking at the patient and doing things of that nature. So, you know, I--I firmly believe that you know, in the real world we use this to communicate with people, we'll do it in the physician office very quickly to the extent that digital apps and digital tools become empowered by this data liquidity future.

FISH: I would say, you know, that sort of (INAUDIBLE) says we underestimate or we overestimate the practice of making the short term and underestimate the progress we're making the long term. So I think these collection of technologies and data is fundamentally going to transform how we provide care to people, both health care and sick care, but over what timeframe is the question.

Right. Healthcare is notoriously slow to adopt tools And I think one of the huge challenges for our industry and anyone who's coming forward and proposing solutions is you have to figure out how to make--how to reduce friction in a system. You can't be adding friction. You can't add time to a clinician's, you know, day. You can't make it harder for someone to adopt these tools. They have to fade into the background, they have to be supportive and they have to augment what people are--what people are doing in the system and that's a lot harder than it sounds. People make that mistake a lot.

RATNAM: Well, we're unfortunately out of time and I was hoping we could have at least a couple minutes for audience to ask questions. But if anyone has a pressing question and a quick one, maybe we can take one. Oh, I guess, there aren't any. Well, we didn't talk about a lot and hopefully, we'll have more opportunities to talk--to talk about that. I mean, this basically, I mean, I've been writing about cyber security in the context of health care as well and all of the data in the hands of so many people also means that the bad guys are looking to exploit the data and so that creates a whole new area of vulnerability as well and so hopefully we'll have a chance to talk about that in future session. Thanks for coming. Thanks.

RESNIK: Thank you Gopal, and thanks again to Andy Fish, Dr. Mukkamala, and Joel White for their fascinating discussion on Medtech. Rounding out today's event--rounding out today's event, I'd like to welcome our second congressional keynote, Congressman Larry Bucshon. Since coming to Congress, Dr. Bucshon has been a champion for advancing patient-centered health care reforms that will give patients and their doctors the freedom to make their own health care decisions.

He also has been a leader in the fight to end the opioid epidemic, having been one of eight lawmakers from around the nation recognized by the coalition to stop opioid overdose in 2016 for his work on the issue. Before taking office, Congressman Bucshon was a practicing physician insurgence specializing in cardiothoracic surgery and served as chief of cardiothoracic surgery and medical director of the Open Heart Recovery Intensive Care Unit at St Mary's Hospital.

Interviewing Congressman Bucshon is CQ Roll Call's health editor, Rebecca Adams. Rebecca, over to you.

ADAMS: Thanks to everyone for joining us. so--

BUCSHON: Good morning, everyone. (INAUDIBLE) There we go.

ADAMS: There we go.

BUCSHON: All right.

ADAMS: All right. Thank you so much for coming in.

BUCSHON: You're welcome. You're welcome.

ADAMS: COVID-19 is the big issue of the day.

BUCSHON: What's that. I'm just kidding. I know what it is. I'm kidding

ADAMS: Anyone worried about that?

BUCSHON: Yeah.

ADAMS: Donna Shalala earlier this morning talked about some of the things that might be considered going forward. Obviously, you all last week dealt with the $8.3 billion law. What do you think the next steps are? She talked about unemployment, insurance and trying to cover costs for testing and that sort of thing.

BUCSHON: I--I didn't hear what her comments were but all those type of things are on the table. One of the things we did do in what the 8.3 billion is there was--part of that was some relief for small businesses, about $20 million for the Small Business Administration to help small businesses get through this. But we'll see, there's ongoing discussions about whether there should be a fiscal type stimulus for industries like the airline industry or the other things related to travel, you know, where their stock prices have really dipped.

But I think that's up in the air. I think the bar--the bottom line is, is I think the money that we gave last week is going to be well-spent. Part of that is to help develop vaccines. So for this problem and also medical therapy, the current antivirals that we have, we don't know if they're effective or not, they may or may not be.

So in the vein of what Donna said about making sure that the vaccines are available low cost or no cost, right, I think help with putting some research money in from the federal government to help the development of that will--will really dramatically help that. And also, a couple of large insurance plans this week announced that they would be covering these without co-pays and for free.

So I think it will be--I think we'll be fine there. I do think if, you know, we're a ways away from a vaccine, we're--some are getting ready to go into human testing. But if you listen to the people from the CDC and the private sector companies, you maybe a year away, maybe 18 months before you know for sure whether these will be effective. But I agree that we have to make them cost free or affordable. And I think a combination the government and the private sector will make that happen. I really do.

ADAMS: What do you think the timetable would be? We do have a May deadline for other health care legislation. Do you think that Congress will be acting more quickly than that to try to take care of some of these issues?

BUCSHON: Yeah, I mean, the honest answer, it's above my pay grade. I mean, I don't know. You know, there's the leadership folks have been talking about a variety of different things. You know, the hope is and again, I want to make clear these are my opinions and not the opinion of the administration or the CDC or the FDA. I want to make that clear to everyone that this will kind of slowly drift away like--like the flu season does, right. But the answer is we don't know. We don't know the epidemiology of this so we don't know for sure.

So I think people are talk, you know, people--there's a--a little bit of a wait and see right now. People are talking about, you know, tax breaks for certain industries or temporary low-interest loans and other ways to backup industries that are struggling because of this. But what the final answer will be, I don't know.

ADAMS: What would you say about the fact that we now have members of Congress who are self-quarantining? Do you think that there is the chance for an extended recess?

BUCSHON: No, I don't. I mean, I think we've talked about that and I can just speak for the Republican Conference and I haven't talked to my Democrat friends. Yet Maybe Donna said some about that but I think there's a pretty much a consensus on the Hill is--is that would set a bad precedent for the Congress to just recess and all go home because I think it would be--personally, I think I'd be the top story in the entire world, you know, I mean, the London paper, you know, Congress goes home.

You know, and it--and the reason I say that is because I think it would--it--it--it the--you know, the more the impression than the real--reality of what that would do to the markets, to people's confidence in the federal government and governments around the world to deal with this on a medical basis. So I don't think. I think, you know, I mean and I don't--you know, I--I don't know the individual situation from each member that has decided to self-quarantine but I do know that the advice from the attending physician office which is at the capital that advises us individually on health care-related issues recommended that the--they didn't need to do that. Based on their exposure that they had, that the exposure was really minimal.

Some had shooken--shaken hands with somebody who had shaken hands with somebody, shaking hands with somebody at CPAC that had--that tested positive. But I don't know their individual situations but I--I think that I mean, there's a little bit of optics there. I mean, I don't want to say there's little bit politics there, but--but I think there is some advice that they didn't--that--that wasn't necessarily--necessary.

Now, I mean, I understand where certain people who are going to have direct contact with the president or the vice president or other high-level people in the near future are concerned about that. So I understand that but I don't think--I don't think it's necessary.

ADAMS: What do you think about the messaging that came out of the White House there? It's sometimes been some inconsistent messaging. I mean, I think it--and I've talked about this with a number of people. I think the--the inconsistency is because we just don't know the answers and people I mean, it's hard to, you know, as a health care provider, I think one of the things that's difficult for to understand sometimes is health care providers don't always know the answer to the question you're asking.

I mean, in this particular case, it's a novel virus. We don't know the epidemiology of it. We don't know, for example, you know, we think it may be a little more contagious than the regular flu, but we don't know. We think there may be a slightly higher mortality rate, but we're basing that off Chinese data, just hospitalized patients. So we don't know. I mean, Dr. Fauci has said, has recently, that--they--they believe this can be less than 1 percent. The regular flu is .01 percent or something like that.

But right now, for example, in China, if you're over 80 years old and you have it, the mortality rates is 15 percent roughly. So we--we don't know. That's why I think you see initially I think you saw some inconsistent messaging because the agencies--different agencies, there wasn't a, you know, a quick coordination on--on the message and that created a little confusion. But I think--I think that's turned around somewhat.

But again, people don't know and sometimes people give their opinions when they--when they probably shouldn't. If they don't know the data, all of us, whether members of Congress, administration people, when you don't know because people really want us to give them answers But we just don't--don't know. Even the health care professionals don't know the answer. And that creates uncertainty and it creates fear.

I mean, medicine is not an exact science, right. It's an art and I found I practice heart surgery for 15 years and people want you to be able to tell them, hey, this is what's gonna happen. And most of the time, you can but not all the time because there's all kinds of factors that come into play that you don't expect and that might change the dynamics of whatever subject. And this is--this is a great example of that, right.

And so I think--I think once the White House, you know, got a more cohesive team approach with a--with a defined leader of that, I think it improved. But once you had individual agencies talking without a more cohesive message, it was--it was somewhat confusing.

ADAMS: So I do want to give time to the audience to ask a question to you but I need to ask you about surprise billing. Why do you think it's going to happen with that? there's been some sticking points over arbitration and other things?

BUCSHON: Yeah. I've been involved in that. I'm on the Energy and Commerce Committee and we passed legislation unanimously out of committee, we're on a voice vote. As really a benchmark, just to put you know, just put a marker out there knowing that we have a long way to go. Okay. And I think, first of all, you know, we have to define the problem. I think most people in a room know what surprise billing is, but it's basically just for discussion sake. It's I'll give you what--I mean--It's--if you go to a hospital, it's in-network, your doctors in network. But it turns out one of the providers that read your pathology slider looked at your x ray, turns out they were not in your insurance network, right.

And so you didn't know that and so months later, you get a bill for the radiologist to read your X-ray and you're like, what's this? Because your insurance denied payment, right, because it was out of network. So that's a surprise bill. One in five Americans get a surprise Bill. We had testimony, one young lady who heard her husband had a child had to go to the neonatal intensive care unit. In an in-network hospital, turns out the NICU--the NICU was a contract--was a contractor, wasn't actually part of the hospital, the hospital had contracted out that service out of network. All of a sudden, they get a bill for 50 grand. You know, that's--that's a pretty substantial surprise bill
