So I think there's a couple of things. Some of the states are addressing it And I want to make it clear that whatever we do at the federal level, we've decided not to be preemptive. And the reason is, is because some states have addressed this and I firmly believe in states' ability to address these things at the state level, insurance coverage is historically been a state issue. So I want to make that clear. So California has addressed it, Texas, New York. I personally think the New York model is more close to what we're gravitating towards at the federal level with some nuance differences.

It is controversial, It is difficult to get consensus. But I think--I think you'll see something similar but different or nothing. I doubt if you'll find anything in between. I mean, the initial approach was just a benchmark payment that you probably know, that came out of--that was the NC bill, that was the Senate health bill.

Most of us believe that would be a reimbursement race to the bottom for providers and was an unbalanced approach just to set a federal benchmark as price-fixing and that alone was not palatable to anyone really on both sides. And I don't know what Secretary Shalala said, but I think she's kind of in that camp.

ADAMS: Yes, it's much more in favor of the ways and means approach.

BUCSHON: Yeah. And the ways and means, the main ways and means situation has a, you know, has a fair market value, but then has an arbitration part of it. I think you'll--you'll see, like I said, somewhere in the middle there but--but more towards an approach, more typical, like to New York, which has arbitration in there versus California, which doesn't. But we got a ways to go, and I think we are--the bottom line is all of us want to make sure it's balanced. We don't--I mean, I do--I'll just speak for myself.

I don't want--I don't want, number one, that the citizens are taken out of this equation, that nobody gets a bill that's a surprise bill Now, if you go to a visit, if you go to a physician you know is out of network. That's not a surprise bill. This is not going to authorize you to go to a doctor that you know is out of network. You're going to--you're going to be stuck with that bill.

Again, that's--that's important for people to understand. It doesn't sol--it's not gonna fix that. But we don't want people to have to get these bills. And I think we're all trying to solve that problem in a way that doesn't advantage the plans, doesn't advantage the providers and it is a balanced approach that everybody can live with and that's a hard place to get to.

ADAMS: So medical providers are probably happy in the shift that's happening but I wonder if you think that you'll just run out of time, you won't have time to get this done this year. Yeah, I think more than that, not necessarily time. I don't think time's a factor. I think we could accomplish it. I think it depends on, you know, whether or not people have the political will to do it.

And the reason is, is because it's--it's controversial, number one. And if anybody's lives in DC, they see the TV ads on both sides of this, right. And now you have conservative groups and liberal groups coming out with this view and that view. And so at some point, congress, you know, I hate to say it congress will go and they'll punt. And that would be the--I don't think time's the factor. I think whether or not we have the political will to do it, in my view.

ADAMS: Okay, so let's take it to the audience. I see a hand back there.

QUESTION: Good morning, Thanks for being here. I am Julie (INAUDIBLE) with Prime Therapeutics. In the Senate HELP Committee bill which addresses the other side of the Capitol but they did reach a compromise with ANC in early December. There was a lot more than just surprise billing in that package and many of us are following these other provisions. Can you put on your prognosticator and say what you think might travel with something on COVID-19 and surprise billing because many of these other provisions are controversial?

BUCSHON: Yes, surprise billing, a lot of the legislation, you know, has been scored by the CBO to save money anywhere from 18 to $25 billion, roughly somewhere in that ballpark. And as anybody follows, this town knows if there's money out there, you know, people go on oh, there's money. What are we going to do with it, right? Health care extenders--the health care extenders package that was--is--and I don't have a list of those things in front me, but one of the big ones is like, you know, federally qualified health care centers, right which I have them in my district, we have them all over the country, I support them. They need a reauthorization in funding, right.

Those type of things I think it's very likely to be in a surprise Medical billing legislation, healthcare-related things. COVID-19, I don't see as much cause that's more of an acute problem. I see more. Again, I don't have the list in front of me, but there's--there's a laundry list of healthcare-related things like community, you know, federally qualified health care centers that need to be reauthorized.

I think it's likely that if a surprise billing medical bill legislation comes if those will be in there and the say--the CBO score savings will be used to--to fund those. I mean, that's my best guess.

ADAMS: One can argue with COVID-19 that the health centers might need more funding.

BUCSHON: And they might, yeah. yeah, right. So in the savings and the surprise medical bill may not be enough, right. So I just don't know.

ADAMS: Do we have another question? Here we go.

QUESTION: Hi, my name's Rachel. I'm finishing up my anesthesia residency in Miami right now. Something we're concerned about, especially with the Energy and Commerce bills, the median and network as insurance companies are becoming aware that legislation might come up with the median and network especially, they've been reducing our rates first up, 30 percent, 40 percent and then just forcing out a network because they're giving us contracts that are 60 percent lower than what we were being reimbursed. And they're hoping that by lowering these rates, the median network will be artificially lowered as well. And I'm wondering if it's something you guys are looking at.

BUCSHON: So here's the factor and there's a couple of things. I mean, it's complicated, but that's why the NC bills set--they start at 2019--2019 rates and then increase that with an inflation area an inflator to try to prevent that from happening. But I think and I don't know the exact numbers, but, for example, California that just put a benchmark bill and that's exactly what's happening, right, there--you're going to see that people getting--dropping people from networks and offering lower contracts.

So in my view, an independent dispute resolution process, whatever that looks like, if you don't have that in some form, you will absolutely get--get this for sure. The ways and means legislation is different but in--at the end of the day, when you look at the IDR process or the arbitration process, it says that the arbiter can consider meeting in-network rate as in statute in the law. And so the CBO has said it will gravitate most of the arbitration would pass--probably gravitate towards that rate.

So it's really difficult--It's really a difficult situation to try to solve. That's why I say I'm not sure whether we'll have the political will to do it, because honestly, there's no right answer because, you know, the best guess we can have is, well, what happened--what's happened in New York in four years. About half the arbitration is gone for the provider, half for the plan and we haven't seen this mass exodus of people being kicked out of their--their networks, right? That's best guess based on that history.

But other states that have addressed this, there's not a long enough time period to really see what's the long-term result. But I'm very concerned about that exact problem, right, and I've mentioned this to the insurance plans. You know, and you know, I think it's a--it's a something we're going to try to prevent and that's one of the things we--we know that's happening and we've got to do-- For example, the way it--Ways and Means Bill, again and I think there's a lot of good things in both. I'm not trying to be critical of ways and means just because I'm on NC, although that's what the NC members do sometimes. I'm not, because I think there's a lot of good things in both--both of those.

They sound like a three--a five-year reset, for example. At the first time, it'd be a three year reset and that's exactly what will happen if you do that. In three years, everybody will be kicked out of their networks and there'll be a--there'll be lower or lower in-network rate so that the benchmark--so that the median and network drops. And so my concern about having--not having an inflator on there, that happens based on a certain plan year, which would be in ANC 19, but having a reset would--would cause more problems like that. But the hon--the honest answer is we don't know. So we're--we're still working on it.

ADAMS: All right, well, that's all the time that we have today. Thank you so much.

BUCSHON: Oh, you're welcome. Thank you.

RESNIK: Thank you to Congressman Bucshon and Rebecca for that insightful discussion. I want to thank my colleagues, all our speakers, our sponsors, Better Medicare Alliance, DentaQuest and the Alzheimer's Association and most importantly, you, our audience for joining us this morning. As a reminder, if you missed any portion of the program, you can watch the video on rollcall.com. Enjoy the rest of your day. Stay healthy and we hope to see you at our next event.

urn:contentItem:5YV3-PN81-F15W-H0MR-00000-00FiscalNote - CQ Roll Call Hold Webinar on Healthcare Policy2020-04-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:13ZLexisNexisFiscalNote - CQ Roll Call Hold Webinar on Healthcare Policy

Fiscalnote - Cq Roll Call Hold Webinar On Healthcare Policy

April 30, 2020 11:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

FAMILIES U.S.A. SENIOR POLICY DIRECTOR ELIOT FISHMAN

AMERICAN ACADEMY OF FAMILY PHYSICIANS ADVOCACY, PRACTICE ADVANCEMENT AND POLICY SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT SHAWN MARTIN

BIOTECHNOLOGY INNOVATION ORGANIZATION LAW AND PUBLIC POLICY DIVISION PRESIDENT OF ADVOCACY TOM DILENGE

CQ ROLL CALL HEALTHCARE EDITOR REBECCA ADAMS

CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL ASSOCIATION VICE PRESIDENT OF PUBLIC POLICY JIM KAUFMAN

[*]ADAMS: Hello, everyone, on today's webinar, where we will be discussing healthcare policy and the road to recovery.

My name is Rebecca Adams and I'm the healthcare editor at CQ Roll Call, part of FiscalNote. Both CQ Roll Call and FiscalNote are actively monitoring the coronavirus outbreak and the effect it's having on our politics and policy environment.

You can check out our up-to-date and comprehensive information on the virus and how the U.S. is responding at coronavirus@fiscalnote.com One thing I should mention is we've made a lot of our coverage available here, free of charge, to help you navigate through this crisis.

You can also sign up for our daily newsletter and learn more about how FiscalNote can help your organization monitor the policies and politics around COVID-19.

I've got just a few housekeeping items, before we start. You'll see a Q&A box and a chat box on your screen. You can use those to submit questions, during the webinar. Feel free to submit your questions, at any time, and we'll try to get to everyone.

Also, after this webinar is done, we'll send out a recording.

Everyone should be muted on entry but, if you're not, except for us, panelists, please go ahead and make sure your microphone is on mute.

Today, I'm joined by four health policy experts, who will help guide the conversation and will be able to answer your questions.

Eliot Fishman is Senior Director of Policy for Families USA. Eliot leads Families USA's policy analysis and advocacy agenda development at the state and federal levels, working with the policy department and other members of senior leadership.

Jim Kaufman is Vice President of Public Policy for the Children's Hospital Association, representing 220 hospital organizations and pediatric programs, dedicated to improving child health through innovation in care, education and research.

Tom DiLenge is President of Biotechnology Innovation Organization's Advocacy, Law and Public Policy Division. Before that, Tom served as BIO's General Counsel and Head of Public Policy.

Shawn Martin is Senior Vice President for Advocacy, Practice Advancement and Policy at the American Academy of Family Physicians. In this role, he directs legislative and private sector advocacy on issues, such as physician payment and medical liability reform.

Thanks so much for joining us. I'd like to kick us off by telling you about the legislation that Congress has already enacted to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as upcoming legislative and regulatory development.

So, let's talk first, about the $100 billion that was in the CARES Act for medical providers. Jim, I know that Children's Hospital has had some concerns about the first $30 billion in funding that was distributed, based on Medicare reimbursement.

HHS Secretary, Alex Azar, then announced his additional information about the second round of funding in that $100 billion. So, what's your take on the way funding has been allocated, so far, and have your hospitals seen any problems in receiving their allotment? And what are you hearing about how the funding allocations that haven't been announced, yet, will be distributed?

KAUFMAN: Rebecca, that's some great questions. First of all, we're very grateful that HHS, supported by congressional advocates, broadened the relief efforts in the second round of funding to recognize more of the financial impact of the COVID-19 surge response on all providers.

As you noted, that first round of funding went strictly to Medicare providers, based on their fee-for-service revenues. And we understand that because it was needed to be done quickly and get the funds out, as fast as possible.

However, you know, children's hospitals, pediatricians, family docs, generally, don't treat Medicare patients. So, we were pretty much excluded from any financial relief, even though that we were seeing significant financial losses, due to deferred procedures, increased cost for PPE and, you know, other efforts to deal with the surge capacity.

The one thing people don't realize is a lot of children's hospitals, you know, we are some of the largest Medicaid providers in the country, with more than 50 percent of our patient environment is being on Medicaid. So, that second round of funding focusing when total patient revenue was greatly, you know, greatly helpful in getting some dollars to the children's hospitals and other providers.

However, it didn't get to everybody, I should note. I mean, pediatricians are a great example. They are not serving anybody, and I've heard they're not receiving any support, from the second round of funding. So, we really look forward to HHS working with others to make sure additional funds go to pediatricians, as well.

And I should also note, for children's hospitals and others, the money that we received will be helpful in avoiding or delaying layoffs, or elimination of services. It doesn't close the gap.

We're still looking at more than a billion-dollar losses, a month, and we're only about 2 percent of the hospital industry. And our losses are, actually, increasing. When the crisis first hit, we saw revenue losses of 20 percent to 30 percent. We're now looking at revenue losses of 50 percent to 60 percent. So, while we're grateful for the funding that has been received, we still need more.

And I have heard one or two hospitals that are having some technical problems getting funds. We're trying to figure out what's going on in that space. So, while we're grateful, we're not done yet, on these efforts.

The other funding that we heard on going out, through the remaining of the $100 billion, is going to be going to hotspots, you know, helping deal with the uninsured and some other efforts, like D&E and health service. But that still leaves a lot of dollars that are being allocated. We look forward to working with HHS to continue to ensure that hospitals, pediatricians and other providers contain and receive support, especially, as states are now starting to talk about budgetary cuts, which means Medicaid cuts, which is going to directly impact children's hospitals, pediatricians and others.

So, Rebecca, hopefully, that helps clarify a little bit of how the dollars have gone out, so far.

ADAMS: That's very interesting. Thank you very much. Eliot, do you want to jump in here and share your thoughts about the distribution of money?

FISHMAN: I certainly agree that the second round of funding was distributed somewhat more broadly. But those gaps are pretty severe. And I would highlight, in particular, the lack of allocation for Medicaid providers.

National Association of Medicaid Directors sent a letter, a couple of days ago, to Secretary Azar, Secretary of Health and Human Services, that's obviously, a bipartisan organization, represents all the Medicaid directors. That letter was signed by Medicaid directors and two Republican gubernatorial administrations in Florida and Arizona.

And what that letter points out is that, leaving out Medicaid, in addition to services like children's hospitals and pediatricians that see a lot of Medicaid, there are swaths of our healthcare system in which you have providers who take almost only Medicaid to before, serve people, without insurance at all.

For example, the behavioral health sector is really segmented by payer, so that there are lots of important mental health and substance use providers who are almost, exclusively, dependent on Medicaid funding. Same for long-term home and community-based services that you have providers who, basically, are exclusively, Medicaid providers. And if you don't start to allocate funds, based on Medicaid, they are dealing with all of the revenue losses, associated with social distancing and lockdowns, without any support and are really in grave danger.

So, that is, potentially, something that can be resolved with future allocations. That is what the Medicaid directors asked for.

Something else that some states have proposed is to use emergency Medicaid waiver authority to direct some payments to those Medicaid providers. And that is another possibility. And maybe something because it involves state flexibility, that the Trump administration is more amenable to. So, that's something we're keeping our eye on, as well.

ADAMS: All right, that's very helpful. Shawn, let me bring you in. What's your perspective?

MARTIN: Hold on, I'm kind of--I think I'm muted.

ADAMS: We can hear you, Shawn.

MARTIN: I agree with the comments that have been made. I think the initial outlay of cash from HHS was more focused on seed than, probably, on comprehensiveness. I think there was a desire to just get cash into the hands of physicians and hospitals, across the country.

I would echo the concerns about Medicaid, particularly, in certain regions and states. Medicaid is a far more dominant payer in the, you know, coverage, a payer in the healthcare system, than Medicare. I also think it is a place where maybe the most vulnerable in the population have their healthcare coverage through Medicaid and those positions that provide services to that patient population placed in severe downward economic pressure and, potentially, closing.

I think--I think the thing we need to be mindful of that we're, you know, constantly working is being appreciative of the efforts today, while also being really forceful, if you will, about the need for how much more needs to be done.

We know that about 80 percent of our family physician practices report that they are within two full weeks of sustainability issues. And this is just going to continue for months in the, kind of, aimed more toward practice setting.

So, really appreciate what Congress and the administration have done today, to just continue to point out that much more needs to be done.

ADAMS: So, Shawn, let me say on that point of what more needs to be done. And that's still that Congress may consider to be able to assist COVID-19 response package may be more difficult to negotiate.

So, what are you pushing for Congress to include in this bill and what do you think will come out of these discussions? Look into your crystal ball a little bit.

MARTIN: Yeah, I think Congress is looking in the next package at some economic stability type provision. So, you know, kind of what post paycheck protection program to kind of create some economic stability of like small businesses. And I think healthcare will be part of that, physician practices.

So, we're really talking to a little about two things. One is continuing to provide financial assistance in the form of cash flow to physician practices and hospitals and long-term care. The healthcare system, you know, just broadly just needs massive amounts of cash flow to sustain it.

And then, the second piece is really looking at a kind of create a payment model--sorry--how can we create a payment model to put us on a better trajectory to a better playing field in the future, so that we can have future capable discussions healthcare we don't have as a survey that results decreasing revenue that happened in our previous system.

So, those are the two approaches they're taking off on.

ADAMS: Okay. I'd like to bring in Tom. Can you talk about your current needs for the next round of legislation?

DILENGE: Sure, thank you, Rebecca, and thank you to FiscalNote and CQ Healthcare for doing this forum, today. I hope all of you and all your listeners are doing well and staying safe.

BIO represents, mostly, startup R&D intensive companies that rely heavily on the private market.

So, picking up on Shawn's comments around kind of like market liquidity, economic stability, we represent really hundreds and hundreds of these small startup companies. A lot of them are actually working on COVID related treatments and vaccines, which I'm sure we'll talk about later.

And a lot of these companies are having trouble raising money in this market environment, as you can imagine. These companies live, you know, day to day, burning huge amounts of capital. They do not have product revenues, yet. These are pre-revenue companies.

And so, they really rely on liquid markets that where money is flowing to keep and sustain all of these R&D programs that are so critical to COVID and non-COVID serious diseases.

So, we're going to be pushing for tax and regulatory reforms that can free up capital for these companies. This is a critical issue. The PPP belongs helped in the first round. But those were really geared more toward the kind of small mom and pop kind of retail establishments. Our companies are going to be facing longer term economic stability issues, as we go, unfortunately, I think into a recession and the capital markets freeze up a bit.

So, we need to be helping these companies spend less of their money on regulations that aren't necessary and we also have to let them keep more of their--more of the money that they have, rather than taxing it in certain ways that the tax code does, right now, which are really unfortunate for our smaller companies.

So, we're going to be looking at those kinds of reforms, as we move into the next package.

ADAMS: All right. And let me add in Eliot and then, we'll go to Jim because I'd like to hear everybody's priorities for the next bill. So, Eliot, why don't you jump in.

FISHMAN: Sure. So, our first priority has to be getting health insurance to the, as many of the tens of millions of people who are losing employer coverage on a day-to-day basis, as we can, right.

We just saw, earlier this morning, another several million people file for new unemployment insurance claims. And a significant number of those people are losing employer coverage.

We, building on the Democrats, who's all for the third COVID package, or the CARES Act proposal that the Democrats put forward in the House, are looking at using both subsidies for COBRA coverage that is to maintain employer coverage, during a period of unemployment, enhanced subsidies for nongroup coverage on the marketplace and more flexibility for states to extend Medicaid for COVID treatment for the uninsured.

Right now, you can add a state option with 100 percent federal funding coverage, as COVID screening and testing. That ought to be extended to cover COVID treatment, as well.

This is really like an all of the above approach, right. So, continuing employer coverage, market place coverage, Medicaid coverage. And that's not an accident if, historically, it has been very hard to leave people who are losing a job to available health insurance coverage, even when there have been federal efforts to subsidize that coverage in a financial crisis.

It's just--it's a time when people are dealing with a lot. We've seen that just filing for unemployment insurance, given just the huge tsunami of unemployment insurance applications is a lot for people to work through. We need to make it as easy as possible and we need to fund enrollment assistance, which is something that was funded, under the Affordable Care Act. Trump administration has cut that way back. It's desperately needed now, if we are going to keep people insured.

And we need to think about insurance as a part of pandemic response. We just heard as Families USA, my organization, we were on the phone with a congressional office from New Jersey on Tuesday. And heard from them that people are in the community in New Jersey, who are un insured, are not going to get tested, even as testing finally is becoming available, and New Jersey's a very hard-hit state. It desperately needs people to get tested because they have heard that you need to bring your insurance card and they are uninsured and they are worried about what the financial implications will be if now, they have no unemployment income, they're limited to, you know, a modest, if supplemented unemployment insurance and they can't deal with a bill for healthcare.

Obviously, we have decades of experience that people don't get healthcare, if they don't have health insurance. And this is a time when we need people not having financial barriers to getting tested or, potentially, getting treated, if they are symptomatic.

Second thing that we see as a major priority is aid to states, preferably, via enhancement to the federal matching person mentioned for Medicaid that targets it to the parts of the state that most need support.

And I just note, that's also a pandemic response. So, it's not just an economic issue. But for example, the state of Minnesota reported, over the weekend, as they're getting asked about staffing up, to do testing and quarantining and contact tracing. Their Department of Public Health said, well, we have a hiring freeze now because of the economic crisis. So, we're just going to repurpose a few dozen people, within our public health department to do that, which is grossly inadequate.

States are not going to be in a position to do what we need to do in pandemic response, if they have giant budget holes and hiring freezes.

And third related priority is more funds for COVID testing and for contact tracing. There was a significant hunk of money that was just included in the fourth COVID package. However, that's not going to be enough. There's increasing evidence out there and bipartisan analysis out there that shows that we need significantly more money, particularly, given how many people likely have COVID, nationally, and how much testing and tracking is going to be involved to get that under control.

ADAMS: So, Jim, I'm sure you have some thoughts on that. And can you also talk about what you think is likely to happen in this legislation, what's likely to cross the finish line?

KAUFMAN: Thanks, Rebecca. And I would echo a lot of the comments that folks have said already are very, very important and we would support, as well.

For the children's hospitals, what we're going to be focusing on this next package is one, continuing to get more funding to the frontline providers like hospitals and pediatricians with more funding into the provider fund that was referenced earlier.

And as Eliot and Shawn noted, we've got to make sure that those funds also go to high Medicaid providers, which is absolutely critical.

I think one of the things that a lot of people don't realize is the testing that was referenced is going to be, absolutely, critical, as providers start to reopen and get services going again, which will definitely help alleviate some of the challenges. But that's going to vary, very much, from state to state and even local communities. So, that's why continued funding through that provider find will be absolutely critical to keep children's hospitals from avoiding layoffs, or reducing staffing issues and elimination of key services in the short run.

In addition to that, while that's a short-term relief, we also need to look at the long term. And this is one going back to Medicaid. We're also going to be supporting additional funding to the states for the Medicaid program. As I noted, the average children's hospital is 50 percent Medicaid. So, any cut at the state level, basically, will reduce any efforts to sustain those programs, long term. And we already recognize that Medicaid, on average, reimburses providers about 30 percent less than what Medicare provides.

And a lot of the Medicaid providers children's hospitals, pediatricians, OB/GYNs, didn't see any of the benefit that Congress provided in some of the previous bills for Medicare patients, like the 20 percent plus up, for treating COVID patients, the elimination of the Medicare sequester, efforts like that.

So, that's why those additional funds going to the states will be absolutely critical.

With that said, we also need to support policies at the federal level that will prevent putting money into the states and, at the same time, allowing the Fed to take money away from the states, such as blocking the implementation of the Medicaid fiscal accountability rule.

One report, before the COVID crisis started, noted that that rule, if implemented as drafted, can reduce federal funding to the states to the tune of $50 billion, annually. So, we can't be putting money in one pocket and taking it out of the other. So, we really need to look, comprehensively, at the funding going to the states and how we can support those efforts.

Now, what gets across the finish line at the end? I wish my crystal ball told me because it would make my job a lot easier. But I do think support for the frontline providers like hospitals, pediatricians and other, you know, healthcare professionals, will be included. And I'm optimistic that Congress will look to provide more funding to the states through an enhanced effort, some type of Medicaid support.

But that's one that's going to continue a lot of advocacy efforts to make sure policymakers on both sides of the aisle see how important Medicaid is.

ADAMS: I wish we had more time to talk even more about this topic. But let me turn to a new issue.

Tom, scientists around the globe are racing to find a vaccine to develop anti-viral treatment. And we've written a lot of these stories, over the past few weeks, about this, including yesterday's NIH announcement.

What can you tell us about your realistic expectations for the timing of the deployment of a vaccine? And what should we be watching for next, in terms of which ones are therapeutic?

DILENGE: Thanks. I'm happy to answer. Let me first, just back up a little bit and just kind of give you a sense of this unprecedented industry response we're seeing to this crisis.

There's about 350 R&D drug development programs under way that have been launched in the last 15 weeks, around the COVID.

You heard about a lot of the big ones that have been getting a lot of attention in the media. But the breadth, depth and creativity of this industry is really shining through, at this pivotal moment.

The speed is remarkable. We're doing things that, normally, take months and weeks. We're doing things that, normally, would take years and months. Companies are putting aside their own competitive and commercial interests. They are collaborating in a way that I've never seen before in the 15 years that I've been in this industry.

They're jumping right into deals and partnerships, before the lawyers can even write it all down. They're not worrying about things like intellectual property and other things, at this point.

The companies are making huge investments in capacity and production, often with the government's help, to build infrastructure to produce drugs that we don't even have yet and that we're only hoping will, someday, prove safety and efficacy. That's a huge risk that companies and the government are taking but we can't approach this, sequentially, like we would normally do in drug development, during a crisis.

So, this has really been, I think, a very hopeful kind of approach that people are taking. Some of it already, it's a bit chaotic, a bit unorganized. Then, maybe we just need to pick one or two that look most promising vaccines and have the government do a Manhattan project. We're hearing a little bit about that in the news, today and yesterday.

Unfortunately, that's not the way drug development works. We know most of these projects will fail; 90 percent of projects tend to fail. We also know that viruses can change. They adapt, they mutate. Not all drugs, or vaccines, are going to work in all populations, or in different stages of the disease.

So, we need many shots on goal, using many different approaches and technologies. And that's what we're seeing, right now, which is great. Frustrating but takes time. There is no substitute, really, for regular science and data analysis. Vaccines in particular, take time to develop the right safety data. And we know that not all vaccines work for everybody.

So, when you're thinking about a vaccine where you are thinking about a little longer term, you've heard some of the reports that there are, well, there's about 11 vaccines that are already in human trials, which is good. Again, unprecedented speed. But what we're really looking at is, probably, this fall, that we can have some emergency use vaccines for frontline workers, those who are at greatest risk of exposure, or who have been exposed, and we can use it, afterwards, as a prophylactic post-exposure.

To get to mass production, to do populations in the United States and around the world, we are probably looking at, at least, a year. It's hard to imagine we can do it much quicker. But you know, everyone is working really hard to do that.

The good news, Rebecca, is that, in the meantime, we have a whole bunch of therapeutic treatments that are coming, hopefully, on line, in the next couple of months. We've all heard about Gilead's antiviral that had great data from yesterday. We expect that to, probably, get an FDA emergency use of authorization, pretty soon, could even be this week.

We have other ones that are also, a lot of antivirals that are in clinical trials that are in, you know, late stage trials. So, we're really optimistic that, over the summer, we're going to start to see kind of a broadening of our tool box to help treat patients that are infected. And that's really important to buy this time to get to a mass population vaccine. And it allows our healthcare workers to be protected. It allows the economy our start to reopen and allows patients to, hopefully, not progress to a really serious disease with COVID.

So, we're really optimistic that all of the approaches that are being taken that some of them are going to work. We're going to have more tools in this toolbox for our healthcare providers and were going to, hopefully, be in much better position to reopen this economy and know that we can treat people who might get infected and become sick.

ADAMS: And that's an (INAUDIBLE) questions on that and, if you have a question, please go ahead and submit it. So, let me stay with you for a moment and just circle back to the CARES Act funding. There was some funding in there that you have been watching closely. Can you tell us a little bit about how the implementation of that funding has been proceeding?

DILENGE: Yeah, so, HHS has had a program called BARDA, which is mostly focused on bio defense work, for years. It's never been funded enough. The good news is, is that Congress gave them a lot more money in several of the COVID bills that passed, over the last two months.

We have, probably, somewhere between $8 billion and $10 billion now, that's available for the government to partner with biotechnology companies to push forward allowing this promising research I was talking about.

The problem is, you know, with everything else, is that it's never seems to be fast enough, right. There's--the HHS has done some big deals. You've read about them in the paper. A couple hundred million dollars for this project, a couple hundred million dollars for that project. These are mostly projects that are building off of past work that we've done for other outbreaks and infectious diseases.

There's so many new approaches out there for COVID. And we have about 2,500 submissions for funding right now, from companies into HHS. Very few have been funded, to date.

And I think, what we'd like to see, is HHS give out more money as seed money to a broader group of companies and approaches because, as I was saying earlier, we need many shots on goal. We'd like to see a broad-based approach to getting money out the door, quicker, in smaller amounts. We don't need hundreds of millions of dollars. We need smaller amounts that can catalyze some of the private capital that's holding back, waiting to see where the government experts may place some of their bets.

There's just are so many different programs out there, potential R&D programs. We do need to work with the government to figure out how we can get money to catalyze different approaches.

Think about it almost like a Chinese restaurant menu. You want a couple from column A, a couple from column B. You want some treatments; you want some antivirals, you want some vaccines. And even within vaccines, for example, there's five or six different types of approaches and about 80 different programs going on.

So, you need to kind of, strategically, look at the funding proposals, across the board, better than one offs. Look at them, strategically, and say, are we, do we have a holistic strategy about making sure that we're going to have enough shots on goal in the different areas that matter, so that, hopefully, come the fall, or early next year, we have a very good toolbox of treatments and vaccines available for people.

That's what we'd like to see, in terms of improvement in the funding for R&D partnerships.

ADAMS: All right. Just a reminder, we will be turning to audience questions in just a few moments. And there will be a recording of this webinar that people can look at, later.

Tom, one more question. What are some of the longer-term issues that might result from the laws that have been enacted, so far, this year?

DILENGE: Yeah, well, you know, we're really hopeful that this pandemic, I mean, you know, it's so sad, in terms of the toll economic and on patients and the deaths in families, a terrible pandemic.

I hope that one silver lining from this is that Congress and the administration, and we've had trouble over bipartisan administrations and bipartisan congresses, getting enough focus on long-term pandemic preparedness.

BIO has been a leader in this, for years. And I'm the first to say, we have not done a good enough job and we have not convinced enough people in Congress that they need to focus on pandemic preparedness, as a long-term sustainable infrastructure that we need, year end and year out, rather than just in crises.

For example, Rebecca, we have done so much, in the last couple of months, to build systems to just share basic information between the government and companies, in terms of these types of viruses and, particularly, COVID.

We have the virus, itself, data sharing around the sequencing of it and all these different types of approaches to treating it.

We're doing that on the fly now, in a very ad hoc way. We could have been, we could be a month or two ahead, in terms of the diagnostics in some of these early treatments, than we are today.

If we had had these systems built for better surveillance, better information sharing and better partnering, between industry and government, right when something starts to hit, as opposed to trying to build it on the fly, during a crisis.

ADAMS: We do see the hearings around these discussions when they already test the crisis and then it seems like the momentum fades.

I want to turn to the rest of the panelists and bring everyone in. I wanted to just talk a little bit about some of the steps that federal officials have taken, change regulations and policies during this pandemic.

Which of those do think will actually continue, after all of this is a few years in the background? Are there additional regulatory actions, also, that you're looking for and that are your priorities for the Trump administration?

So, Jim, could you address that question?

KAUFMAN: Sure, like I said, the first thing we'll be looking at is as we're trying to provide some more Medicaid funding to the states, trying to prevent some of the things that was on the table before the COVID crisis hit.

Medicaid fiscal accountability is a great example. Some opportunities now, is with the telehealth, is there may be some opportunities to keep those in place, long-term. We've seen a patchwork of efforts at the state level with Medicaid reimbursement for that. So, hopefully, we will see, as a result of this, some opportunities to keep things in place longer and make it easier for kids and other Medicaid recipients to receive care, through telehealth.

ADAMS: All right. Shawn, what are your thoughts?

MARTIN: Yeah, I think it's a really interesting question. And maybe we'll head turn at the fear. I'm not real sure how to answer.

So, I think the--I think on telehealth, I would echo that. I think we jumped forward about a decade, on telehealth and virtual health platforms. And I think many of the regulations, although, I think they will be dialed back, slightly, or right sized, if you will, to kind of correct some over reaches, I do think telehealth and virtual health is here to stay in a more robust manner.

I think the challenge will be how do you incorporate that into the, you know, work flows of the entire healthcare system and not just of an episodic nature of acute telehealth lenses on. And--but I think the regulations will be designed to support that.

I think the other place where we're going to see kind of a continuing effort on a policy front is the relationship between healthcare systems, particularly, in rural America, the dependence on the public health preference of Medicaid and Medicare, the kind of lack of robust private insurance markets in those communities and the impact that has on hospitals, long-term care, physicians, of course, but I think an increased spotlight was put on rural delivery healthcare systems.

And then, in a more kind of controversial way, I think we've reignited the discussion about the relationship between individuals and their lawyers and health coverage. And I think that's a discussion that's going to continue to kind of build, as we move to the fall into the future as individuals that rely upon their employers for healthcare coverage, when there is an economic downturn or a personal event, what that means sort of in an economic sense, a healthcare sense that individual and family.

And I think this debate is coming back.

ADAMS: All right. Eliot just a few thoughts from you on this.

FISHMAN: Well, I certainly agree that the debate around health coverage is going to have a major new reexamination. Of course, this pandemic is happening, during an election year.

And the first way in which the discussions are going to play out, will be in presidential debates of, literally, an end, figuratively.

And I think that, not only the timing of (INAUDIBLE) employment, the automaticness of insurance in the United States is really the only country in the advanced world, even in terms of countries that have mixed systems between public and private insurance, like we do, in which you can have tens of millions of people falling through the cracks and having to make the application processes to get help coverage.

Another major policy area that is not new but, certainly, has had a harsh light thrown on it by the pandemic. And I anticipate will be a major new policy discussion, or renewed policy discussion, is inequities in health and inequities in access to healthcare.

And if you look at the racial and ethnic distribution of COVID hospitalizations and COVID that's in the major hotspots around the country, there are very stark disparities really, breathtaking disparities, by race and ethnicity.

And that is not a simple problem. But it is an urgent one. And like a number of the problems that we've been talking about here, it should always have been urgent. And the pandemic is, hopefully, a silver lining, is that it is throwing such a prominent light on that problem.

ADAMS: All right, we have a few questions from some listeners. So, the first question is, do we know anything more on the potential buy American, or international pricing index executive orders? Who would like to address that question?

DILENGE: I can. This is Tom. So, first of all, on the buy American, we do anticipate the administration will be issuing some type of executive order to look at the U.S. medical supply chain, right, and to kind of make sure that we have, domestically, the ability to serve our people, right. And making sure that we're not overly reliant on unstable sources of supply, whether it's for drug substances, or manufacturing capabilities, etc.

This is an issue that has been percolating for a while. I think it's going to get a lot more attention, certainly, on Capitol Hill and with the administration. And I would just urge that we all think about this very deliberately because these supply chains are very complicated for medical products, not just drugs, but also, it's medical products.

And we have to really resist the temptation to think that we can build everything here in America and keep it all, here in America. You know, there is--we see some countries, around the world, that have tried to limit exports of critical supplies. Unfortunately, our own administration has kind of dabbled in that, as well.

And that's a really dangerous situation, when you're dealing with a global pandemic. So, we need to make sure that the supply chains are robust and resilient. But we also have to make sure, at the same time, that we're not kind of creating a too nationalistic approach to supply chains in this global economy. It just won't work.

It doesn't mean that we shouldn't be secure in knowing that we've got some excess capacity redundant supplies, within the boundaries of a country. We have a national stockpile. It's woefully, inadequate for our needs. I think we realize that, now.

States and hospitals and the federal government all need to do a better job of making sure we have that capacity available and ready in the supplies. But we do expect to see a lot of movement on this with the administration and with Congress,

On the international pricing index, I think that's a reference to the Trump administration's proposal, from a year or so ago, to try to tie drug prices to foreign drug prices. We haven't heard much about that, recently. I think the focus, obviously, now is on making sure we have robust research and development of new treatments and vaccines for COVID. And our companies, as I think you've probably seen in the press, repeatedly, we have committed to making sure that these products are affordable and accessible to everyone that needs them.

I don't think drug crisis is the time is the time be talking about drug pricing. It's never been an issue in pandemics, before. And our companies are leading the way in developing these cures and will make sure that they're affordable and accessible to everybody.

ADAMS: So, we have a question following up on the CARES Act money. Perhaps, Jim, you might be able to handle this one. Will there be situations where some providers receive too much money in the first allocation, based on Medicare revenue, compared to the allocation based on total revenues and will providers be required to pay back the difference? Jim, have you heard anything about that?

KAUFMAN: A great question. I'll be honest, I have not heard any provider talk about getting more money than what they've lost.

I mean, what we've been seeing, so far, is the amount of funding that we've seen from some of our hospitals, it's covering, you know, less than a third of losses that have incurred, already. And we're not talking about the losses that are continuing.

So, I think the dollars that are going in are critical to help keep hospitals, providers operating and avoid some cuts. However, it's not going to plug the holes from you know, being created the national response.

ADAMS: We have a question about testing. Is enough testing worth it, given many false positives? Shawn, would you be able to take that one?

MARTIN: Yeah, I'd be happy to. I'm not an epidemiologist so, you know, it's necessary to say that up front.

I do think mass testing is a critical component of our national strategy, to kind of reopen the economy and create the free flow of people. And I think there's, you know, more data coming out about the individuals that do not have visible symptoms, or either have symptoms that are identifiable that probably are able to participate in viral spread.

But I think the testing is going to be really important to identify and isolate people, so that they, you know, can protect the general population. I just worry, until there is a vaccine, it's encouraging the progress we're making towards a vaccine and antivirals, absent some type of herd community or a vaccine, testing is going to be their only way to isolate individuals from, you know, their families and general population, moving forward. So, I would answer yes, I think it's very much worth it.

ADAMS: Okay. There's a question on billing legislation. Is there a chance that surprise billing provision could be included in the next phase of coronavirus legislation? Has anyone heard anything about that?

MARTIN: So, this is Shawn. I would jump in here, as well. I think surprise billing has been front line for a number of congressional committees and members of Congress for well over a year, now. I think it continues to be a priority issue, generally speaking, in the healthcare policy realm on Capitol Hill in the administration.

I don't know that it bubbles up. I think there's just a lot of competition for dollars and attention, right now. I think, if you did a poll, everybody would say that they should do something about surprise billing. But I think it's always going to kind of be in that after, you know, a couple of bullet points down from the other urgent healthcare issues that are being discussed, right now.

ADAMS: We will have other vehicles later in the year, including appropriations and also from the extenders I think expire in November, if I remember correctly.

I wonder if it might be something that could be attached to another bill later on.

FISHMAN: This is Eliot from Families USA. I think, if were thinking about just huge vulnerabilities in our healthcare system that are getting a harsh light thrown on them, that is certainly one of them. And it is true that there ought to be a healthcare extenders must pass kind of legislative vehicle that would require and offset that surprise billing reform can provide, in the fall.

But this is, also, a barrier to people accessing healthcare, both for COVID and other kinds of healthcare between now and the fall at a bad time for there to be barriers.

And certainly, it is helpful that the Trump administration has said for and that providers who are receiving CARES Act funds and related funds cannot engage in surprise billing practices. That's not really a comprehensive solution and it's notable that there's no real way for consumers for patients to know which providers those are.

So, if we can't get this done in the next package, that's bad news at a bad time. And certainly, at a minimum, we're hopeful that we can get to it later this year.

ADAMS: Okay, alright. Let me stay with you for this next question and others may want to jump on this, as well. It's about Medicaid expansion. Will Congress include incentives for states that have not expanded Medicaid to move forward with expansion and any chance that Florida, or Texas, might move forward to expand Medicaid?

FISHMAN: There's certainly a chance in that the, unfortunately, the population of people who are uninsured and in states that have expanded Medicaid can get Medicaid and in Florida and Texas and the other remaining expansion states can't and aren't really eligible for anything realistic, in terms of insurance coverage. That population is growing, rapidly, in the middle of a pandemic.

And the other thing that really should be noted, is that states can undo an expansion. No state has ever done that. But if Florida, or Texas, were to pursue an expansion on an emergency basis, if, at some point later on, they felt that it was a mistake, again, I think it's unlikely that any state would ever conclude that but they do have that option. And perhaps, that can provide some cover for an emergency expansion measure and the remaining on it.

ADAMS: Okay. We have a couple of questions about artificial intelligence. And Tom, I'm going to direct this one to you.

Can new technologies, such as AI machine learning, help speed up some of the R&D, in terms of finding vaccines and treatments?

DILENGE: The short answer is, yes, it already is. So, I believe that there are a lot of the big tech companies and other, even smaller ones with AI capabilities, are already working with our companies in the biopharmaceutical space to help that, to help speed those processes along.

Absolutely, I think very important, when it comes to things like testing, in particular, but I think even for other drug development work, absolutely, the short answer is, yes, and it's already happening. And I think that that will be another outcome, long term outcome of this pandemic, is a speeding up of those kinds of partnerships, going forward, across the board, on other types of diseases, as well.

ADAMS: Interesting. Another AI question. Can technology, such as robotics, be used to do COVID testing, without exposing medical personnel? Who wants to take this one?

MARTIN: So, this is Shawn. I will try.

I think it's possible. I mean, I would never rule out anything in kind of this area and the ability of technology to be deployed to improve patient care.

I do, I have a hard time visualizing that a cotton swab with somebody's nose being delivered by a robot but I think, if you got to more finger prick, you know, saliva type testing, you might be use AI and robotics in a kind of porta care patient directed testing environment. I can certainly visualize that. I can see that working.

ADAMS: I actually wanted to circle back a little bit on telemedicine and telehealth. We talked about this a bit but I wonder if we can talk a little bit more about what you might see, going forward, and what kind of conversations are happening, right now, with the administration on that. Could someone build on that a little bit more?

MARTIN: This is Shawn. I'd be happy to go first. I think we, I think there's a couple of things on the deployment of the technology side and I believe it was Eliot, earlier, that talked about how the COVID pandemic, or crisis, has brought the light in a number of disparities and trying to accessing healthcare and securing equal healthcare, across different geographies and socioeconomic classes.

And I think telemedicine is, obviously, one of those areas. Not everyone has access to broadband, or Internet, or a smart phone that makes telemedicine possible. Then a lot of, you know, older people certainly do not have the capabilities because of their health conditions, can necessarily, engage in a telemedicine visit, without a caregiver, or somebody else being there.

So, I think we have a lot of opportunities to think about how to make tele-medicine work, equitable, across all geographies and socioeconomic classes to kind of eliminate some disparities, there.

I think, as I think about telemedicine, when it's real, I think we're framing it as more of a 21st century house call. I don't know that it's in the pandemic modality of care that will, you know, kind of render everything else not important, or unusable.

I think it's going to be a modality of care that gets incorporated in care plans, gets used in a more robust way, as house calls have been at various points, throughout history, with physicians.

But I think it's exciting about expanding access to care in the home, certainly, considered a convenience. And I think anything that connects people with healthcare in a more equitable way is going to be a really good thing, moving forward.

I think we have to work on some payment issues and I think we have to work on some licensure legal issues about the location of the patient, location of the physician and state licensure laws. But all of those things seem really achievable, now.

ADAMS: All right.

KAUFMAN: And this is Jim, if I could jump in on that. A couple things to add. I mean, there's been some great opportunities with the administration, even in the TRICARE program, which is the Department of Defense health program. They're making some steps, when improving access, using telehealth services.

But one of the big challenges that we continue to face in pediatrics is the 50 different flavors of Medicaid and every state having its own policy. So, having more consistency, across the country and that would be hugely helpful.

And it goes to the state licensure piece and, actually, the registration of the programs because, not every state has every provider and having to have a provider register in every state Medicaid program creates just huge administrative burdens.

But the one thing is telehealth is not a panacea. I mean, although it's being used for behavioral health services, especially as this crisis is creating more challenges in that space. Sometimes, it's not appropriate to have a behavioral health visit at the home with a child, when they really should be in a more protected location.

So, this is when it's a definitely help improving access but it's not a solution for everything.

ADAMS: Okay. And regarding telehealth, there's another question from the audience. Where we headed with state-based licensing for providers? Are you expecting changes that are just following up on what was previously said?

Tom, you haven't talked about this. Do you want to jump in here and does anyone else want to address this?

DILENGE: Yeah, I believe I can address that question about state licensure. I do want to add that, relatedly, on the telehealth, is the issue of Medicare, Part B patients-Part B, as in boy. These are drugs that are administered, usually, in a physician office for very serious diseases, complicated chronic diseases, cancers and others.

What we've seen, so far, is some good initial steps by the Trump administration to make home infusion of these products more readily available for patients, so they don't have to go into hospital settings, or doctor offices to get these treatments.

Very important, right now in COVID, but long term, it provides an option, as well, that can help lower costs of medicine, generally speaking. And I think that's a good trend, hopefully, one that can continue but we do, as, I think it was Shawn, or Eliot alluded to, we have to fix some of the regulatory and payment structure issues, within Medicare Part B, to make sure we can do that kind of home infusion safely but also, and that it makes sense for providers and for the patients, themselves, to get it done that way, which I think will lower system costs, overall,

I'm sorry, I can't answer the state licensure question.

ADAMS: Anyone else want to jump in on that question. Tom, thank you for your insight.

MARTIN: Rebecca, this is Shawn. I'm happy to cause controversy.

I think this is a really, you know, this is a difficult issue, just kind of built upon principles of federalism and the ability of governors and state legislatures to determine commerce in their states.

And at the end of the day, you know, who's licensed to provide healthcare services in a state has, you know, historically, been under the jurisdictions of governors and state legislatures and state oversight agencies. And I just, although there is the ability to relax those provisions for the purposes of a pandemic, and I think we should explore how to streamline that more in the future, I just, I struggle with state 50 governors giving that up on a permanent basis.

But I would be happy to be further along their, potentially, but it just seems like a, maybe, a step too far for the governors.

KAUFMAN: Rebecca, related to that, what's not state licensure--this is Jim-- there is legislation up on the Hill that would allow enrollment in Medicaid programs a little bit easier, by allowing providers to register with Medicare and then, the states would accept that for registration in their Medicaid program.

So, it's not perfect under the state licensure peace but it does reduce an administrative burden for providers to help improve access.

ADAMS: Very interesting. Well, thank you all so much. I really appreciate this. Just a warning to the panelists, you may be hearing from our recording team to follow up on some of the things that you said, today.

Thank you so much. This has been a great conversation. I'd like to thank our audience, as well. We know your time is valuable and we appreciate you spending it with us.

As a follow-up, we will be sending out a recording of today's webinar. So, if you're looking for resources that can help you monitor the politics and policy around COVID-19, please visit coronavirus.fiscalnote.com.

Thank you, everyone, and have a great rest of your day. That's all for now.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TNR-NXS1-JCJY-G51N-00000-00Fiscal Phil keeps room for Brexit2018-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:51:12ZLexisNexisINVESTMENTSVersion:1Fiscal Phil keeps room for BrexitEd Smith

The Chancellor put together the 2018 Budget knowing that he borrowed more than £5bn less in the 2017 to 2018 fiscal year than he thought he had at the time of the Spring Statement, and that borrowing between April and September in the current fiscal year was 35 per cent lower than during the same period last year - twice as a big a reduction as forecast.

Uncharacteristically, he reallocated this windfall to future spending. So how much more is Philip Hammond forking out?

By the end of the current Parliament, the government will spend an additional £17.9bn while raising just an additional £280m in taxes.

But remember, this is relative to the spending plans already set out. That's crucial to assessing the validity of Mr Hammond's proclamation that "austerity is coming to an end". It is no more than rhetoric and the politically-neutral Office for Budget Responsibility's (OBR's) report tells a different story.

Mr Hammond previewed the spending review by announcing that day-to-day spending limits will rise by an average of 1.2 per cent a year.

At best, fiscal policy won't be getting any more austere in 2019 to 2020, but the OBR's numbers clearly show that the cyclically adjusted budget deficit will tighten again from 2020 to 2021. And that's after eight long years of extraordinary fiscal tightening. As a result, we are not changing our outlook for the UK economy. Low growth and tight fiscal policy is here to stay.

The 'giveaway'

Nevertheless, public sector net borrowing is likely to be 1.9 per cent of national income this year, back in line with the 70-year average, albeit still above the 1.3 per cent average seen during the Tony Blair years (1997 to 2007).

But a net giveaway Budget does not reverse eight years of austerity. Sure, total real spending has fallen by just 1.5 per cent from a peak of £800bn in 2010 to 2011, but this must be seen in the context of an increasing, aged population that requires more government services. In this context, eight years of cuts were deep and unprecedented. The average department's budget was cut by 20 per cent.

All told, total public spending as a share of GDP has fallen from 45 per cent in 2009 to 2010 to 38 per cent, close to the US's 36 per cent which has always been viewed as disconcertingly low.

Mr Hammond previewed the spending review by announcing that day-to-day spending limits will rise by an average of 1.2 per cent a year. However, the OBR clearly illustrates that real expenditure limits per capita will not rise at all once we exclude the NHS. Moreover, the government has discretely slashed the money set aside for long-term capital spending in the coming years. According to the OBR, the capital spending budget has been cut by £7bn per year in 2020 to 2021.

The fiscal rules

The chancellor delivered his net giveaway Budget while lowering the national debt to GDP ratio by 2020 to 2021 and keeping the structural deficit below 2 per cent of national income. But he had to jettison one of his fiscal rules and a manifesto pledge to run a fiscal surplus from the mid-2020s.

Reneging on the rule shouldn't concern investors; we have had 12 fiscal rules since 1997, and 10 of those have been broken or abandoned. Markets rarely bat an eyelid. It's been seven decades since there were four consecutive years without a deficit.

Gilt yields were unmoved. Unsurprising given that the UK has the second lowest public debt to GDP ratio among the G7.

Raising the minimum wage

The 4.9 per cent rise in the national living wage will help lower-income households. Someone, somewhere must pay for higher minimum wages. Either domestic firms make less profit, cut jobs or other benefits, or pass the costs onto households in the form of higher prices.

In practice, there's precious little evidence that firms cut jobs as a result of higher minimum wages. But that may be because the historic examples start from a relatively low base. Theoretically, there must be a point beyond which higher minimum wages lower employment, but that point is unknown.

We do not expect the higher living wage to exert significant pressure on inflation - historically this relationship has been very weak.

Tax on big tech

The new "tech tax" is aimed at technology platform providers with large revenues. A new tax on business is not something one would expect from a Conservative Chancellor, especially one designed with explicit interventionist intentions. However, it could be seen as correcting for a market distortion created by the tax loopholes that online companies use so deftly.

After a year with a net outflow of foreign direct investment, one might be concerned about disincentivising investment from globally dominant companies. But it is a sign of the times for techs. The next decade is likely to see a tightening of regulation in all jurisdictions and we are keeping an eye on long-term earnings projections.

Having said that, big tech appears committed to maintaining UK headquarters, despite Brexit uncertainty.

Do we need Brexit 'headroom'?

The Chancellor maintained headroom of around £15bn against his fiscal rule to reduce the structural budget deficit to 2 per cent of GDP by 2020 to 2021.

We sometimes hear that forecasts of economic deterioration were wide of the mark after the referendum, so pessimistic forecasts may be similarly wide of the mark after a "no deal".

That said, those post-referendum forecasts may not have been as wrong as you might think.

For example, after the referendum the Bank of England estimated that GDP would increase by just 0.5 per cent over the 12 months to June 2017, after which the economy would gather more steam and increase by 3 per cent to September 2018. Actually, GDP increased by about 2 per cent over the first 12 months, before decelerating to grow by 1.5 per cent to September 2018 (we've estimated the final quarter based on the monthly data available so far).

So, while the popular narrative has it that the initial forecasts were way off, the 27-month forecast was actually spot on; the economy just took a different route.

At the time, we thought other forecasters' initial estimates were too pessimistic but the first 12 months beat even our expectations, largely because households unexpectedly decreased their rate of saving.

Key Points

The outlook for the UK economy remains unchanged, with low growth and tight fiscal policy ahead.

The new "tech tax" could be seen as correcting for a market distortion.

The Chancellor has maintained some fiscal headroom in preparation for Brexit.

The size of the UK's trade in services relative to its economy is bigger than any other large advanced economy's. Its manufacturing is one of the most specialised, involving above average use of overseas supply chains. Even if Brexit eventually turns out to be a great change of direction, the disruption to regulatory regimes and supply chains that a hard Brexit would entail over the short to medium term means that the likelihood of investment surprising to the upside is very low indeed.

So, in short, the Chancellor is wise to keep some fiscal headroom.

We believe the most likely outcome next year is a deal de minimis with the salient details still to be hammered out during an extended negotiating period. Indeed, in the past fortnight the EU and UK have reportedly considered a year's extension to the two-year transition period, taking us to December 2021.

However, that would overlap with the start of the EU's next seven-year budget cycle, and could leave the UK liable for a bigger 'divorce bill'.

Economically, by preserving 'business as usual' for another three years, a transition extension would likely be positive for the economy. That said, it sustains the cloud of uncertainty and could potentially hold back investment decisions for longer.

The bottom line is that neither the Budget nor Brexit are globally important events, and the global revenue streams underlying most investors' portfolios should be unmoved.

Ed Smith is head of asset allocation research at Rathbones
